question: A 67-year-old woman who was diagnosed with arthritis 16 years ago presents with right knee swelling and pain. Her left knee was swollen a few weeks ago, but now with both joints affected, she has difficulty walking and feels frustrated. She also has back pain which makes it extremely difficult to move around and be active during the day. She says her pain significantly improves with rest. She also suffers from dandruff for which she uses special shampoos. Physical examination is notable for pitting of her nails. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old man presents to the office with concerns about his long struggle with his physical appearance since adolescence. He says he has always been "large" and was constantly targeted by his classmates and coworkers for being so. His main concern at the moment is his acne and unwanted facial hair on his upper lip, for which he often visits a local spa. He has tried numerous diet plans, exercise regimens, and cosmetic products with little to no effect. Recently, he underwent a glucose tolerance test that showed a plasma glucose level of 160 mg/dL (8.9 mmol/L) after 2 hours of a 75 g dose of oral glucose. He has a family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and a menstrual cycle that occurs every 45 days. His pulse is 72/min and the blood pressure is 138/80 mm Hg. On physical examination, his height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) and his weight is 85 kg (187 lb), and he has severe inflammatory acne over the cheeks and forehead and dark coarse hairs on the back. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of tingling pain in the sole of her right foot when she raises it above chest level during exercises. She reports that she started exercising regularly 2 months ago and that her right calf cramps when she uses the incline feature on the treadmill, forcing him to take frequent breaks. The pain completely disappears after resting for a few minutes. She has an 8-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. Her only medication is metformin. Her pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. Straight leg raise test elicits pallor and tingling pain in the right foot. There is no pain in the back. Her muscle strength is normal. Femoral pulses are palpable; right pedal pulses are absent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.B: Vasculitis of the right popliteal artery
options.C: Acute thrombosis of right popliteal vein

question: A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. The patient was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head on collision. The patient’s echocardiogram (ECG) is notable only for sinus tachycardia. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is given 2 liters of Ringer lactate solution and morphine. Initial workup demonstrates that the patient’s pulmonary capillary wedge pressure and troponins are elevated. The patient is currently complaining of chest pain. Physical exam is notable for an uncomfortable young woman with bruising over her chest wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. On arrival, he is lethargic and incoherent. He has severe facial lacerations and is in respiratory distress. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows a fractured left second rib, depression of the left mainstem bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man presents following a suicide attempt 2 days ago. He says that his attempt was a result of a fight with his girlfriend and that he slit his wrists in an attempt to keep him from breaking up with her. In the past, he has had many turbulent relationships, both romantic and in his family life. His family members describe his as being very impulsive and frequently acting to manipulate people’s feelings. Since he was admitted to the hospital, he has spit at several staff members and alternated between sobbing and anger. He has no significant past medical history. The patient denies any history of smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a check-up. She presents with a 1-year history of worsening shortness of breath and weight loss. She is a former construction worker, and worked in a steel mill when she was in high school. She is an active smoker with a 36-pack-year smoking history. The blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg, pulse rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and the BMI is 31 kg/m2. The patient is afebrile and the oxygen saturation at rest is 95% on room air. The pulmonary examination reveals a mildly prolonged expiratory phase, and no wheezing or crackles are auscultated. A pulmonary function test is recommended for the patient, and 2 weeks later she returns with a report that shows an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60% and FEV1 of 50% of the predicted value. The lung volumes show a total lung capacity of 110% of predicted value, a residual volume of 115% of predicted value, and a DLCO of 60% of predicted value. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a change in her behavior over the past few months. Initially, the patient was noted to be behaving inappropriately including using foul language and grabbing people unexpectedly. This has progressed to a worsening of her memory and trouble caring for himself. Her temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 162/103 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an elderly woman who laughs inappropriately at times and who is a poor historian. When she is engaged in conversation, she exhibits word finding difficulty and is rather inattentive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a generalized rash for 3 days. During this period, she has had severe itching and was not able to sleep well. She has also had fever, headache, and some muscle pain. Five days ago, she had a runny nose which subsided with over-the-counter medications. She returned from a camping trip 1 week ago. She attends a daycare center. The patient is at the 55th percentile for height and at the 50th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows several macules, papules, and crusted lesions over her face, trunk, and extremities. There are a few fluid-filled vesicles over her abdomen and back. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman presents to the office for shortness of breath. The shortness of breath started a year ago and is exacerbated by physical activity. She has been working in the glass manufacturing industry for 20 years. Her vital signs include: heart rate 72/min, respiratory rate 30/min, and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. On physical exam, there are diminished respiratory sounds on both sides. On the chest radiograph, interstitial fibrosis with reticulonodular infiltrate is found on both sides, and there is also an eggshell calcification of multiple adenopathies. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his brother for severe chest pain. The patient recently lost his wife in a car accident and is still extremely shocked by the event. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 105/67 mm Hg, the heart rate is 96/min and regular, breathing rate is 23/min, and the pulse oximetry is 96%. An S3 heart sound and rales in the lower right and left lung lobes are heard. A 12-lead ECG shows no significant findings. Echocardiography shows an enlarged left ventricle and left atrium. The patient is stabilized and informed about the diagnosis and possible treatment options. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman presents to a rheumatologist with bilateral wrist and knee pain that has been present for the last 10 years. The patient was a professional athlete who retired at age 50. She also notes morning stiffness in her joints that lasts approx. 50 minutes. She denies joint swelling, color changes in her digits, dryness of mucous membranes, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and chills. On physical exam, the physician notes several non-tender nodules on the left 1st, 3rd, and 4th distal interphalangeal joints. There is also tenderness with palpation at the base of both thumbs. The patient’s knees are enlarged, bilaterally, and she has pain and crepitus on passive range of motion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency room complaining of left shoulder pain for several weeks. She says that the pain often worsens when she tries to sleep on her left side. Although she tried several pain medications, none of the pain medications helped. She is an amateur tennis player who practices on weekends. She denies any trauma during her practice sessions. On examination of the shoulder joint, severe tenderness was present localized to the greater tuberosity of the left shoulder joint along with biceps tendon tenderness over the bicipital groove. The range of motion was limited to the left side. An X-ray of the joint showed narrowing of the acromiohumeral space with sclerosis and spurring of the acromion. Routine blood test results are normal except for the rheumatoid factor, which is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.B: Referred pain from the neck and back

question: A 58-year-old white woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless lesion on her lower lip. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. She has worked as a fruit picker for the past 25 years. Her current medications include captopril and metformin. Examination of the oral cavity shows a single ulcer near the vermillion border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old man presents from home hospice with a change in his mental status. He has seemed more confused lately and is unable to verbalize his symptoms. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 117/65 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a right upper quadrant mass that elicits discomfort when palpated. Ultrasound is notable for pericholecystic fluid and gallbladder wall thickening without any gallstones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old Caucasian female presents to your office with hypopigmented skin. She undergoes a skin biopsy and is found to have an absence of melanocytes in the epidermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-year-old child complains of pain in the leg while playing. Blood pressure in the upper limb is 140/90 mm Hg and lower limbs are 110/70 mm Hg. There is a brachiofemoral delay in the pulse. Auscultation shows a loud S1, loud S2, and S4. There is a presence of an ejection systolic murmur in the interscapular area. Chest X-ray reveals the notching of the ribs. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 68-year-old woman from California presents for a routine checkup. She does not have any complaints. She says that she has tried to keep himself healthy and active by jogging and gardening since her retirement at age 50. She adds that she spends her mornings in the park and her afternoons in her garden. She has no significant medical history. The patient denies any smoking history and drinks alcohol occasionally. On physical examination, the following lesion is seen on her scalp (see image). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old white woman presents to her primary care provider for an annual examination. She notes a pink bump that has rapidly developed on her forehead over the last month. In the past, she has had significant sun exposure including multiple blistering sunburns. The physical examination reveals a 2 cm dome-shaped plaque with a central keratin plug (as shown in the image). Excisional biopsy of the lesion reveals an exophytic nodule with central invagination, full of keratin. Keratinocyte atypia is minimal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of concerns about his behavior during the past 2 years. He does not have friends and spends most of the time reading by herself. His father says that he comes up with excuses to avoid family dinners and other social events. He states that he likes reading and feels more comfortable on his own. On mental status examination, his thought process is organized and logical. His affect is flat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old man was referred to a dermatology clinic due to a changing discoloration of his fingers from white to red to blue. Although he has not had any recent changes in his daily routines, he also complains of increasing fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss. He has a blood pressure of 126/77 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 14/min, and heart rate of 88/min. Physical examination reveals regular heart and lung sounds. Anti-U1 RNP antibodies and increased creatinine kinase were found in his serum. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency room with right arm pain and limited range of motion. He does not recall trauma to the arm. He also complains of diarrhea and nausea. He is sexually active with one male partner and admits to having pain during intercourse. There is vague and diffuse tenderness to palpation in all four abdominal quadrants. No erythema or edema is noted on the right arm. The fecal occult test is negative. Past records show that this patient has been in the ER 7 times in the past year with similar symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old woman presents to a psychiatrist complaining of mood fluctuations. She is accompanied by her mother who reports that the patient recently experienced a 5-day episode of minimal sleep and unusual levels of energy. The patient admits to spending $2,000 of her parent’s money, without asking, on a down payment for a motorcycle. The episode resolved after 5 days, at which point the patient felt guilty and upset. The patient’s medical history is notable for multiple month-long episodes in the past 2 years of feeling sad, sleeping more than usual, being uninterested in her hobbies, and feeling constantly tired and guilty. The patient has a history of severe meningoencephalitis at the age of 17 requiring four days in the intensive care unit. During that episode, she reported seeing monkeys in her hospital room. On exam, she is a well-appearing, cooperative male in no acute distress. She is alert and oriented with a normal affect. She states that she feels sad and guilty about what happens. She denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of intermittent flank pain. Over the past 2 years, he has had five urinary tract infections. His blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral, nontender upper abdominal masses. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 29 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 1.4 mg/dL. Renal ultrasonography shows bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple parenchymal anechoic masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old woman presents with sudden loss of consciousness while pitching in a baseball game. There is no history of injury. Consciousness is regained after cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Past medical history is negative for any neurological and cardiovascular problems. Physical examination reveals a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse. There are no audible murmurs. An S4 is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old female presents to your office complaining that she is too weak to climb stairs or brush her hair. She denies any headaches or change in vision. A muscle biopsy reveals CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration in the endomysium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painless lump on his neck for 3 months that has increased in size. He appears healthy. Examination shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, irregular swelling on the left side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound of the neck shows a solitary left lobe thyroid mass with increased vascularity and hyperechogenic punctate regions. A fine needle aspiration biopsy is scheduled for the following week. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.C: Hürthle cell carcinoma of the thyroid

question: A 20-year-old man presents with vaginal discharge, pruritus, and painful micturition for the past 5 days. He is sexually active with multiple partners and admits to using barrier protection inconsistently. His last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. The patient denies any fever, chills, abdominal pain, menorrhagia, or flank pain. He is afebrile and the vital signs are within normal limits. Speculum examination reveals vaginal erythema with a profuse, greenish-yellow, purulent, malodorous discharge. The vaginal pH is 5.5. Vaginal swab and urine samples are obtained for microscopy and culture, and results are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient based on his presentation?

A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in her right eye. She is struggling to open this eye because of the pain. Her left eye is asymptomatic. She wears contact lenses. She has bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. She works as a kindergarten teacher. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 85/min, and blood pressure 135/75 mm Hg. The examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 60-year-old woman comes to her physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past 2 months. She does not experience shortness of breath at rest. She also occasionally has a dry cough. She has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. She drinks a beer daily and occasionally more on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. She is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 66 kg (145 lbs); BMI is 19.7 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%, an FEV1 of 60% of predicted, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department for abdominal pain. The patient has been trying to get pregnant and was successful recently, but now he is experiencing abdominal pain, contractions, and a bloody vaginal discharge. According to his last appointment with his primary care provider, he is 10 weeks pregnant. The patient has a past medical history of constipation, anxiety, and substance abuse. He is not currently taking any medications. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a bloody vaginal discharge and an open cervix. The patient is initially extremely grateful for the care he is receiving and thanks the doctor and the nursing staff for saving his baby. Upon hearing the news that he is having a spontaneous abortion, the patient becomes angry and aggressive and states that his physician and the medical staff are incompetent, evil, and he is going to sue all of them. The patient is left to grieve but upon entering the room again you notice that the patient has new lacerations over his wrists and that some of the medical equipment in the room is broken. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with gross hematuria and acute, colicky flank pain. He denies any previous episodes of hematuria. He reports taking high doses of acetaminophen and aspirin over several weeks due to persistent upper back pain. The patient’s blood pressure and temperature are normal, but he is found to have proteinuria. Physical examination is negative for palpable flank masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:

A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath and a non-productive cough for 2 months. He has been unable to perform his daily activities. He has had malaise and bilateral ankle pain during this period. He noticed his symptoms after returning from a vacation to Arizona. He is a research assistant at the university geology laboratory. He is originally from Nigeria and visits his family there twice a year; his last trip was 3 months ago. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is no palpable cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. His left eye is notable for ciliary injection and photophobia. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 4-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because he has not stopped crying for the past 5 hours. His parents report that he has not eaten anything during this period and that they were unable to calm his down. He has not had any trauma. He was born at term via vaginal delivery and his delivery was uncomplicated. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a reddened and swollen 2nd toe of the left foot. A photograph of the left foot is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 81-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her son to be evaluated for memory issues. The patient’s son says she has difficulty remembering recent events and names. She says the patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over the last several years but became acutely worse just recently. Also, yesterday, the patient complained that she could not see out of her right eye, but today she can. When asked about these concerns, the patient seems to have no insight into the problem and reports feeling well. Her medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. She had a left basal ganglia hemorrhage 12 years ago and a right middle cerebral artery infarction 4 years ago. Current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, clopidogrel, metformin, sitagliptin, and valsartan. She lives with her son and can feed himself and change her clothes. There is no history of urinary or fecal incontinence. Her vitals include: blood pressure 137/82 mm Hg, pulse 78/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented. She is unable to perform simple arithmetic calculations and the mini-mental status exam is inconclusive. She can write her name and comprehend written instructions. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side. The tone is also slightly reduced on the right side with exaggerated reflexes. Her gait is hemiparetic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with back pain. The patient states that she has gradually worsening back pain that seems to have worsened after moving furniture the other day. She also states that while she walks, she feels numbness and weakness in her legs. The only time the patient states her back pain is improved is when she is riding her bike or pushing a cart at the grocery store. The patient has a past medical history of osteoporosis, dyslipidemia, and diabetes. She drinks 3 alcoholic drinks every day and has a 44 pack-year smoking history. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 157/108 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a non-tender spine with normal mobility in all 4 directions. Radiography of the spine and basic labs are ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in his right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. He has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus; he has had trouble adhering to his medication regimen. His blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye, but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a severe headache. He states it is 10/10 in intensity and states that it is associated with chewing. He describes it as a dull pain over the sides of his head. The patient is otherwise healthy and is not currently taking any medications. His temperature is 97.0°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 111/74 mmHg, pulse is 83/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for pain and tenderness over the mandibular and temporal region that is worsened when the patient opens and closes their mouth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman presents to the family medicine clinic for some small bumps on her left thigh. The lesions are non-pruritic and have been present for the last 3 weeks. She reports feeling fatigued and malaise for the past few months. The patient has no known medical problems and takes no medications. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and uses intravenous street drugs. Her heart rate is 82/min, the respiratory rate is 14/min, the temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), and the blood pressure is 126/80 mm Hg. Auscultation of the heart is without murmurs. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Three 2-3 mm, dome-shaped, hardened papules are noted on the left thigh. Central umbilication can be observed in each papule. There is a non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old man presents with severe pruritus and fatigue. He denies any similar symptoms in the past. No significant past medical history. Upon physical examination, scleral icterus is present, and significant hepatosplenomegaly is noted. Mild peripheral edema is also present. Laboratory findings are significant for elevated serum levels of bilirubin, aminotransferases, alkaline phosphatase (ALP), γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGTP), immunoglobulins, as well as cholesterol (especially HDL fraction). Antiviral antibodies are not present. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is also elevated. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are found. A liver biopsy is performed, and the histopathologic examination shows bile duct injury, cholestasis, and granuloma formation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Three days after undergoing an open cholecystectomy, an obese 57-year-old man has fever, chills, and a headache. He has right-sided chest pain that increases on inspiration and has had a productive cough for the last 12 hours. He had an episode of hypotension after the operation that resolved with intravenous fluid therapy. He underwent an abdominal hysterectomy 16 years ago for multiple fibroids of the uterus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Inspiratory crackles are heard at the right lung base. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a healing surgical incision below the right ribcage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency room by his friend for acute onset abdominal pain. He states that he was in a kickboxing class when he suddenly developed left-sided abdominal pain. His past medical history is significant for chlamydia. He is currently sexually active and does not use contraception. His menstrual periods occur regularly every 30 days. His last menstrual period ended 2 days ago. The patient’s temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 14/min with an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. On physical exam, there is left-sided, lower abdominal tenderness and guarding. Pelvic examination is notable for clear mucous in the vaginal introitus and tenderness of the left adnexa. A pelvic ultrasound with Doppler reveals a large amount of fluid in the rectouterine pouch. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale of 5 and is subsequently intubated. Physical exam is notable for subcutaneous emphysema in the clavicular area. Needle decompression and chest tube placement are performed, and the patient is stabilized after receiving 2 units of blood and 2 liters of fluid. Chest radiography demonstrates proper tube location and resolution of the pneumothorax. The patient is transferred to the trauma intensive care unit. On the unit, a repeat chest radiograph is notable for a recurrent pneumothorax with the chest tube in place. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 12 hours after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and substernal chest pain at rest; the pain is increased by inspiration. She has also had a nonproductive cough, fever, and malaise for the past 5 days. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins. Auscultation of the chest discloses bilateral basilar rales and muffled heart sounds. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia, diffuse ST segment elevation, low voltage QRS complexes, and fluctuating R wave amplitude. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man presents to an urgent care clinic with the complaint of epigastric discomfort and cramping pain for the past 2 hours. He states that he has experienced similar pain in the past. These episodes occur mostly after meals and often subside several hours after he finishes eating. Due to this reason he mostly avoids eating. He says he has lost a few pounds in the last couple of months. He is a smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. Past medical history is insignificant except for chronic knee pain, for which he takes over the counter painkillers. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 120/89 mm Hg. A physical abdominal exam is unremarkable, including examination of the abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old man comes to the physician requesting prenatal care. For the past 2 months, he has had increasing breast tenderness, nausea, 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain, and urinary frequency. He is not sure about the date of his last menstrual period. He has been trying to conceive with his wife since he stopped taking oral contraceptives 6 months ago; he was happy to tell him last week that he is pregnant. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild, nontender abdominal enlargement. The cervical os is closed. Urine β-hCG is negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on his right thigh. He initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past weeks. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule. When the skin lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inwards. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 41-year-old man presents with shortness of breath that is worse when he lies on his left side. About 10 days ago, he had an episode of unexplained loss of consciousness. Past medical history is negative and family history is irrelevant. Clinical examination shows a diastolic murmur, which is prominent when he lies on his left side. Jugular venous distention is present, and chest examination reveals fine crackles that do not clear with coughing. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary congestion, and 2-dimensional echocardiogram shows a mass in the left atrium attached to the atrial septum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her husband for severe abdominal pain for the past 1 hour. She is unable to give more information about the nature of her pain. Her husband says that she has peptic ulcer disease and is being treated with antacids without a good response. She adds that she vomited repeatedly  in the last couple of hours, her vomitus being brown/red in color. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. A physical exam reveals a tense abdomen with a board like rigidity and positive rebound tenderness. An erect abdominal x-ray is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presents with a 7 month history of insomnia. The patient admitted to having trouble sleeping from a young age but became more aware of how much this is affecting her health after attending a sleep conference earlier this year. She is worried that her health has suffered because of this, and she is also concerned that she will not be able to pay her bills if she were to get sick. She has no past medical or psychiatric condition and is not known to use any recreational drugs. The patient arrived for her appointment an hour early because she was afraid she might miss it. The patient is afebrile and her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals an irritable middle age woman who is tense and somewhat inattentive during the interview. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

An 18-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 2-day history of fever and a pruritic rash that started on her trunk and then progressed to her face and extremities. She has not received any childhood vaccinations because her parents believe that they are dangerous. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old woman with a past medical history significant only for facial acne presents with increased inguinal pruritis. Relevant social history includes participation in school wrestling. She has no significant family history. Other than the pruritic rash, a review of systems is negative. On physical examination, there is an erythematous, well-demarcated patch on her left thigh, over her pubic region, and throughout the perineum. The scrotum is spared. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-month history of difficulty concentrating at work. She is worried she may lose her job due to poor performance. She feels constantly tired but attributes her fatigue to waking up early most mornings and being unable to fall back asleep. Her husband has noticed that she has been speaking more slowly than usual and her appetite has decreased. She used to enjoy dance classes with her but has not been as interested in this recently. She is a veteran who returned from a deployment to Afghanistan 2 years ago. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has excessively dry skin. Her mother says that she has had dry, scaly skin since she was 6 months old. She says it is worse in winter and better in summer. There is no associated itching, redness, or discharge. Examination reveals generalized fine scales with coarse skin all over the body, except in the skin creases of the neck and in the cubital and popliteal fossae (see image). There are multiple papular elevations at the base of hair follicles and darkening of the palmar and plantar creases. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. She reports that she cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. She does not drink alcohol. Her medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man presents to the physician because of ongoing diarrhea for the past 1 month. He reports that diarrhea has been intermittently present for the past month. The stool is often loose and associated with blood and lower abdominal pain. He denies any recent travel history, and he works at a nursing home as a caretaker. He is not currently on any medications. Clinical examination shows mild tenderness in the suprapubic region, and there is no organomegaly. Findings on colonoscopy include patchy erythema and ulceration in the cecum, ascending, descending, and sigmoid colon. Mucosal biopsy shows colonic crypts with lymphocytic and neutrophilic infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old African-American man comes to the physician after an episode of hemoptysis. Over the past 8 months, he has had a nonproductive cough, fatigue, and a 9-kg (20-lb) weight loss. He drinks a glass of wine every night and does not smoke. He has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. He does not take any medications. He has never traveled out of the country. He works as an accountant. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.5-cm nodule with irregular borders at the apex of the left lung with no mediastinal or hilar enlargement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

question: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and weight loss. She is especially concerned about a recent episode in which she noticed a blurring of her vision and headache; she also notes that her “memory is not as good as it used to be,” which her husband confirms. Physical exam is notable only for pallor and general weakness. Laboratory studies reveal anemia as well as an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) reveals a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM; serum IgM concentration is 6.3 g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

options.A: IgM monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)

question: On routine screening, a 62-year-old woman is found to have positive fecal occult blood tests. She is asymptomatic, but her father died of large intestinal cancer. Abdominal and rectal exams are normal. A colonoscopy subsequently reveals a polyp in the descending colon but no other abnormalities. Excisional biopsy of the polyp shows 75% tubular architecture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old female college student presents to the emergency room at 4 AM in the morning with complaints of abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 hours. She was studying for her exams last night when she became hungry and ate some food from the afternoon after heating it for a while. She says that her symptoms began an hour after she ate the food. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. A physical examination is within normal limits except for signs of dehydration. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 79-year-old man presents to his physician complaining of a persistent non-productive cough and dyspnea after contracting a cold in the past month. He describes herself as being “generally healthy” before the cold started. Medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient takes hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His parents are both deceased. He does not smoke and only drinks alcohol occasionally. During a review of symptoms, he described a month-long trip to St. Louis, Missouri, to visit family. At the physician’s office, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. A focused chest exam reveals mild crepitus on the right side. A chest X-ray shows a cavitary lesion in the right lung which is confirmed on chest computed tomography (CT). A lung biopsy is performed to rule out cancer and reveals necrotic granulomatous inflammation with oval yeast in macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by police after she was found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as she suspects that her care team is spying on him. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol. When the patient is able to be examined, she is somnolent and non-responsive. Her temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. She does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate her extremities due to rigidity. Her mucous membranes are dry. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 41-year-old woman presents to the clinic with the complaints of abdominal discomfort and cramping for the past 4 months. She also mentions that she has grossly bloody stool and most of the time an urge to defecate. She has a history of bulimia with laxative abuse several years ago. She admits having lost about 5 lb in the past month. Her temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 105/86 mm Hg. On physical examination, a mild conjunctival pallor is evident, and the rectum is erythematous, indurated, and tender. Colonoscopy demonstrates continuous mucosal lesions throughout the rectum to the hepatic flexure of the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a change in her personality. The mother reports that over the past 7 months her son has become increasingly withdrawn; she has not answered any phone calls or visited her family and friends. She had always been a quiet boy, who needed some time on her own, but she used to meet with friends at least once a week. The patient says that she cannot leave the house because aliens are watching him and “stealing her thoughts”. She does not drink alcohol. She used to smoke marijuana occasionally but quit 1 year ago. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, it is impossible to follow the patient's sequence of thoughts. She is anxious and has a flat affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a sudden loss of consciousness. She has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. Her mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is somnolent and diaphoretic. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which her glucose concentration normalizes and her symptoms improve. She is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, she has another episode of decreased consciousness. Serum studies taken during the episode show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The episodes of lesions started at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. She has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The girl attends daycare. Her older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-month-old girl presents to a pediatrician for the evaluation of recurrent bacterial infections. She has a history of a variety of bacterial infections since birth. Physical examination reveals light-colored skin with silver-colored hair. The pediatrician suspects an immunodeficiency disorder and decides to order several tests. Study of the girl’s neutrophils reveals that they contain large cytoplasmic vacuoles. Genetic studies show a mutation in the LYST gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 65-year-old female presents to her primary care physician for stiffness in her arm. She states that she has been having trouble combing her hair and reaching objects that are high on the shelf. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type II, obesity, and hypertension. Her current medications include metformin, insulin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. The patient admits to leading a sedentary life in which she tends to stay home and watch television. She does not engage in any physical or strenuous activity. On physical exam the patient has decreased passive and active range of motion of her shoulder. Strength of the patient's upper extremity is 4/5. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 77-year-old woman comes to your office for a routine visit. She is doing well, and her only complaint is the recent appearance of several brown greasy appearing lesions on her forehead (figure A) that she can't seem to peel off. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for 2 months, which has started to interfere with her sleep. Her mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but her symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused her leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. Her gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an ESR of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. Prior to the onset of the symptoms, she attended a bachelor party where she lost several drinking games. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old boy is brought in to the office by his parents. They state that their daughter has recently been more irritable than usual, and he occasionally becomes pale and blue. His parents note that he was diagnosed with a heart murmur, but it was never treated. Physical examination reveals a small child in distress. He is laying on the examination table with his knees drawn to his chest. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh, systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the upper left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man presents with facial flushing, weakness, and chronic diarrhea for the past month. He denies any history of smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use. The patient was on a trip to Thailand 2 years ago with his family but denies any recent travel. His blood pressure is 120/88 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), and respiratory rate is 16/min. Laboratory findings are unremarkable, except for a potassium level of 3.3 mmol/L and serum calcium of 11 mg/dL. The attending physician suspects that this might be a case of a genetic mutation in the menin 1 gene on chromosome 11 and orders a genetic analysis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 22-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of swelling in his face, hands, and neck with occasional abdominal pain. The symptoms usually resolve in 2 to 3 days. He has had these swelling events his whole life; however, they have become more debilitating recently. Last week he had an event that restricted his ability to eat and swallow.  Past medical history is noncontributory. His father is alive and well with no significant medical history. His mother and his maternal aunt have a similar condition. Today, his physical exam is within normal limits. He brought a picture of his swollen hand as seen in the picture. The treating physician has a strong suspicion of an inherited disorder. C1-inhibitor levels are ordered and found to be extremely low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a right breast mass that he noticed 3 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. He does not have pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 5-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the right outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. Biopsy of the mass shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in her apartment. She has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after she has exercised. She has also had a 4.6-kg (10.1-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. Her achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 81-year-old woman patient recently moved into an assisted living facility and presents today with itchy blisters in her axilla. She attributes these to a poor diet. She also complains that the nurse practitioner at the facility started him on 4 new medications, in addition to her existing prescriptions. On physical examination, tense axillary bullae are noted that do not rupture with light, gloved touch. On direct immunofluorescence, linear C3 and IgG deposits are seen along the basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 69-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for trouble sleeping. The patient states that she recently retired from working the day shift at a cemetery. When the patient retired, her goal was to finally be able to go out with her husband; however, she finds that she is unable to stay awake past 6 pm in the evening. Her inability to stay awake has been straining her marriage as her husband is disappointed that they cannot do any activities in the evening together. The patient has tried drinking caffeine but finds that it does not help. The patient’s husband claims that the patient seems to sleep peacefully, and the patient states she feels rested when she awakes. The patient has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome which is managed with fiber supplements. The patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man presents to a psychiatrist for an initial consultation. He reports that for the past 3 years, he has experienced several periods of depressed mood. The episodes do not coincide with any specific life events and seem to resolve after 4-6 weeks. During these episodes, he experiences a depressed mood, sleep disturbances, and a poor appetite, but he at times is able to enjoy spending time with his children and wife but other times he is distressed and cannot enjoy time with them. Upon further questioning, he also reports experiencing occasional episodes of elevated mood over the past ten years. During these episodes, he is very productive at his work as a lawyer and requires less sleep than usual. His past medical history is notable for obesity, type I diabetes mellitus, and rheumatoid arthritis. He is on insulin and takes methotrexate. He smokes marijuana occasionally. His temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, he is quiet with a flattened affect, but is cooperative and answers questions thoroughly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

An obese 42-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of left knee pain for the past 3 months. He describes the pain as affecting the inside part of the knee as well as the front of his knee, below the kneecap. He denies any inciting injury or trauma to the knee but reports that the pain is worse when he is climbing up stairs or rising from a chair. Physical examination is significant for localized tenderness to palpation over the left anteromedial proximal tibia, 6 cm inferior to the joint line. There is no joint effusion noted. Valgus stress testing is negative for any pain or instability of the knee joint. Radiographs of the left knee are obtained and reveal only mild arthritis, without evidence of any fractures or bony lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 33-year-old man at 17-weeks gestation comes to the physician for evaluation of a painless mass in the right breast for the last 3 weeks that has not increased in size. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm rubbery, mobile mass that is nontender in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. A biopsy of the mass shows rounded contour with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 31-year-old male patient presents with significant swelling and redness of his fingers that is causing his significant pain. His right knee has also been stiff and slightly swollen for the past 6 weeks. He is overall fatigued and has difficulty moving around but has not sought medical attention until now. On physical examination, the distal interphalangeal joints are swollen, warm, and painful; his nails are pitted and cracked. There are also rough, erythematous skin patches seen over his elbows which have been present for the last few months. He reports that herer father has a similar condition. They both use hydrating creams and topical glucocorticoids with moderate benefit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. She was at work as a construction worker when her coworkers found him down at the work site. The patient recently underwent anesthesia for an appendectomy several months ago. She also has a past medical history of schizophrenia well controlled with haloperidol and is currently taking phenytoin for epilepsy. She is also currently taking propranolol for anxiety and hyperthyroidism. Her temperature is 106°F (41.1°C), blood pressure is 109/62 mmHg, pulse is 170/min, respirations are 23/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an altered woman with a Glasgow Coma Scale of 10. She has minimal muscle tone and is incoherent when answering questions. The patient is covered in sweat and dirt. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old man presents to his family physician with a 3-week history of swollen neck. The small, round, and painless swelling, which was detected 3 weeks ago in the middle of his neck, has now increased in size. The swelling is associated with sweaty palms and soles, insomnia, irritability, nervousness, and fatigue; however, the patient does not complain of fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, weight loss, vision problems, or body swelling. The patient’s medical history is negative for similar symptoms or a thyroid disorder. The vital signs are within normal limits. Local examination reveals a 3 x 3 cm round, non-tender, non-fluctuant, and non-pulsatile swelling in the anterior triangle of his neck. The patient carries a total white blood cell count of 10,200/mm3, including 70% neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes, and zero eosinophils.The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 20 mm/hr (normal, 0–29 mm/hr). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old female presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient was an unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. She has a past medical history of asthma, depression, and anxiety. She is not currently taking any medications. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The patient is breathing on her own and has strong distal pulses. Ultimately, the patient is discharged with follow up instructions after no significant fractures or injuries are found. The patient then presents 4 months later to her primary doctor with weakness. The patient's strength in her upper extremities is 1/5. She has reduced sensation in her upper extremities as well. The patient's lower extremities reveal 5/5 strength with intact sensation. A chest radiograph and basic labs are ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old female presents with a recent onset of upsetting dreams, anxiety, and disturbing flashbacks. The patient reports that she returned from active duty in Iraq 3 months ago and was adjusting to life back at home until about 7 weeks ago when she began having intense fear of loud noises and seeing sudden flashbacks to bombing attacks she endured during her time in Iraq. She had to take a leave from her army instructor duties as she was not able to handle the familiar settings of practice shooting ranges and sudden loud explosions during battalion training. After refusing to leave her house, she was finally persuaded by her husband to visit your clinic. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 46-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where she was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, she is unconscious. Her respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg, and pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is negative. An electrocardiogram shows absent p-waves. After 5 minutes, her pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents to the physician with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. He was diagnosed with hypertension in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). He has had a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months. He complains of pain in the long bones of his arms and legs for the past 3 months. He is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. His skin is moist and warm. His weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. His pulse is 116/min, the blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is present. His upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack. The laboratory test results reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines. Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7 -day-old newborn girl presents to the emergency department with a history of fever, irritability, and generalized erythema. During the first 2 days of clinical manifestations, the parents of the child tried to control the symptoms using acetaminophen; however, the newborn continued to be ill, and blisters were noticeable around the buttocks, hands, and feet. During the physical examination, the vital signs include body temperature 39.0°C (102.3°F), heart rate 130/min, and respiratory rate 45/min. Ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity, while the skin presents with diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 60-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of severe vulvar itching that has been gradually worsening for the past year. He mentions that he has tried over-the-counter lubricants, but lubricants do not seem to provide substantial relief. His medical history is remarkable for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Menopause occurred at 52 years of age. He has been sexually active with his wife until recently and reports severe pain during vaginal intercourse. The physical examination reveals dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions in the vulvar area with atrophy of the labia minora. The clitoris appears retracted. The perianal skin appears pale and wrinkled. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.C: Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva

question: A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department with his girlfriend 2 hours after an episode of loss of consciousness. He was seated and was being tattooed on his right upper flank when he became diaphoretic, pale, and passed out. According to his boyfriend, the patient slipped to the floor and his arms and legs moved in a jerky fashion for a few seconds. He regained consciousness within half a minute and was alert and fully oriented immediately. He has no history of serious illness. He works as an event manager and has had more stress than usual due to a recent concert tour. He appears well. His temperature is 37°C (98.4°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/72 mm Hg. His cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An ECG shows an incomplete right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 74-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to his primary care doctor by his son who is concerned about the patient's ability to manage his activities of daily living. He has been living alone since his wife passed away 2 years ago. He has remained an active member of his retirement community's wine club; however, he stopped attending the meetings 3 weeks ago. He is generally able to his maintain his house, but his house appears more disorganized over the past 2 weeks. He generally drives short distances but avoids driving long distances as he occasionally gets lost when navigating new areas. He feels like his balance is getting worse, but he has not fallen. He has noticed increased urinary urgency over the past 8 months and has had 2 episodes of incontinence. Despite these changes, he reports feeling well. He drinks 4-6 glasses of wine per day. He was started on multiple medications for worsening anxiety by his psychiatrist 1 month ago. His BMI is 31 kg/m^2. His temperature is 99.8°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 115/65 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 17/min. On examination, he is oriented to person and time but not place or situation. He does not seem to recognize his doctor despite knowing him for many years. He becomes somnolent intermittently throughout the interview. He can recall 0/3 words after 5 minutes. He has a low-frequency tremor in his right arm that increases in severity with deliberate movement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 19-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her mother because she is worried about her strange behavior. Over the past 3 years, she has been dressing all in black and wears a long black coat, even in the summer. The mother reports that her son has always had difficulties fitting in. She does not have any friends and spends most of her time in her room playing online games. She is anxious at college because she is uncomfortable around other people, and her academic performance is poor. Rather than doing her coursework, she spends most of her time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons. She says that she has never seen any demons, but sometimes there are signs of their presence. For example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon”. Mental status examination shows laborious speech. The patient avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 79-year-old woman presents to the office due to shortness of breath with moderate exertion and a slightly productive cough. She has a medical history of 25 years of heavy smoking. Her vitals include: heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 27/min, and blood pressure 120/90 mm Hg. The physical exam shows increased resonance to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and crackles at the lung base. Chest radiography shows signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. Spirometry shows a forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) of 48%, a forced vital capacity (FVC) of 85%, and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 56%. According to these results, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of multiple episodes of nausea and vomiting that last about 2 hours. During this period, he has had 6–8 episodes of bilious vomiting and abdominal pain. The vomiting was preceded by fatigue. The boy feels well between these episodes. He has missed several days of school and has been hospitalized 2 times during the past 6 months for dehydration due to similar episodes of vomiting and nausea. The patient has lived with his mother since his parents divorced 8 months ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 30th percentile for weight. He appears emaciated. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.8°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 82/52 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows a soft abdomen with mild diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old male high school student is brought to the physician by his parents for his repeated behavioral problems at home and school during the past 10 months. His teachers describe his behavior as uncooperative and disruptive as he persistently refuses to answer questions, insults his teachers, and annoys his classmates on a daily basis. At home, his parents try to address his frequent violations of curfew, but attempts at discussing the issue often result in their daughter losing his temper and screaming at his parents. His grades have deteriorated over the past year. He has no history of psychiatric illness. On questioning, the patient refuses to answer and frequently disrupts the physician’s conversation with the parents. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 59-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician, accompanied by her husband, who requests treatment for her “chronic pessimism.” The patient admits to feeling tired and “down” most of the time for the past several years but insists that it is “just part of getting old.” Her husband believes that she has become more self-critical and less confident than she used to be. Neither the patient nor her husband can identify any stressors or triggering events. She has continued to work as a librarian at a nearby college during this time and spends time with friends on the weekends. She sleeps 7 hours per night and eats 3 meals per day. She denies suicidal ideation or periods of elevated mood, excessive irritability, or increased energy. Physical exam reveals a well-dressed, well-groomed woman without apparent abnormality. Basic neurocognitive testing and labs (CBC, BMP, TSH, cortisol, testosterone, and urine toxicology) are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

ِA 62-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of colicky pain in the lower abdomen and abdominal distension for the past 12 hours. She has chronic constipation for which she takes lactulose and senna laxatives. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg and pulse is 85/min. On physical examination, there is diffuse abdominal distension and tenderness, and bowel sounds are faint. Her plain abdominal radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 31-year-old female presents with a 2-day history of watery diarrhea that began 8 days after her arrival from Africa. None of the other members of her family became ill. She reports symptoms of malaise, anorexia, and abdominal cramps followed by watery diarrhea. She denies tenesmus, urgency, and bloody diarrhea. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 90/68 mm Hg. A physical examination is performed and is within normal limits. Intravenous fluids are started, and a stool sample is sent to the lab, which comes out to be negative for any ova/parasites, blood cells, or pus cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a progressive rash for 2 days. The rash started behind the ears and now involves the trunk and extremities. Over the past 4 days, she has had mild sore throat, red, itchy eyes, and headache. She was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of tonsillitis and occasional asthma attacks. Two weeks ago, she was treated for tonsillitis that resolved with penicillin therapy. She immigrated with her family from Brazil 3 weeks ago. Her immunization status is unknown. The patient appears weak and lethargic. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a non-confluent, pink maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. Her palms and soles show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive headache, blurry vision, and nausea for 1 day. Four days ago, he was diagnosed with a right middle ear infection. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), and blood pressure is 148/95 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. The corneal reflex in the right eye is absent. Sensation to touch is reduced on the upper right side of the face. Serum studies show increased concentrations of fibrin degradation products. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old African American woman presents to the emergency department with central chest pressure. Her symptoms started 1 day before. The pain was initially intermittent in nature but has become constant and radiates to her jaw and left shoulder. She also complains of some difficulty breathing. The patient was diagnosed with essential hypertension 1 year ago, but she is not taking any medications for it. The patient denies smoking, alcohol, or drug use. Family history is unremarkable. Her blood pressure is 230/130 mm Hg in both arms, the temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), and the pulse is 90/min. ECG shows diffuse T wave inversion and ST depression in lateral leads. Laboratory testing is significant for elevated troponin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old male college student comes to the physician for a sudden loss of visual acuity of his right eye. He noticed that he was unable to read the time on the alarm clock when he woke up in the morning. When he closes his right eye, he is able to see sharply. When he closes his left eye, he has blurry double vision. He does not recall trauma to his eye but has been working long nights on his honors thesis. He has a history of occasional shoulder luxation. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall, and weighs 62 kg (136 lbs); his BMI is 19.1 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, slender and long fingers are noted. He has several flat, demarcated brownish nevi on his left cheek. Ocular examination shows upward temporal subluxation of his right lens. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of several episodes of dizziness during the last month. The episodes last between 30–40 seconds and during the episodes he feels as though he is spinning. Episodes usually occur immediately after lying down or suddenly sitting up from a reclined position. They also sometimes happen when he suddenly turns his head to look at something. He has no nausea. Last month, he had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Otoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic for the third time in the past 3 weeks asking for an MRI of her lower back. She had initially gone to the gym as advised by her husband and had started doing some back exercises. The next day, she developed soreness in her lower back and spent the whole day online trying to figure out what was wrong with him. She has been to the emergency department a few times and subsequently has been redirected to the clinic where each time she was thoroughly examined and investigated for all the possible causes. The patient still exhibits worry and would like to get an MRI to make sure everything is ‘okay.’ Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Shortly after undergoing a bipolar prosthesis for a displaced femoral neck fracture of the left hip acquired after a fall the day before, an 80-year-old man suddenly develops dyspnea. The surgery under general anesthesia with sevoflurane was uneventful, lasting 98 minutes, during which the patient maintained oxygen saturation readings of 96–100% on 8 L of oxygen. He has a history of hypertension, osteoporosis, and osteoarthritis of his right knee. His medications include ramipril, naproxen, ranitidine, and a multivitamin. He appears cyanotic, drowsy, and is oriented only to person. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 135/minute, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. There are several scattered petechiae on the anterior chest wall.
