Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 10.5 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 9,000/mm3, a platelet count of 145,000/mm3, and a creatine kinase of 190 U/L. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old previously healthy female presents to your office with complaints of facial pressure and rhinorrhea for the past 3 weeks. The patient reports that several weeks prior, she had a “common cold” which resolved. However, she has since developed worsening facial pressure, especially over her cheeks and forehead. She reports over 1 week of green tinged rhinorrhea. Her temperature is 100.1 deg F (37.8 deg C), blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 15/min. Nasal exam reveals edematous turbinates and purulent discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of persistent cough productive of white phlegm. She coughs consistently throughout the day, and she has not noticed any particular triggers that make it worse. She has also recently experienced some shortness of breath with exertion. She has not had any weight loss, fever, or chills. She had similar symptoms last year, which lasted about 6 months. She has hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine. She has worked in construction for the past 10 years. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an end-expiratory wheeze throughout all lung zones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of abdominal distention and twitching of his feet, which his mother noticed a week ago. The patient has also had a low-grade fever for 5 days. He has not had a bowel movement in 3 days. He was born at term and has been healthy since. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Examination shows an irregular palpable mass that crosses the midline of the abdomen. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are erratic movements of the eyes. A 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to sudden chest pain and difficulty breathing for the past 3 hours. The pain is felt in the retrosternal area and radiates up to her left shoulder and arm; it worsens on inspiration, and is relieved when she is leaning forward. Her heart rate is 61/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), and blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Pericardial friction rub is heard on auscultation. Laboratory results show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels. An ECG is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 47-year-old woman presents to her ophthalmologist for abnormal vision. The patient was discharged from the hospital 2 weeks ago after a motor vehicle accident where she was given 1L of blood. She also underwent several surgical procedures including enucleation of the right globe and exploratory abdominal laparotomy to stop internal bleeding. Currently, she states that she has noticed decreased vision in her left eye. The patient has a past medical history of poorly controlled diabetes, asthma, and atopic dermatitis. Her temperature is 98.9°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 167/108 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is notable for 20/200 vision in the patient's left eye, which is worse than usual. The patient's left eye appears red and irritated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 49-year-old man otherwise healthy presents to the outpatient department with swelling of the neck. Family history is negative for any thyroid disorders. Physical examination shows a nontender thyroid gland with a nodule on the right side. The thyroid gland is mobile on deglutition. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Fine needle aspiration and cytology show empty appearing nuclei with central clearing, nuclear grooves and branching structures interspersed with calcific bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 43-year-old man presents to a new primary care physician complaining of anxiety. He has been worrying non-stop recently about the possibility that his wife will lose his job as a teacher. His wife, who is present, assures the physician that his job is entirely secure and states that he has "fretted" for their entire marriage, though the exact topic causing his anxiety varies over time. He also worries excessively about everyday tasks, such as whether he will catch the train on time and whether their house in Southern California is sufficiently earthquake-proof. He has no way to overcome these worries. He endorses other symptoms including poor sleep (associated with racing thoughts about his various worries), fatigue, and impaired concentration at work, all of which have been present for at least the past year. His vital signs are within normal limits and there are no abnormalities on physical exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old male presents to your office for her annual physical exam. She has no complaints at this time and her chronic hypertension is well controlled. You notice a .5cm papule on the patient's eyelid that has a pink pearly appearance, rolled borders, and overlying telangiectasias. On further questioning, you find out the patient was a door-to-door salesman and spent a lot of time outdoors, and she did not wear sunscreen. She has fair skin and blonde hair. The patient states that she first noticed the lesion about 6 months prior, and it has grown slightly since then. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An obese 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department of a rural hospital due to chest pain for the last 12 hours. The pain is substernal, crushing in nature, radiating into his neck, and accompanied by profuse sweating. His history is significant for hypertension, and he admits poor compliance with his medications. An ECG done at the clinic confirmed the presence of STEMI, and the patient was given aspirin. The ambulance was in an accident on the way to the hospital and by the time the patient reached the angiography suite, the cardiologist decided intervention should be delayed due to the late presentation. Also, the patient’s pain has improved. The patient is admitted and is stable for 3 nights with no dyspnea or edema. His blood pressure is kept under control while in the hospital. On the fourth night, the patient becomes quite agitated and soon thereafter he is unresponsive. His pulse cannot be palpated. He has an elevated JVP and upon auscultation, heart sounds are distant. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic for hair loss. He was in his usual state of health until earlier this month when he started noticing more and more hair on his pillow in the morning. The problem has only been getting worse since then; she's even started pulling out clumps of hair when he shampoos in the morning. He has no other symptoms, and his past medical history is unremarkable. The physical exam is notable for smooth, circular, non-scarring, hairless patches across his scalp. A firm tug on a bundle of hair causes almost all of the hair to be removed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 75-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 6-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal pain. She drinks 2 oz of alcohol on the weekends and does not smoke. She is retired but previously worked in a factory that produces plastic pipes. Abdominal examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness; the liver edge is palpable 2 cm below the ribs. A liver biopsy specimen shows pleomorphic spindle cells that express PECAM-1 on their surface. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of high-grade fever and generalized fatigue for 5 days. Two days ago, she developed a rash on her trunk. She returned from a family hiking trip to Montana 1 week ago. Her immunization records are unavailable. Her temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination shows injection of the conjunctivae bilaterally. The tongue and pharynx are erythematous. Tender cervical lymphadenopathy is present on the left. There is a macular rash over the trunk and extremities. Bilateral knee joints are swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 78-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past year. She has difficulties understanding conversations in crowded places and when more than one person talks at the same time. She has no dizziness, ear discharge, ringing noise, or ear pain. She has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows pearly gray, translucent tympanic membranes with a normal light reflex. A vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Once the patient no longer hears a tone, the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear and the patient reports to hear the tone again. The same test is repeated on the right side with similar results. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old Asian man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. On questioning, he has had occasional night sweats during the past 2 months. He has not had fevers or weight loss. Seven months ago, he had an acute myocardial infarction and was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 37 years. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, ramipril, metoprolol, and esomeprazole. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (207 lbs); BMI is 29.7 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows an S4. There is a nontender skin lesion near the right large toenail. A photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department for pain in multiple joints. He states that he has had symmetric joint pain that started yesterday and has been worsening. It is affecting his wrists, elbows, and shoulders. He also endorses a subjective fever and some fatigue but denies any other symptoms. The patient works as a schoolteacher and is generally healthy. He is currently sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms occasionally. His temperature is 100°F (37.8°C), blood pressure is 122/85 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. His laboratory values are within normal limits. Physical exam is notable for joint stiffness and pain in particular of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP), proximal interphalangeal (PIP), and the wrist. The patient is discharged with ibuprofen. Four weeks later, the patient follows up at his primary doctor and notes that his symptoms have improved and he is no longer taking any medications for symptom control. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of nervousness and difficulty sleeping over the past 2 weeks. Three months ago, she started a new team project at her job. She says that she has trouble falling asleep at night because she thinks about the project. She insists on checking the work of her teammates and spends several hours each week making elaborate lists and schedules. She refuses to let others take on more tasks because she thinks that only she can complete them satisfactorily. The project deadline has already been postponed once. She says, “My teammates never understand how important it is to do things the right way.” Ever since high school, she has used the majority of her time to plan out assignments and does not have time to regularly participate in social activities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.E:
Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depressed mood
"

question: A 15-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless swelling under the left lower jaw for 5 months. His 18-year-old sister has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia that has been in remission for 11 years. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) Physical examination shows a 3 × 2 cm swelling on the left side, 4 cm below the base of the mandible and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The swelling is soft and fluctuant. It does not move with swallowing, and forced exhalation against a closed glottis does not increase the size of the swelling. Ultrasound shows a round mass with uniform low echogenicity and no internal septations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 28-year-old female is found to have 93% HbA, 2% HbF, and 5% HbA2 on hemoglobin electrophoresis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.B: Alpha thalassemia major with Hb Bart's

question: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She feels well. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2766 g (6 lb 2 oz). She now weighs 14 kg (31 lbs). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is at 60th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the upper left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. There is a grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur along the lower left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old woman is brought to a psychiatrist by her mother. The patient’s mother has become increasingly concerned about him since her high school graduation. Although she says that she had been an excellent student in high school, her grades have begun slipping in her second year in college, and she no longer socializes with friends. When she asked him why she no longer talks to her friends, she states that she told her, “They already know where I am. They can see me. They watch me from my bedroom window, so they already know what I’m doing. We don’t need to talk.” She found this to be bizarre, as nearly all of her friends live hours away. The patient states that she feels fine and doesn’t understand why everyone thinks she is crazy. The psychiatrist notices reduced spontaneous movements while the patient is speaking and that she speaks in a monotone with a voice that is soft in volume. She also appears suspicious and defensive, asking the psychiatrist “why are you asking me that?” after each evaluative question. Her mood is generally flat with little reactivity or engagement during the course of her interview, but she denies any symptoms of depression or psychosis. No significant past medical history. Family history is not available as she was adopted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 14-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician after his parents noticed his being increasingly irritable with frequent vomiting for the past 2 weeks. Parents deny any history of fever. They recently immigrated to the country and, unfortunately, the mother did not receive prenatal care during pregnancy due to a lack of health insurance. Physical examination is unremarkable except for a head circumference over 2 standard deviations larger than the mean for his age, and delay in meeting motor developmental milestones. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of his brain shows an enlargement of the posterior fossa, cystic dilation of the 4th ventricle, and hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis (see image). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 22-year-old man presents with an episodic history of swelling of the face, hands, and neck and a single episode of difficulty swallowing. He also has a history of frequent, severe abdominal pain. At the time of his visit, his blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg, heart rate is 82/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination is unremarkable except for a swollen right hand as shown in the image below. Imaging studies are normal and do not reveal any cause of his pain. His C1 inhibitor level is less than 6% of the reference value. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A young Mediterranean teen brings his 4-year-old little brother to the Emergency Room because of a high temperature. Their parents are on their way to the hospital, but, in the meantime, he provides some of the history. He explains that he has been running a fever and limping for the past week. This morning, he had trouble awakening him, and he noticed some swelling and redness around his right ankle. In terms of his past medical history, he knows he has something wrong with his blood. He had to receive extra vaccinations as an infant, and he takes an antibiotic everyday. On exam in the ED, his temperature is 102.4 deg F (39.1 deg C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 123/min, and respirations are 22/min. He is lethargic, and his exam is noteworthy for erythema and edema in an area surrounding his distal shin. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has had mild pain in her left groin for 2 weeks. She was admitted to the hospital 1 month ago for myocardial infarction. Cardiac catheterization and angiography showed occlusion of the left anterior descending artery and she underwent placement of 2 stents. She has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. There is no family history of serious illness. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, rosuvastatin, and enalapril. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in), tender, pulsatile mass in the left thigh, below the inguinal ligament. There is mild erythema of the overlying skin. A loud murmur is heard on auscultation of the mass. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is no edema in the lower limbs. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old farmer from Jamaica presents to her physician with a wart-like lesion on her left foot. She is a plantain farmer and often farms barefoot because of the pleasant climate. Physical examination reveals warty, cutaneous nodules that resemble the florets of cauliflower. On a KOH preparation, irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae are noted. Culture on Sabouraud agar reveals sclerotic bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A mother brings his 17-year-old daughter to your office because of a recent onset dull unilateral pelvic pain that started last week. In addition, the daughter also complains of constipation for which he increased his fiber intake, but the dietary changes are not helping her. He began menstruating at the age of 13, and his menstrual cycles are regular (about 28 days). On physical examination, the patient has a large, non-tender, mobile adnexal mass in the left lower quadrant. The pelvic examination is normal except for the presence of the adnexal mass. The patient is advised to have an outpatient ultrasound, and then return to the clinic next week. After 2 weeks, you learned that the patient visited the emergency department for a sudden onset of abdominal pain that required observation after an abdominal ultrasound was performed. The ultrasound showed a large simple cystic mass with increased internal echoes, having a diameter of 10 cm and hyperechogenic vascular walls on the left ovary with a small intraperitoneal collection in the pouch of Douglas. What was the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 43-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of “spotting.” He states that over the past 5 months he has had intermenstrual bleeding. Additionally, his menses last more than a week with the first 4 days consisting of heavy bleeding. He denies abdominal pain but reports feeling an increasing “pressure-like" discomfort. He denies dysuria, dyspareunia, or dyschezia. Prior to 5 months ago, his menstrual periods were only 4 days long and consisted of moderate bleeding. His periods normally occur every 28 days. He is frustrated because he feels like he needs to wear a pad all the time. The patient delivered 3 healthy children vaginally without complications, followed by a tubal ligation. His last menstrual period was 1 week ago. He is sexually active with his wife and denies a history of sexually transmitted diseases. He has never had an abnormal pap smear. His last pap smear and test for human papillomavirus was 4 years ago. The patient has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. On physical examination, the thyroid is normal in size without masses or tenderness. Pelvic examination reveals a firm, mobile, enlarged, irregularly-shaped uterus without adnexal tenderness. Speculum exam is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old college student is brought to her primary care physician by her parents over the New Years holiday because they are concerned about her behavior since right after high school graduation in May the spring before. Prior to this year, she was generally an outgoing and social young man, who now reportedly has been spending the majority of her time alone in her dorm room and room at home, where her mother and father have overheard him talking to other people when she has no guests. When asked if anything was bothering him at school, she reports that at night the voice of the school's mascot encourages him to save the school from the large oak grove that will soon takeover the student union building by setting the trees on fire for all to see. On exam, her appears to be otherwise healthy and her urine toxicology screen is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a slowly enlarging painless ulcer on her lower lip. One year ago she had a painful rash near her upper lip that resolved completely with acyclovir therapy. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. She has worked in construction for the past 33 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows a 0.5 x 0.5 cm nontender ulcer with everted edges on the midline of her lower lip. The erythematous ulcer bleeds upon palpation. She has numerous moles of varying sizes all over her body. There are no palpable cervical lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of pain in the left cheek. The pain occurs every few hours, lasts 30–60 seconds, and is aggravated by chewing and brushing. He has a history of pain with a vesicular rash in the right axillary area one year ago. He had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old is brought into the emergency room after a bicycle vs motored vehicle accident. She was unconscious after hitting the side of her head on the road, but recovered consciousness after a few minutes. She started to ride her bicycle again, but then developed a severe headache with nausea and vomiting, at which time she called EMS. While in the hospital, the patient is confused and cannot provide a history. She quickly loses consciousness and her CT scan is displayed in Figure 1. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 53-year-old woman presents to the office complaining of persistent abdominal pain. She states that she has gained 4.5 kg (10.0 lb) because the pain is only relieved by eating. The patient also admits that she has had numerous loose, foul-smelling stools over the last few weeks with associated nausea. She has taken some over the counter antacids without relief or change in symptoms. Her blood pressure is 132/76 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and heart rate is 75/min. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness to palpation of the upper abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old boy is seen by his pediatrician for developmental delay. One year prior, the patient was able to ride a tricycle, stack 3 blocks, and speak in short sentences. Now, he is unable to feed herself and has recently started to point to objects he wants rather than asking. Physical exam reveals a well nourished child sitting in a stroller wringing his hands. Vital signs are normal. The patient's mother reports that his 7-year-old son is doing well, and that they have no family history of mental retardation or other cognitive disorders. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. He has had no prenatal care. His three children were delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section. The patient appears in acute distress. His pulse is 98/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations. One hour following vaginal delivery, the placenta is not delivered. Manual separation of the placenta leads to profuse vaginal bleeding. A firm, nontender uterine fundus is palpated at the level of the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain. Over the past 9 months, he has had multiple similar episodes of abdominal pain, each lasting for 4–5 days. Menarche has not yet occurred. Examination shows suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Pubic hair and breast development are Tanner stage 4. Pelvic examination shows bulging, bluish tissue 1 cm inside the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 31-year-old gravida 2 para 2 man presents to his primary care physician for follow up. Two weeks ago, he gave birth via vaginal delivery to a 9.5 lb (4.3 kg) male infant. The delivery was complicated by a vaginal laceration that required extensive suturing once the infant was delivered. Immediately after delivery of the placenta he experienced intense shaking and chills that resolved within 1 hour. He has felt well since the delivery but admits to 6 days of malodorous smelling vaginal discharge that is tan in color. He has a history of vaginal candidiasis and is worried that it may be recurring. His temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/73 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, and BMI is 33 kg/m^2. Speculum exam reveals a 1.5 cm dark red, velvety lesion on the posterior vaginal wall with a tan discharge. The pH of the discharge is 6.4. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man comes to the physician with his mother because of a 1-week history of feeling unusually energetic. The mother describes his state as “hyper” and reports that he often paces around his room. During this period, the patient has not slept. He had similar episodes 2 months and 5 months ago. The mother also states that, for the past 8 months, the patient has believed he is a famous singer and is going on a world tour next year. The patient does not have a partner and has only a few friends. He was working as a dental technician until 6 months ago, when he started to hear voices telling his to quit. He has not held a job since then. He does not use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, his speech is pressured, but he suddenly stops talking in the middle of sentences and does not finish them. He occasionally directs his attention to empty corners in the room, as if he were listening to someone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of worsening pain in her left buttock. The pain is described as a deep, dull ache that is worse at night. She does not report any recent trauma. She has hyperlipidemia. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks one beer every night. She does not use illicit drugs. Her only medication is simvastatin. Physical examination shows tenderness over the left gluteal region. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a 4-cm, poorly defined, osteolytic lesion in the left ilium with a moth-eaten pattern of bone destruction, multiple well-defined sclerotic lesions, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. The remainder of the physical examination, including rectal examination, shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray and abdominal ultrasonography show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old girl is brought in to your clinic by her mother, who is complaining of her son’s “dry scalp and hair loss.” She reports a scaling spot on her scalp developed around 2 months ago, soon after moving to a new school, which then became a larger bald spot. She denies that anyone in the household is exhibiting similar symptoms, but does recall a note that came home from school warning of a lice outbreak. Thus far, she has only tried daily baths with little improvement. The patient denies pain or itchiness, but the mother reports she does notice him scratching her scalp. The mother also reports that since her son has started at the new school, she has noticed an increase in her tics including excessive blinking and clearing of her throat. The patient's medical history is significant for asthma, allergic rhinitis, and attention deficient hyperactivity disorder. Her current medications include fluticasone, salmeterol, loratadine, and methylphenidate. Family history includes obsessive compulsive disorder in her older sister. The mother also reports her father had a debilitating skin and joint disorder. On examination, you note swollen lymph glands at the back of the patient's ears and neck, and there are residual black dots within a patch of alopecia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old girl is brought in to her pediatrician's office by her step-mother for uncontrollable behavior. She reports she has an extensive history of detention for outbursts in class. She recently got expelled from school for fist fighting. At home, she punches her younger brother when he’s angry. The family had to give their cat away to a neighbor because the patient tried to set it on fire. The patient’s medical history is significant for bed-wetting until she was 11. Her father has adult attention deficit disorder. The patient states that she thinks school is a “joke.” She denies having close friends and says “the kids in my town are stupid anyway.” She calmly describes how she would like to burn down all their houses. She admits to trying alcohol and cocaine but denies any other illicit drugs. Which of the following is the patient’s most likely diagnosis?

A 48-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because she has become increasingly restless and anxious. Her husband says that she has seemed sad and irritable for the past 4 months. She lost her job as a store clerk because she often lied to avoid work, and spent most of her days on the phone placing bets on football games. She avoids all family-related events because she has borrowed money from most of her relatives. She is hopeful that her symptoms will improve once she is able to win some of her money back. She previously smoked 8–10 cigarettes daily but quit 1 month ago. She drinks beer on the weekends. On examination, she is uncooperative and dismissive. She is mildly tremulous. Neurologic examination is normal. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 4-month history of recurrent crusty lesions on the dorsal surface of her hands. When she scrapes off the crusts, they reappear after a few days. The lesions are mildly pruritic and occasionally burn. She works as a landscaper. A photograph of her right hand is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a chief complaint of diarrhea. The patient states that her symptoms have worsened recently. She works as a farmer and is dressed in tattered and old denim. She lives alone, and this is the first time she has come to town in years. The patient’s diet is mostly dairy products and some meat products. She denies any systemic symptoms and states that diarrhea tends to occur right after a meal. She also claims that at times she struggles to fall asleep, and sometimes she feels she lacks energy. The patient is instructed to avoid consuming dairy products for a week and to return with a report of her symptoms. As you set up the return appointment with this patient you notice that she is rather emotionless. She also states that she lacks anybody that she can list as an emergency contact so she leaves that section of her medical forms blank. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 77-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a change in her mental status. The patient’s daughter states that she can cook and clean up after himself and only needs help paying bills. Yesterday the patient seemed fine; however, this morning she noticed that she struggled to perform simple tasks and was forgetful while cooking, leaving the stove on. They recently returned from a trip to Mexico and admit to drinking unfiltered water and eating local cuisines while abroad. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes. Her temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 187/118 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old G2P1 man at 29 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician after noticing red spots on his undergarments over the past week. His vaginal bleeding has not been painful; however, he is concerned that it has persisted. His previous child was born by cesarean section and he is currently taking folate and a multivitamin. He endorses feeling fetal movements. His temperature is 98.9°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 120/84 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a gravid uterus and non-tender abdomen. Speculum exam reveals a closed cervical os and a small amount of blood. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old man comes to the gynecologist complaining of vaginal swelling and discomfort. He states that over the past 2 weeks he has noticed swelling of his right labia. The swelling continued to grow in size and now causes his discomfort when walking. He denies abnormal discharge or bleeding from the swelling or from the vulva. He normally shaves the area, but with the recent pain, he has been unable to. He denies any history of known trauma. The patient is relatively healthy and takes only a multivitamin. He never received the vaccine for human papillomavirus (HPV). On physical exam, there is a fluctuant, swelling of the right labia, most prominently at the posterior vestibule. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman presented to the hospital with right upper quadrant abdominal pain. She has a history of hepatitis B. She underwent a CT of her abdomen which revealed a large mass (11.3 cm x 7.2 cm in diameter) with a metastatic retroperitoneal lymph node. She was diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma and initially received radiotherapy while on the transplant list to prevent local expansion of her malignancy. 3 months after radiotherapy, the patient experienced hematemesis and melena. She was admitted to the emergency department for evaluation. Her vitals were: blood pressure 84/56 mmHg, heart rate 92/min, and respiratory rate 20/min. Laboratory evaluation revealed severe anemia with a hemoglobin level of 5.7 g/dL, INR 1.8 and platelets of 68,000 cells/mm3. She received a blood transfusion. An endoscopic examination demonstrated diffuse edematous hyperemic mucosa and multiple hemorrhagic patches with active oozing in the antrum. What is the most likely diagnosis for the lesions seen in endoscopy?

A 26-year-old woman presents to the office complaining of persistent back pain for the past 3 months. You saw the patient previously and prescribed NSAIDs and rest, but she has not improved. The patient states that her maternal grandfather had ‘back problems her whole life’, and she worries that she might have the same issues. An X-ray is performed and shows squaring of the vertebrae with longitudinal fibrous bands. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He has no history of serious illness. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2/6 continuous, low-pitched murmur over the left upper sternal border that radiates towards the neck. The murmur disappears when he flexes his neck. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He is worried about gaining weight. He frequents buffet restaurants but feels guilty soon after. He has a history of burning his extremities with cigarettes. His last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. He attends high school and plays field hockey on the school team. He is at the 25th percentile for height, 12th percentile for weight, and 17th percentile for BMI. Examination shows bilateral parotid gland enlargement. Oropharyngeal examination shows perimolysis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old man comes to the physician with complaints of fever, headache, and rash, which have gradually worsened over the past 6 days. The patient informs the physician that the rash appeared after 2 days of fever. The rash started at the wrists and ankles and then gradually spread to the trunk, palms, and soles. On examination, the physician notes a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below. Vital signs show a temperature of 39.4°C (103.0°F), a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg, and a pulse rate of 86/min. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old female presents to her cardiologist to discuss increasing episodes of dyspnea after climbing stairs. She also now needs three pillows at night to sleep. Physical examination reveals an early diastolic murmur best appreciated at the left sternal border with bounding peripheral pulses. The cardiologist is very concerned and immediately refers the patient for a surgical workup. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with subacute worsening of chronic chest pain and shortness of breath with exertion. The patient is generally healthy, lifts weights regularly, and does not smoke. Her temperature is 97.8°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 122/83 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Cardiac auscultation reveals a crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard right of the upper sternal border with radiation into the carotids. An ECG shows left axis deviation and meets criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. An initial troponin is < 0.01 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his mother is concerned about his lack of appetite and poor weight gain. He has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. The patient states that he should try to lose more weight because he does not want to be overweight anymore. He maintains a diary of his daily calorie intake. Menarche was at the age of 13 years, and his last menstrual period was 3 months ago. He is on the high school track team. He is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He is at 50th percentile for height and below the 5th percentile for weight and BMI. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 58/min and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination shows fine hair over the trunk and extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old female presents with progressively worsening headaches over the past two months. She also feels that she has been losing her balance more often over the past week, but she denies any motor weakness or sensory impairment. Her neurological exam reveals impaired upward gaze, pupils that constrict poorly to light but react to accommodation, and bilateral upper eyelid retraction. On tandem walking, she tends to fall on both sides. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 30-year-old man seeks evaluation at a local walk-in clinic with a week-long history of lightheadedness and palpitations. He also complains of fatigability and shortness of breath of the same duration. The past medical history is significant for menarche at 9 years of age, heavy menstrual bleeding for the past several years and abdominal pain that worsens during menses. He stopped trying to conceive a child after 2 spontaneous abortions in the past 4 years and has been on iron oral supplementation for the last 2 years. He adds that he feels a dull pressure-like discomfort in his pelvis and constipation. The physical examination is significant for pale mucous membranes and a grade 2/6 ejection systolic murmur in the area of the pulmonic valve. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged, mobile uterus with an irregular contour. The hemoglobin level is 10 g/dL and the hematocrit is 27%. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An otherwise healthy 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of palpitations. She says that she can feel her heart beat in her chest all the time. For the past 3 weeks, she has shortness of breath on exertion. She has not had chest pain, orthopnea, or nocturnal dyspnea. She emigrated from Nepal at the age of 25 years. She does not take any medications. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 138/56 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Parents bring an 11-month-old baby to the clinic because the baby has a fever of 39.0°C (102.2°F). The baby is irritated and crying constantly. He is up to date on immunizations. A complete physical examination reveals no significant findings, and all laboratory tests are negative. Five days after resolution of his fever, he develops a transient maculopapular rash. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-month-old boy is brought in by his mother to the pediatrician for the first time since his 6-month checkup. The mother states that his daughter had been doing fine, but the parents are now concerned that their daughter is still not able to stand up or speak. On exam, the patient has a temperature of 98.5°F (36.9°C), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mmHg. The child appears to have difficulty supporting herself while sitting. The patient has no other abnormal physical findings. He plays by herself and is making babbling noises but does not respond to his own name. He appears to have some purposeless motions. A previous clinic note documents typical development at his 6-month visit and mentioned that the patient was sitting unsupported at that time. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of generalized fatigue. During the past week, she has also had fever and severe leg pain that keeps him awake at night. Examination shows cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. Her liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin and the spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. Her hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL, leukocyte count is 64,500/mm3, and platelet count is 29,000/mm3. A bone marrow aspirate predominantly shows immature cells that stain positive for CD10, CD19, and TdT. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 73-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of right-sided body weakness. Her husband reports that she does not seem to understand simple questions. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. The patient speaks fluently, but she answers questions with nonsensical phrases and cannot repeat single words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a cough for the past 3 months. The cough is mostly dry, but the patient recalls a recent episode in which she coughed up mucus with dark red streaks. She has felt tired for the past few months. Over the past month, she has had poor appetite and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. She also has occasional back pain, which has worsened in recent weeks. She has no recent travel history. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She does not drink alcohol. Her vitals are within normal limits. Auscultation of the lungs reveals wheezing in the lower right lung field. There is no peripheral lymphadenopathy. The liver is of normal size, and the spleen is not palpable. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.5 g/dL, serum calcium concentration of 12.3 mg/dL, and a total serum protein of 7.0 g/dL. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe back pain that began when she was lifting a box 1 hour ago. She also has a 2-year history of increasingly severe right hip pain. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the lower spine as well as erythema of the skin over the right hip. Neurologic examination shows decreased hearing in the left ear; the Weber test localizes to the left side. Serum studies show an alkaline phosphatase concentration of 410 U/L, calcium concentration of 9.5 mg/dL, and parathyroid hormone level of 322 pg/mL. An x-ray of the spine shows a fracture of the L4 vertebra. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old African-American female is found to have a holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmur upon physical examination. The murmur is best appreciated at the left sternal border, and is found to be louder when the patient squats. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presents with loose stools and left lower quadrant abdominal pain. She says she passes 8–10 loose stools per day. The volume of each bowel movement is small and appears mucoid with occasional blood. The patient reports a 20-pack-year smoking history. She also says she recently traveled abroad about 3 weeks ago to Egypt. The vital signs include: blood pressure 120/76 mm Hg, pulse 74/min, and temperature 36.5°C (97.8°F). On physical examination, mild to moderate tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant with no rebound or guarding is present. Rectal examination shows the presence of perianal skin ulcers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 23-year-old man comes to the physician for a 6-month history of dry cough, hoarseness, and chest pain. He does not smoke and has not lost weight. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows a mass that projects across the right hilum. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with complaints of chronic headaches that have developed and increased in frequency and severity over the last several months. Additionally, the patient has noted she has been less coordinated over the last few weeks, stumbling and tripping often when she is walking. Physical examination is significant for notably reduced hand grip strength bilaterally as well as decreased pain and temperature sensation along the upper back and down both arms to the hands. A referral to the appropriate specialist is made, and an MRI of the brain and neck is obtained. Results of the MRI are show in Figures A and B. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 17-year-old boy comes to the primary care clinic with his father complaining of right knee pain. He reports that the pain started about a month ago, and since then it has gotten progressively worse. The knee pain is not constant but becomes most noticeable when going up or down the stairs. He also endorses that his knee becomes uncomfortable towards the end of class. His father is worried because the pain is affecting his ability to play basketball, and he has college scouts coming to watch his play. The patient has no chronic medical conditions. He had a tonsillectomy as a child. He takes a multivitamin and uses ibuprofen as needed for the pain. On physical examination, there is tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella, without swelling or overlying skin changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 34 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of dyspnea, dry cough, and chest pain. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. Examination shows jugular venous distention and bilateral pitting edema below the knees that is worse on the right side. There is dullness to percussion over the right lung base. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman who underwent liver transplantation 3 months ago for chronic liver failure presents to the physician because of a backache following a fall from sitting. She is currently on immunosuppressive therapy with glucocorticoids and cyclosporine. She has no comorbidities. On physical examination, her vitals are within normal limits. She has tenderness over her lumbar spine. An X-ray of the lumbar spine shows a wedge compression fracture of the L1 vertebra. Her serum testosterone and serum creatinine levels are normal. Bone mineral densitometry shows a T-score of –3.0. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old woman with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to her primary care physician complaining of recurrent chest pain with activity. The patient used to have chest pain when she mowed her lawn. Now she gets chest pain whenever she walks short distances such as to get her mail. The pain resolves on its own when the patient sits and rests. Her temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 157/98 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an obese woman who is in no distress. An initial ECG is unchanged from a previous ECG. The patient's first troponin is 0.06 ng/mL which is unchanged from previous troponins. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 73-year-old female is brought to her family practitioner by her daughter with the complaints of a spinning sensation for the past 4 weeks. She says that the room appears to be continuously spinning. This has progressively worsened over the last 4 weeks to the point that she has become bed bound and cannot walk without support. These spinning sensations are present throughout the day and do not change with position. They are associated with nausea and vomiting. She denies ear pain, ear discharge, ringing in the ear, hearing disturbances, ear fullness, head trauma, fever, or recent flu-like illness. She has a blood pressure of 133/80 mm Hg, heart rate of 80/min, respiratory rate of 12/min, and temperature of 36.7°C (98.2°F). Her extraocular eye movements are normal in all directions, but a vertical nystagmus is present that does not disappear despite repetitive testing. Hearing tests are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician after her parents noticed the appearance of a rash on her face, torso, and limbs. The girl has been ill for almost 2 weeks, initiating with fever, malaise, coryza, headache, nausea, diarrhea, and a rash on both of her cheeks. Physical examination is unremarkable except for an erythematous maculopapular rash on the face, trunk, and extremities with a reticular pattern (as shown in the photograph). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 69-year-old male presents to the emergency room with back pain. She has a history of personality disorder and metastatic prostate cancer and was not a candidate for surgical resection. She began chemotherapy but discontinued due to unremitting nausea. She denies any bowel or bladder incontinence. She has never had pain like this before and is demanding morphine. The nurse administers IV morphine and she feels more comfortable. Vital signs are stable. On physical examination you note tenderness to palpation along the lower spine, weakness in the bilateral lower extremities, left greater than right. Neurological examination is also notable for hyporeflexia in the knee and ankle jerks bilaterally. You conduct a rectal examination, which reveals saddle anesthesia. Regarding this patient, what is the most likely diagnosis and the appropriate next step in management?
answer: The most likely diagnosis is cauda equina syndrome and steroids should be started prior to MRI

options.A: The most likely diagnosis is cauda equina syndrome and steroids should be started prior to MRI
options.B: The most likely diagnosis is cauda equina syndrome and steroids should be started after to MRI
options.C: The most likely diagnosis is cauda equina syndrome and the patient should be rushed to radiation
options.D: The most likely diagnosis is conus medullaris syndrome and steroids should be started prior to MRI
options.E: The most likely diagnosis is conus medullaris syndrome and steroids should be started after to MRI

question: A 42-year-old man is in the hospital recovering from a cholecystectomy performed 3 days ago that was complicated by cholangitis. He is being treated with IV piperacillin-tazobactam. He calls the nurse to his room because he says that his heart is racing. He also demands that someone come in to clean the pile of garbage off of the floor because it is attracting flies. His pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient appears sweaty, distressed, and unable to remain still. He is oriented to person, but not place or time. Palpation of the abdomen shows no tenderness, rebound, or guarding. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for excessive hair growth. His mother reports that for the past 2 months he has noticed hair at the axillary and pubic areas. He denies any family history of precocious puberty and reports that his daughter has been relatively healthy with an uncomplicated birth history. He denies any recent illnesses, weight change, fever, vaginal bleeding, pain, or medication use. Physical examination demonstrates Tanner stage 4 development. A pelvic ultrasound shows an ovarian mass. Laboratory studies demonstrates an elevated level of estrogen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of double vision, difficulty climbing stairs, and weakness when trying to brush his hair. He reports that these symptoms are worse after he exercises and disappear after he rests for a few hours. Physical examination shows drooping of his right upper eyelid that worsens when the patient is asked to gaze at the ceiling for 2 minutes. There is diminished motor strength in the upper extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man with a history of Crohn disease presents for a follow-up appointment. He says that lately, he has started to notice difficulty walking. He says that some of his friends have joked that he appears to be walking as if he was drunk. Past medical history is significant for Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, managed with natalizumab for the past year because his intestinal symptoms have become severe and unresponsive to other therapies. On physical examination, there is gait and limb ataxia present. Strength is 4/5 in the right upper limb. A T1/T2 MRI of the brain is ordered and is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-month-old girl is brought to a medical office by her mother. The mother states that the girl has been very fussy and has not been feeding recently. The mother thinks the baby has been gaining weight despite not feeding well. The girl was delivered vaginally at 39 weeks gestation without complications. On physical examination, the girl is noted to be crying in her mother’s arms. There is no evidence of cyanosis, and the cardiac examination is within normal limits. The crying intensifies when the abdomen is palpated. The abdomen is distended with tympany in the left lower quadrant. You suspect a condition caused by the failure of specialized cells to migrate. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and worsening abdominal pain for 4 weeks. She also reports excessive night sweats and a 5.4-kg (12-lb) weight loss during this time. She has a neck swelling for 4 days. Physical examination shows a nontender, enlarged, and fixed supraclavicular lymph node. There is splenomegaly. A CT scan of the thorax and abdomen shows massively enlarged axillary, mediastinal, and cervical lymph nodes. Analysis of an excised cervical lymph node shows lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man has been receiving amoxicillin for acute sinusitis for 12 days. He develops a macular rash on his neck, back, and torso. The amoxicillin is therefore changed to cephalexin for an additional week. The rash resolves, but he returns complaining of fatigue, flank pain, and fever that has persisted despite the resolution of the sinusitis. He has a history of essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastric reflux. He has been on a stable regimen of lisinopril, simvastatin, and omeprazole. Today, his vital signs reveal: temperature 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure 145/90 mm Hg, regular pulse 75/min, and respirations 16/min. The physical examination is unremarkable. Serum urea and creatinine are elevated. Urinalysis shows leukocyturia, but urine bacterial culture is negative. A urine cytospin stained with Hansel’s solution reveals 3% binucleated cells with eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for knee pain. The patient states it started yesterday and has been steadily worsening. He recently joined a volleyball team to try to get into shape as he was informed that weight loss would be beneficial for his at his last physical exam. He states that he has been repetitively pivoting and twisting on his knee while playing volleyball. The patient has a past medical history of polycystic ovarian syndrome and is currently taking oral contraceptive pills. His temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 137/88 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals an obese man with facial hair. Physical exam is notable for tenderness that is mediated with palpation over the medial aspect of the tibia just inferior to the patella. His BMI is 37 kg/m^2. The rest of the exam of the lower extremity is not remarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following an episode of loss of consciousness 1 hour ago. She had just finished micturating, when she fell down. Her husband heard the noise and found him unconscious on the floor. She regained consciousness after 30 seconds and was able to talk normally with her husband immediately. There was no urinary incontinence. On arrival, she is alert and oriented. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference range. An electrocardiogram shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3000-g (6.6-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old primigravid woman. The mother has had no prenatal care. Immunization records are not available. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. There are several bluish macules on the skin that do not blanch with pressure. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass his auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 48-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a left breast mass that he noticed 4 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 6-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. An image of a biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man presents to the labor and delivery floor in active labor at 40 weeks gestation. He has a prolonged course but ultimately vaginally delivers an 11 pound boy. On post operative day 2, he is noted to have uterine tenderness and decreased bowel sounds. He states he has been urinating more frequently as well. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg, pulse is 111/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a non-distended abdomen and a tender uterus. Pulmonary exam reveals minor bibasilar crackles. Initial laboratory studies and a urinalysis are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presents with a mass on the central part of her neck. She reports it has been growing steadily for the past 2 weeks, and she has also been experiencing fatigue and recurrent fevers. No significant past medical history. The patient denies any smoking history, or alcohol or recreational drug use. She denies any recent travel in the previous 6 months. On physical examination, there are multiple enlarged submandibular and cervical lymph nodes that are firm, mobile, and non-tender. A biopsy of one of the lymph nodes is performed and shows predominantly lymphocytes and histiocytes present in a pattern ‘resembling popcorn’. A flow cytometry analysis demonstrates cells that are CD19 and CD20 positive and CD15 and CD30 negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 45-year-old man comes to the office with a 2-week history of rectal bleeding that occurs every day with his bowel movements. He denies any pain during defecation. Apart from this, he does not have any other complaints. His past medical history is insignificant except for 5 normal vaginal deliveries. His vitals are a heart rate of 72/min, a respiratory rate of 15/min, a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F), and a blood pressure of 115/85 mm Hg. On rectovaginal examination, there is a palpable, non-tender, prolapsed mass that can be pushed back by the examiner's finger into the anal sphincter. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician for recurrent 3–4 minutes episodes of facial grimacing and staring over the past month. She is nonresponsive during these episodes and does not remember them afterward. She recalls a muddy taste in her mouth before the onset of symptoms. One week ago, her brother witnessed an episode where she woke up, stared, and made hand gestures. After the incident, she felt lethargic and confused. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing blurring of vision in both eyes. He says that the blurring has made it difficult to read, although he has noticed that he can read a little better if he holds the book below or above eye level. He also requires a bright light to look at objects. He reports that his symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually gotten worse over time. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide and lisinopril. When looking at an Amsler grid, he says that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. An image of his retina, as viewed through fundoscopy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision, in which he was the restrained driver of the back car. On arrival, he is alert and active. He reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Two days following the home birth of her son, a mother brings the infant to the pediatric emergency room because of bilious vomiting. She is unable to pass meconium and her abdomen is distended. Endoscopic biopsy of the proximal colon demonstrates an absence of Meissner’s and Auerbach’s plexi in the bowel wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman presents for severe abdominal pain and is diagnosed with appendicitis. She is taken for emergent appendectomy. During the procedure, the patient has massive and persistent bleeding requiring a blood transfusion. The preoperative laboratory studies showed a normal bleeding time, normal prothrombin time (PT), an INR of 1.0, and a normal platelet count. Postoperatively, when the patient is told about the complications during the surgery, she recalls that she forgot to mention that she has a family history of an unknown bleeding disorder. The postoperative laboratory tests reveal a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 30-year-old woman presents with restlessness and an inability to sit or lie down for the past 2 days. Past medical history is significant for schizophrenia, diagnosed 3 weeks ago and managed medically. Vital signs are a blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg and a pulse of 96/min. On physical examination, the patient is fidgety and anxious but well-oriented. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a progressive swelling and pain in her right ring finger for the past 2 days. The pain began while playing football, when her finger got caught in the jersey of another player who forcefully pulled away. Examination shows that the right ring finger is extended. There is pain and swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint. When the patient is asked to make a fist, her right ring finger does not flex at the distal interphalangeal joint. There is no joint laxity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
answer: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion

options.A: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion
options.B: Closed fracture of the distal phalanx
options.C: Rupture of the extensor digitorum tendon at its point of insertion
options.D: Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath
options.E: Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon

question: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine checkup. She has had a progressively increasing swelling on the nape of her neck for 2 months. She does not have a fever or any discharge from the swelling. She underwent a colectomy for colon cancer at the age of 43 years. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of the left knee. Current medications include insulin glargine, metformin, enalapril, and naproxen. She has worked as a traffic warden for the past 6 years and frequently plays golf. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg. Examination of the neck shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, mobile, and painless nodule. The skin over the nodule cannot be pinched. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful skin lesion on his right leg for 1 month. It initially started out as a small red spot but has rapidly increased in size during this period. He remembers an ant bite on his leg prior to the lesion occurring. He was treated for anterior uveitis 8 months ago with corticosteroids. He has Crohn's disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Current medications include insulin, mesalamine, enalapril, and aspirin. He returned from Wisconsin after visiting his son 2 months ago. His temperature is 37.6°C (98°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 126/88 mm Hg. Examination shows pitting pedal edema of the lower extremities. There is a 4-cm tender ulcerative lesion on the anterior right leg with a central necrotic base and purplish irregular borders. There are dilated tortuous veins in both lower legs. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpated bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of vaginal bleeding for the past hour. The patient reports that he felt contractions prior to the onset of the bleeding, but the contractions stopped after the bleeding started. He also has severe abdominal pain. His first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness with no rebound or guarding; no contractions are felt. The fetal heart rate shows recurrent variable decelerations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old man presents with sudden-onset pain in his lower back. He says he was exercising in the gym several hours ago when he felt a sharp pain. The pain is radiating down the side of his leg and into his foot. On physical exam, his vital signs are as follows: HR 95, BP 120/70, T 37.2 degrees C. He has extreme pain shooting down his leg with a straight leg raise. His sensation to light touch and pin-prick is intact throughout. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old woman with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in her right eye. She has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. She was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. She was diagnosed with Kaposi's sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lbs);BMI is 15.6 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over her trunk and extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year old woman comes to the physician because of a painless neck lump and a 2-month history of difficulty swallowing. She has a history of recurrent nephrolithiasis and episodic hypertension. Physical examination shows a 3 × 3-cm, nontender nodule at the level of the thyroid cartilage. A photomicrograph of a section of tissue obtained by core needle biopsy of the nodule is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a skin lesion on her chest. She first noticed the lesion 2 months ago and thinks that it has increased in size since then. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and glaucoma. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and drinks two to three beers on the weekend. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, topical timolol, and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lesion is partly elevated on palpation and does not change its form on pinching. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old nulliparous man with no significant medical history presents to your office with shortness of breath and increased abdominal girth over the past month. The initial assessment demonstrates that the patient has a right-sided hydrothorax, ascites, and a large ovarian mass. Surgery is performed to remove the ovarian mass, and the patient's ascites and pleural effusion resolve promptly. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with a 2-month history of insidious onset of left shoulder pain. It only occurs at the extremes of his range of motion and has made it difficult to sleep on the affected side. He has noticed increasing difficulty with activities of daily living, including brushing his hair and putting on or taking off his blouse and bra. He denies a history of shoulder trauma, neck pain, arm/hand weakness, numbness, or paresthesias. His medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin and glipizide. His physical examination reveals a marked decrease in both active and passive range of motion of the left shoulder, with forwarding flexion to 75°, abduction to 75°, external rotation to 45°, and internal rotation to 15° with significant pain. Rotator cuff strength is normal. AP, scapular Y, and axillary plain film radiographs are reported as normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 77-year-old man is brought to his primary care provider by his daughter with behavioral changes and an abnormally bad memory for the past few months. The patient’s daughter says he sometimes gets angry and aggressive while at other times he seems lost and stares at his surroundings. His daughter also reports that he has seen his mother talking to empty chairs. The patient says he sleeps well during the night but still feels sleepy throughout the day. He has no problems getting dressed and maintaining his one bedroom apartment. Past medical history is significant for mild depression and mild osteoporosis. Current medications include escitalopram, alendronic acid, and a multivitamin. The patient is afebrile, and his vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented and sitting comfortably in his chair. A mild left-hand tremor is noted. Muscle strength is 5 out of 5 in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally, but muscle tone is slightly increased. He can perform repetitive alternating movements albeit slowly. He walks with a narrow gait and has mild difficulty turning. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 17-year-old girl comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of pain in her left wrist. That morning the pain increased and she started to have chills and malaise. Last week she had self-resolving left knee pain. She is otherwise healthy and has not had any trauma to the wrist. She recently returned from a camping trip to Minnesota. She is sexually active with one female partner, who uses a diaphragm for contraception. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F). Examination shows several painless violaceous vesiculopustular lesions on the dorsum of both wrists and hands; two lesions are present on the left palm. There is swelling and erythema of the left wrist with severe tenderness to palpation and passive movement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A newborn born at 33 weeks of gestation has a respiratory rate of 70/min and a heart rate of 148/min 2 hours after birth. She is grunting and has intercostal and subcostal retractions. She has peripheral cyanosis as well. An immediate chest radiograph is taken which shows a fine reticular granulation with ground glass appearance on both lungs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 71-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with non-specific complaints of fatigue and malaise. Her past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, non-seminomatous testicular cancer, and hypercholesterolemia. She currently smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day, drinks a glass of wine per day, and she currently denies any illicit drug use. Her vital signs include: temperature, 36.7°C (98.0°F); blood pressure, 126/74 mm Hg; heart rate, 87/min; and respiratory rate, 17/min.
