On examination, her physician notices cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy bilaterally, as well as splenomegaly. The patient comments that she has lost 18.1 kg (40 lb) over the past 6 months without a change in diet or exercise, which she was initially not concerned about. The physician orders a complete blood count and adds on flow cytometry. Based on her age and overall epidemiology, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician for a well-child visit. Her mother reports him to be doing well and has no concerns. The girl was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. On physical exam, she is noted to have a right upper extremity blood pressure of 150/80 mm Hg. 2+ radial pulses and trace femoral pulses are felt. Cardiac auscultation reveals a regular rate and rhythm with a normal S1 and S2. A 2/6 long systolic murmur with systolic ejection click is heard over left sternal border and back. The point of maximal impact is normal Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a mildly pruritic rash on his trunk and extremities for 2 days. One week ago, he developed a low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and headache, followed by a facial rash 4 days later. The facial rash did not involve the perioral skin. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F). A photograph of the rash on his lower arms is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old female is evaluated for frequent epistaxis and mucous membrane bleeding. Physical examination shows diffuse petechiae on the patient’s distal extremities. Peripheral blood smear shows an absence of platelet clumping. An ELISA binding assay reveals that platelet surfaces are deficient in GIIb/IIIa receptors. Serum platelet count is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 75-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with his son because he is convinced that people are stealing from her. His son claims he has been misplacing his medications and money throughout the house. He recently lost his wife to old age and has become reclusive and no longer wants people to visit. Physical examination is unremarkable and the patient is oriented to person, time, and place. A mini-mental status examination (MMSE) is performed and he has difficulty recalling words after 5 minutes and also has problems with serial subtraction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 24-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling of the left knee for 2 months. The pain has awoken him from her sleep on multiple occasions. She tried ibuprofen but has had no relief of her symptoms. There is no family or personal history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the left knee is mildly swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the left knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-month-old boy presents for routine health maintenance. The patient has coarse facial features and stiff joint movements with restricted passive and active range of motion. She also has problems following objects with her eyes and seems not to focus on anything. On physical examination, the corneas are clouded, and the patient fails to meet any 3-month developmental milestones. Genetic testing and histopathology are performed and reveal failure of a cellular structure to phosphorylate mannose residues on glycoproteins. An electron microscopy image of one of this patient’s cells is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for sudden weakness. The patient states that she was at home enjoying her morning coffee when her symptoms began. She says that her left arm suddenly felt very odd and weak thus prompting him to come to the ED. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes, COPD, hypertension, anxiety, alcohol abuse, and PTSD. She recently fell off a horse while horseback riding but claims to not have experienced any significant injuries. She typically drinks 5-7 drinks per day and her last drink was yesterday afternoon. Her current medications include insulin, metformin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, albuterol, and fluoxetine. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 177/118 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. On physical exam, you note an elderly woman who is mildly confused. Cardiopulmonary exam demonstrates bilateral expiratory wheezes and a systolic murmur along the right upper sternal border that radiates to the carotids. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves II-XII as grossly intact with finger-nose exam mildly abnormal on the left and heel-shin exam within normal limits. The patient has 5/5 strength in her right arm and 3/5 strength in her left arm. The patient struggles to manipulate objects such as a pen with her left hand. The patient is given a dose of diazepam and started on IV fluids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 54-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of progressive difficulty walking during the past 3 months. She has not been able to walk without assistance for the past month and has started to use a wheelchair. She also reports having urinary incontinence for 1 year. Her husband says that she has begun to slur her words and has become very difficult to understand. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 16/min. Her blood pressure is 130/80mm Hg while sitting and 110/65mm Hg when standing. She is oriented to person and place but not to time. Neurological examination shows a mild tremor in her right hand and rigidity in her upper and lower extremities. She is unable to perform repetitive rotary forearm movements. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Six hours after delivery, a 3050-g (6-lb 12-oz) male newborn is noted to have feeding intolerance and several episodes of bilious vomiting. He was born at term to a healthy 35-year-old man following a normal vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, but the patient's mother had missed several of his prenatal checkups. The patient's older brother underwent surgery for pyloric stenosis as an infant. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows epicanthus, upward slanting of the eyelids, low-set ears, and a single transverse palmar crease. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left mid to lower sternal border. Abdominal examination shows a distended upper abdomen and a concave-shaped lower abdomen. There is no organomegaly. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 53-year-old woman is being evaluated for a 3-week history of fatigue, difficulty to concentrate, dyspnea with exertion, dizziness, and digital pain that improves with cold. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes a day since she was 20. Her current medical history involves hypertension. She takes enalapril daily. The vital signs include a blood pressure of 131/82 mm Hg, a heart rate of 95/min, and a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F). On physical examination, splenomegaly is found. A complete blood count reveals thrombocytosis of 700,000 cells/m3. Lab work further shows decreased serum iron, iron saturation, and serum ferritin and increased total iron binding capacity. A blood smear reveals an increased number of abnormal platelets, and a bone marrow aspirate confirmed the presence of dysplastic megakaryocytes. A mutation on her chromosome 9 confirms the physician’s suspicion of a certain clonal myeloproliferative disease. The patient is started on hydroxyurea. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old Caucasian female presents to your office with hematuria and right flank pain. She has no history of renal dialysis but has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. You order an intravenous pyelogram, which reveals multiple cysts of the collecting ducts in the medulla. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by police officers because she was acting strangely in public. The patient was found talking nonsensically to characters on cereal boxes in the store. Past medical history is significant for multiple hospitalizations for alcohol-related injuries and seizures. The patient’s vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a disheveled male who is oriented to person, but not time or place. Neurologic examination shows nystagmus and severe gait ataxia. A T1/T2 MRI is performed and demonstrates evidence of damage to the mammillary bodies. The patient is given the appropriate treatment for recovering most of her cognitive functions. However, significant short-term memory deficits persist. The patient remembers events from her past such as the school and college she attended, her current job, and the names of family members quite well. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 30-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because they have been trying to conceive for 15 months with no success. They have been sexually active at least twice a week. The wife sometimes has difficulties maintaining erection during sexual activity. During attempted vaginal penetration, the patient has discomfort and his pelvic floor muscles tighten up. Three years ago, the patient was diagnosed with body dysmorphic disorder. There is no family history of serious illness. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows normal appearing vulva without redness; there is no vaginal discharge. An initial attempt at speculum examination is aborted after the patient's pelvic floor muscles tense up and he experiences discomfort. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 74-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of abdominal pain that is most felt around the umbilicus. The pain began 16 hours ago and has no association with meals. She has not been vomiting, but she has had several episodes of bloody loose bowel movements. She was hospitalized 1 week ago for an acute myocardial infarction. She has had diabetes mellitus for 35 years and hypertension for 20 years. She has smoked 15–20 cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg, and pulse is 95/min. On physical examination, the patient is in severe pain, there is a mild periumbilical tenderness, and a bruit is heard over the epigastric area. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of episodic cough and shortness of breath. The cough is nonproductive and worsens when he climbs stairs and during the night. He has not had chest pain or palpitations. Eight weeks ago, he had fever, sore throat, and nasal congestion. He has a 10-year history of hypertension. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years. His only medication is enalapril. His pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Diffuse end-expiratory wheezes are heard on pulmonary auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 60%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 9-month-old infant is brought to the physician because of a generalized nonpruritic rash for 2 days. The rash began on his trunk and spread to his extremities. Five days ago, he was taken to the emergency department for fever of 40.5°C (104.9°F) and a 1-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He was born at term and has no history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. Current medications include acetaminophen. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and pulse is 120/min. Examination shows a maculopapular rash that blanches on pressure. A photograph of the rash is shown. Posterior auricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of a pruritic rash on the bilateral upper extremities. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. A skin biopsy of the rash shows intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of generalized weakness and difficulty walking for the past month. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 6.6 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 74 μm3, platelet count of 150,000/mm3, and serum total bilirubin of 2 mg/dl. An MRI of the spine shows low signal intensity in all vertebral bodies and a small epidural mass compressing the spinal canal at the level of L1. A CT scan of the head shows osteopenia with widening of the diploic spaces in the skull. A biopsy of the epidural mass shows erythroid colonies with an abundance of megakaryocytes and myeloid cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 69-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for pain when she walks. She states that the pain is the worst in her left great toe but is also present in her hips and knees. She says that her symptoms are worse with activity and tend to improve with rest. Her symptoms have progressively worsened over the past several years. She has a past medical history of obesity, type II diabetes mellitus, smoking, and hypertension. She drinks roughly ten beers per day. Her current medications include metformin, insulin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. The patient has a recent travel history to Bangkok where she admits to having unprotected sex. On physical exam, examination of the lower extremity results in pain. There is crepitus of the patient's hip when her thigh is flexed and extended. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to a rash. She states the rash started last night and is very concerning to him. The patient cannot remember being exposed to any environmental stimuli such as new detergents or poison ivy. The patient recently started following with a primary care provider who is helping him manage her arthritis and a new onset cough. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the findings of coalescing erythematous macules, bullae, desquamation, and mucositis only on the upper half of her back. Cardiopulmonary exam and abdominal exam are within normal limits. Inspection of the patient’s oropharynx reveals ulcers and erythema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has not had his menstrual period yet. At birth, he was found to have partial labial fusion and clitoromegaly. The mother reports that during the pregnancy he had noticed abnormal hair growth on his chin. The boy has severe acne. Three years ago, he broke his wrist after a minor trauma. Last year, he sustained a spinal compression fracture after lifting a box during a move. He currently takes oral isotretinoin and an oral contraceptive. The patient is at the 97th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows numerous inflamed pustules on his face and upper back. Breast development is at Tanner stage I. The patient refuses to have a pelvic examination. A pelvic ultrasound shows ovaries with multiple cysts and a normal uterus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old man comes to your office because he noticed the growth of unwanted hair on his upper lip, chin, and chest. He has also noticed an increase in blackheads and pimples on his skin. His female partner has also recently brought to his attention the deepening of his voice, weight gain, and changes in his external genitalia that generated some personal relationship issues. The patient is frustrated as these changes have appeared over the course of the last 8 months. He claims that he was feeling completely normal before all of these physical changes started. Physical examination shows dark coarse stubbles distributed along his upper lip, chin, chest, back, oily skin, and moderately inflamed acne. Pelvic examination reveals a clitoris measuring 12 mm long, a normal sized mobile retroverted uterus, and a firm, enlarged left ovary. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of stiffness and pain in multiple joints. He says that the fingers on both of his hands have become increasingly stiff and difficult to move over the past 8 months. He also complains of nails that break easily and look spotty as well as chronic back pain. He had a urinary tract infection a year ago that was treated with antibiotics. He is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His vitals are within normal limits. A photograph of his right hand is shown. There are multiple, well-demarcated red plaques with silvery-white scales over the shins and back. Serum studies show a negative rheumatoid factor and ANA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a chief complaint of "failing health." She states that she typically can converse with animals via telepathy, but is having trouble right now due to the weather. She has begun taking an assortment of Peruvian herbs to little avail. Otherwise she is not currently taking any medications. The patient lives alone and works in a health food store. She states that her symptoms have persisted for the past eight months. On physical exam, you note a healthy young woman who is dressed in an all burlap ensemble. When you are obtaining the patient's medical history there are several times she is attempting to telepathically connect with the animals in the vicinity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old woman seeks evaluation at an outpatient clinic for a single, red, crusty lesion on the shaft of her penis and a similar lesion on the middle finger of her left hand. She recently immigrated to the US from Africa. The lesions are painless and the physicians in her country treated him for syphilis and eczema, with no improvement. She lives with her 4th husband. She smokes 2 packs of cigarette per day and has been doing so for the last 30 years. She is not aware of any family members with malignancies or hereditary diseases. The physical examination is remarkable for an erythematous plaque, with areas of crusting, oozing, and irregular borders on the dorsal surface of the penile shaft and a similar lesion on her left middle finger (shown in the picture). The regional lymph nodes are not affected. A biopsy is obtained and the pathologic evaluation reveals cells with nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitotic figures within the follicle-bearing epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A parent-teacher conference is called to discuss the behavior of a 9 year-old girl. According to the girl's teacher, she has become progressively more disruptive during class. When asked to help clean up or read out-loud, she replies with "You're not the boss of me." or "You can't make me." She refuses to participate in gym class, but will play the same games during recess. She gets along with and is well-liked by her peers. Her mother reports that her son can "sometimes be difficult," but she is helpful around the house and is very good playing with her 7-year-old sister. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old primigravid man is brought to the emergency department after complaining of severe abdominal pain for 3 hours. He has had no prenatal care. There is no leakage of amniotic fluid. Since arrival, he has had 5 contractions in 10 minutes, each lasting 70 to 90 seconds. Pelvic examination shows a closed cervix and a uterus consistent in size with a 38-week gestation. Ultrasound shows a single live intrauterine fetus in a breech presentation consistent with a gestational age of approximately 37 weeks. The amniotic fluid index is 26 and the fetal heart rate is 92/min. The placenta is not detached. He is scheduled for an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. The infant is delivered and APGAR score is noted to be 8 at 1 minute. The doctor soon notices cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa, which does not resolve when the infant cries. The infant is foaming at the mouth and drooling. He also has an intractable cough. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-month-old infant is brought in by her parents because she is vomiting and not passing stool. Her parents say she has vomited multiple times over the past couple of hours, but the most recent vomit was green. The patient has no significant past medical history. On physical examination, the patient is irritable and crying. On palpation in the periumbilical region, an abdominal mass is present. Emergency laparotomy is performed, which shows a part of the patient’s intestine folded into the section adjacent to it. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 72-year-old woman is brought in by her daughter who is concerned about her recent memory impairment. The patient’s daughter says she has noticed impairment in memory and functioning for the past month. She says that she has forgotten to pay bills and go shopping, and, as a result, the electricity was cut off due to non-payment. She also says that last week, she turned the stove on and forgot about it, resulting in a kitchen fire. The patient has lived by himself since her husband died last year. She fondly recalls living with her husband and how much she misses her. She admits that she feels ‘down’ most days of the week living on her own and doesn’t have much energy. When asked about the kitchen fire and problems with the electricity, she gets defensive and angry. At the patient’s last routine check-up 3 months ago, she was healthy with no medical problems. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears to have a flat affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 65-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for fatigue. The patient states that she has not been sleeping well and requests sleep medication to help him with her fatigue. She recently changed her diet to try to increase her energy and has been on a vegetarian diet for the past several months. The patient has no significant past medical history. She smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day and drinks 5 alcoholic beverages per day. The patient has lost 12 pounds since her last visit 1 month ago. Physical exam demonstrates a tired man. She appears thin, and her skin and sclera are icteric. Abdominal ultrasound is notable for a thin-walled and enlarged gallbladder. A urine sample is collected and is noted to be amber in color. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old man is brought to the physician by his father because of a change in his behavior over the past 8 months. The father says that his daughter has become increasingly withdrawn; he has not answered any phone calls or visited his family and friends. The patient says that he has to stay at home because a foreign intelligence service is monitoring her. He thinks that they are using a magnetic field to read his mind. Mental status exam shows disjointed and perseverative thinking. He is anxious and has a flat affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommates for aggressive and unusual behavior. Her roommates state that she has been under a lot of stress lately from her final exams and has been more reclusive. They state that this evening she was very irritable and was yelling at her computer prior to breaking it, followed by him spending several hours at the gym. Her temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 137/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 23/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an irritable young man. Cardiopulmonary exam is notable for tachycardia and bilateral clear breath sounds. Neurological exam reveals dilated pupils. The patient is notably diaphoretic and speaks very rapidly during the physical exam and is aggressive. She is given haloperidol, diphenhydramine, and diazepam for sedation and placed in soft restraints. Her symptoms resolved over the next 10 hours in the emergency department. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old boy comes to the emergency department with a 5-day history of severe abdominal pain, cramping, nausea, and vomiting. He also has pain with urination. He is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. He experienced a burning pain when he last had sexual intercourse 3 days ago. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days. His last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination shows cervical motion tenderness and purulent cervical discharge. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 15,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 100 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man with a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome, depression, and chronic bilateral ear infections presents to the otolaryngologist's clinic 12 weeks after right ear tympanoplasty. His audiology report one week prior showed that his hearing improved as expected by 20 decibels. However, he reports that he has occasional shooting pain with eating and when he wears earrings. He states that he has a stressful job as a cashier at the local department store and often sleeps poorly. He denies any neck pain or tenderness when he washes his face. On physical exam, no tenderness is elicited with preauricular or mandibular palpation bilaterally. No jaw clicking is heard. Right postauricular tapping causes tenderness in his right tonsillar area. His molar teeth appear even and symmetric bilaterally. His uvula is midline and his gag reflex is intact. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-month-old girl is brought to the clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of stridor and wheezing. Her mother reports that her wheezing is exacerbated by crying, feeding, and flexion of the neck, and is relieved by extension of the neck. Occasionally she vomits after feeding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-day old female newborn delivered vaginally at 36 weeks to a 29-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, has generalized convulsions lasting 2 minutes. Previous to the event, she had difficulty feeding and was lethargic. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Pregnancy and delivery of the mother's first 2 children were also uncomplicated. Medications of the mother include folic acid and a multivitamin. The mother's immunizations are up-to-date. The infant appears icteric. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The infant's weight and length are at the 5th percentile, and her head circumference at the 99th percentile for gestational age. There are several purpura of the skin. Ocular examination shows posterior uveitis. The patient does not pass her auditory screening tests. Cranial ultrasonography shows ventricular dilatation, as well as hyperechoic foci within the cortex, basal ganglia, and periventricular region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother after he noticed multiple painless, nonpruritic papules on his abdomen. The child attends daycare three times per week, and this past week one child was reported to have similar lesions. His immunizations are up-to-date. His brother had chickenpox one month ago. He is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several skin-colored, nontender, pearly papules with central umbilication on the abdomen and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend because of a 4-month history of feeling sad. His girlfriend says that, during this period, he has slept and eaten very little and has been unable to focus at work. He says that he feels “empty inside” and has been hearing voices telling his that he is worthless. He first heard these voices 7 months ago when they started to make fun of her. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, his speech is slow and monotonous; he abruptly stops talking in the middle of sentences and does not finish them. He occasionally directs his attention to the ceiling as if he were listening to someone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 47-year-old woman presents to the clinic for an evaluation of intense itching of her right thigh region for the past few days. She states some ‘red bumps’ just began to form. The patient mentions that she was recently at a business conference in Miami. She has a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes type 2, and hyperlipidemia. She takes enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink. Her vitals are within normal limits today. On physical examination, a linear line with 3 red papules is present along the medial aspect of her right thigh. Additionally, there are small rows of bumps on her left leg and right forearm. Excoriations are also apparent in the same region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old African-American female presents to her family physician after noticing red-tinged urine the week before, when she was suffering from a cold. The patient states that she had experienced that before. Her father is with him and says that this happens to him on occasion as well. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 75-year-old woman presents to the physician with progressive difficulty reading over the past year. Currently, she avoids driving as she has trouble reading road signs. She has no history of a serious illness and takes no medications. The fundoscopic examination shows localized retinal elevation and drusen. A description of the patient’s visual on the Amsler grid is shown. Fluorescein angiography shows early hyperfluorescence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of sadness that started 6 weeks after his 9-month-old daughter was born. Since then, he has not returned to work. His daughter usually sleeps through the night, but the patient still has difficulty staying asleep. He is easily distracted from normal daily tasks. He used to enjoy cooking, but only orders delivery or take-out now. He says that he always feels too exhausted to do so and does not feel hungry much anyway. The pregnancy of the patient's child was complicated by gestational diabetes. The child was born at 36-weeks' gestation and has had no medical issues. The patient has no contact with the child's father. He is not sexually active. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is 157 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 47 kg (105 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert and cooperative but makes little eye contact. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in his right thumb and wrist that radiates to his elbow. It is worse when he holds his infant son and improves with the use of an ice pack. Six months ago, he slipped on a wet floor and fell on his right outstretched hand. His mother takes methotrexate for chronic joint pain. The patient takes ibuprofen as needed for his current symptoms. Examination of the right hand shows tenderness over the radial styloid with swelling but no redness. There is no crepitus. Grasping his right thumb and exerting longitudinal traction toward the ulnar side elicits pain. Range of motion of the finger joints is normal. There is no swelling, redness, or tenderness of any other joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of a rash on her scalp and forehead. The parents report that the rash has been present for several weeks. They state that the rash is sometimes red and scaly, especially when it is cold. The patient was born at 36 weeks' gestation and has generally been healthy since. Her father has psoriasis. The patient appears comfortable. Examination shows several erythematous patches on the scalp, forehead, and along the hairline. Some patches are covered by greasy yellow scales. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with dizziness. She states she has experienced a sustained sensation of the room spinning that is low grade and constant since this morning. The patient occasionally feels nauseous and has been taking diphenydramine to sleep which helps with her symptoms. The patient is generally healthy, has no other medical conditions, and only endorses eating more garlic recently to get over a cold she had a few days ago. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/81 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a healthy man. The patient is sat upright, her head is turned slightly to the right, and she is laid back flat rapidly. This does not provoke any symptoms even when repeated on the left side. A nystagmus is notable on cranial nerve exam as well as bilateral decreased hearing. The patient’s tandem gait is unstable; however, her baseline gait appears unremarkable despite the patient stating she has a sustained sensation of imbalance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Three days after undergoing coronary bypass surgery, a 67-year-old woman becomes unresponsive and hypotensive. She is intubated, mechanically ventilated, and a central line is inserted. Vasopressin and noradrenaline infusions are begun. A Foley catheter is placed. Six days later, she has high unrelenting fevers. She is currently receiving noradrenaline via an infusion pump. Her temperature is 39.6° (102.3°F), pulse is 113/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Examination shows a sternal wound with surrounding erythema; there is no discharge from the wound. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. A Foley catheter is present. Her hemoglobin concentration is 10.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 21,700/mm3, and platelet count is 165,000/mm3. Samples for blood culture are drawn simultaneously from the central line and peripheral IV line. Blood cultures from the central line show coagulase-negative cocci in clusters on the 8th postoperative day, and those from the peripheral venous line show coagulase-negative cocci in clusters on the 10th postoperative day. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 65-year-old woman presents with facial weakness. She says she noticed that her face appeared twisted when she looked in the bathroom mirror this morning. She is otherwise well and does not have any other complaints. She denies any facial pain or paresthesia. No significant past medical history. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination reveals difficulty shutting the right eye tight and inability to bring up the right corner of her mouth when asked to smile. Remainder of the exam, including the left side of the face, is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 55-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of inappropriate behavior for the past 6 months. She has been making inappropriate comments and jokes while talking to friends and family members. She was arrested 3 weeks ago while trying to kiss strangers on the street. She has no interest in talking to her daughter or playing with her grandchildren. During this period, she has developed a strong desire for chocolate pudding and potato chips and has gained 10 kg (22 lb). She appears unkempt. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Mental status examination shows apathy and a blunt affect. She avoids answering questions and instead comments on the individuals she saw in the waiting room. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 28/30. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatine, and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of intermittent bleeding from his vagina. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Pelvic ultrasound shows a thickened endometrial stripe and a left adnexal mass. Endometrial biopsy shows a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Laboratory studies show increased levels of inhibin B. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Three days after delivery, a 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 25 seconds. He has become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He appears ill. His pulse is 123/min, respirations are 50/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of burning pain in her neck and arms for a year. She has also had paresthesias in her hands during this period. She has had increasing weakness in both hands during the past 3 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. She was involved in a motor vehicle collision 3 years ago. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. She has had 7 sexual partners in her lifetime; she uses condoms inconsistently. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination of the upper extremities shows decreased muscle strength, absent reflexes, and decreased hand grip with fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent over the chest and bilateral upper arms. Vibration and joint position sensations are present in the upper limbs. Cranial nerve examination shows no focal findings. Examination of the lower extremities show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man presents to his gynecologist complaining of mild pelvic discomfort and a frothy, yellowish discharge from his vagina for the past 2 weeks. He also complains of pain during sexual intercourse and sometimes after urination. His past medical history is noncontributory. He takes oral contraceptives and a multivitamin daily. He has had two male sexual partners in his lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Today, his vitals are normal. On pelvic exam, he has vulvovaginal erythema and a 'strawberry cervix' that is tender to motion, with minimal green-yellow malodorous discharge. A swab of the vaginal wall is analyzed for pH at bedside. Vaginal pH is 5.8. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 59-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden-onset sensation that the room is spinning causing him to experience several episodes of nausea and vomiting. Upon arriving, the patient’s symptoms have resolved. She states her symptoms occurred as she was going to bed. She has never experienced this before, but felt extremely dizzy for roughly 3 minutes. She currently feels at her baseline. The patient is otherwise healthy and only has a history of eczema. Her temperature is 97.7°F (36.5°C), blood pressure is 134/85 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a healthy woman with a normal gait. The patient has a physiologic nystagmus and her cranial nerve exam is unremarkable. The patient’s head is turned to the left and she is laid back on the stretcher, which exacerbates severe symptoms with a nystagmus notable. The patient’s symptoms improve after 2 minutes of being in this position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive right knee pain for the past 3 months. She reports that the pain is worse at night and while doing sports at school. She has not had any trauma to the knee or any previous problems with her joints. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows mild swelling and tenderness without warmth or erythema; the range of motion is limited. She walks with an antalgic gait. Laboratory studies show an alkaline phosphatase of 180 U/L and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 80 mm/h. An x-ray of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old man at 30 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician with the sudden onset of fever, headache, anorexia, fatigue, and malaise. He mentioned that he had eaten ice cream 3 days ago. Blood cultures show gram-positive rods that are catalase-positive and display distinctive tumbling motility in liquid medium. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 1-year history of abnormal behavior. During this time he has been irritable, restless, and has had multiple episodes of hearing voices. Over the past month, he has also had difficulty swallowing. He has a 2-year history of depression. He was let go by his employer 6 months ago because he could no longer handle all his tasks and often forgot about assignments. His father committed suicide at the age of 50. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily over the past 20 years. He has a history of smoking cocaine for 8 years but stopped 1 year ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is confused and oriented to person and place only. Neurologic examination shows a delayed return to neutral ankle position after triggering the plantar reflex. Physical examination shows irregular, nonrepetitive, and arrhythmic movements of the neck and head. The patient has poor articulation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty sleeping. One to two times per week for the past 2 months, he has woken up frightened in the middle of the night, yelling and crying. He has not seemed confused after waking up, and he is consolable and able to fall back asleep in his parents' bed. The following day, he seems more tired than usual at school. He recalls that he had a bad dream and looks for ways to delay bedtime in the evenings. He has met all his developmental milestones to date. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

During a humanitarian medical mission in rural Vietnam, a medical resident encounters a 50-year-old woman with a year-long history of a pruritic rash on her upper body and face, along with numbness and tingling sensation of both of her palms. She mostly works on her family’s rice farm, where she also takes care of livestock. A physical examination revealed multiple erythematous macules and papules on the face, arms, chest, and back, as well as thinning of the eyebrows and loss of some eyelashes. Additional findings include hypopigmented macules around the elbows, which are insensitive to light touch, temperature, and pinprick. The grip strength is slightly diminished bilaterally with the conservation of both bicipital reflexes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his roommate. His roommate says that the patient has been acting “strangely” for the past 10 days. He has noticed that the patient has been moving and talking on the phone at all hours of the night. He doesn’t think that the patient sleeps more than one to two hours a night. He also spends hours pacing up and down the apartment, talking about “trying to save the world.” He also notices that the patient has been speaking very fast. When asking the patient if anything seems different, the patient denies anything wrong, only adding that, “she’s made great progress on his plans." The patient said he has felt like this on one occasion 2 years ago, and he recalled being hospitalized for about 2 weeks. He denies any history of depression, although he said about a year ago he had no energy and had a hard time motivating herself to go to class and see his friends for months. He denies hearing any voices or any visual hallucinations. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for an annual well-check. His past medical history includes diabetes and hypertension, which are well-controlled with metformin and losartan, respectively. The patient reports a healthy diet consisting of mainly vegetables and lean meat. He denies smoking or alcohol use. He enjoys taking walks with his wife and sunbathing. Physical examination is unremarkable expect for a rough, scaly, sand paper-like plaque on his left dorsal hand with no tenderness or pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months despite a good appetite. She takes no medications. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse, nontender lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL and a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is positive. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old boy is brought into his pediatrician's office by his mother because the mother thinks his daughter has attention issues. The mother explains that his daughter started high school four months ago and had lackluster grades in a recent progress report despite having earned consistent top marks in middle school. The mother complains that his daughter never talks to his at home anymore. The patient yells at his mother in the exam room, and the mother is escorted out of the room. The patient scoffs that his mother is so overbeaing, ruining his good days with criticism. He begins to chew gum and states that he hates hanging out with the boys on the cheerleading squad. He denies experiencing physical abuse from anyone or having a sexual partner. He has seen kids smoke marijuana underneath the football field bleachers, but does not go near them and denies smoking cigarettes. He denies any intention to harm herself or others, thinks his grades went down because his teachers are not as good as his middle school teachers, and states he thinks he learns best by watching explanations through online videos. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 70-year-old woman is accompanied by her husband to the primary care clinic for hand tremors. She states that she first noticed the tremor of her left hand 1 year ago. Since then, the tremor has been worsening and now she can hardly relax when trying to read. Her husband says that she is also worried about her memory. She had to take over the finances several weeks ago after learning that she had forgotten to pay the bills for the past few months. The patient’s medical history is significant for hypertension. She takes aspirin and amlodipine. Her mother had schizophrenia. The patient drinks 1-2 beers a night and is a former cigar smoker. On physical examination, she speaks softly and has reduced facial expressions. She has a resting tremor that is worse on the left, and she resists manipulation of her bilateral upper extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of headache and worsening vision. Ophthalmologic examination shows a visual acuity of 20/120 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 14.2 g/dL and total serum calcium of 9.9 mg/dL. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Serum electrophoresis shows increased concentration of a pentameric immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old female bodybuilder presents to the emergency department with weakness of her right arm. The patient states she has experienced these symptoms for a few weeks; however, today her hand felt so weak she dropped her cup of tea. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes. She drinks 2-7 alcoholic drinks per day and has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes per day since she was 25. The patient admits to using anabolic steroids. She has lost 17 pounds since she last came to the emergency department 1 month ago. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 177/108 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals decreased sensation in the right arm and 2/5 strength in the right arm and 5/5 strength in in the left arm. The patient states that she is experiencing a dull aching and burning pain in her right arm during the exam. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old woman presents to the physician with fever, cough, weakness, night sweats, and poor appetite for the past 6 months. Medical records suggest that she has lost 7.5 kg (16.5 lb) of weight during this period. There is no history of breathlessness, nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, palpitations, chest pain, or symptoms related to digestion. She was released from prison 9 months ago after serving a 2-year sentence. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hepatomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy, and auscultation of the chest reveals diffuse crackles throughout the lung fields bilaterally. On direct ophthalmoscopy, three discrete, yellow-colored, 0.5 mm to 1.0 mm lesions with indistinct borders are seen in the posterior pole. A chest X-ray is shown in the image. Tuberculin skin test with purified protein derivative is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman is brought by her husband with a complaint of an ongoing progressive history of memory problems for 6 months. She is an accountant by profession. She has difficulty remembering things and events, which has affected her job. She began using a diary to aid with remembering her agenda. Her husband also says that she has wet her pants multiple times in the past 2 months and she avoids going out. She has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Her past medical history is unremarkable. The vital signs include: blood pressure of 134/76 mm Hg, a pulse of 70 per minute, and a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). Her mini-mental state examination (MMSE) result is 22/30. Her extraocular movements are normal. The muscle tone and strength are normal in all 4 limbs. The sensory examination is unremarkable. She has an absent Romberg’s sign. She walks slowly, taking small steps, with feet wide apart as if her feet are stuck to the floor. The CT scan of the head is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis of the patient?

A 31-year-old woman is referred to a neurologist due to her gradually increasing eccentric behavior and involuntary movements, especially the movements of her arms and hands. She also has difficulty with her short-term memory. Past medical history is otherwise noncontributory. Her father had similar symptoms before she died but those symptoms started at the age of 33. Her blood pressure is 125/92 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F). Physical exam reveals involuntary writhing movements of hands, slow eye movements, and sporadic rigidity. The physician explains that this is an inherited disorder where the symptoms occur progressively at an earlier age than the parent and often with increased severity in the future generations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 51-year-old woman alcoholic presents to the emergency department with persistent vomiting. She was found vomiting forcefully next to an empty bottle of vodka. Her medical history is significant for Lyme disease, currently being treated with doxycycline. After a prolonged episode of retching, the patient begins choking and coughing forcefully in between bouts of chest pain in the ER. At this point, the patient is unable to communicate. The patient appears toxic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 90/68 mm Hg. A quick physical exam reveals fullness at the base of the neck and a crunching, rasping sound on auscultation of the chest. The attending physician orders an upright chest X-ray, showing free mediastinal air. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman presents with a large wound on her right lower leg that has been present for 6 months as shown in the picture. She has had chronically swollen legs for over 10 years. Her mother and brother had similar problems with their legs. She had a documented deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the affected leg 5 years earlier, but has no other past medical history. She has a blood pressure of 126/84 and heart rate of 62/min. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old college student presents with her parents for a follow-up appointment. She was recently diagnosed with schizophrenia and was started on risperidone approx. 2 months ago. She reports a significant improvement since the start of treatment. Her parents report that their son’s symptoms of delusions, hallucinations, and paranoid behavior have been ameliorated. On physical examination, the patient seems uncomfortable. She frequently fidgets and repeatedly crosses and uncrosses her legs. When asked if something is troubling him, she gets up and starts pacing. She says, “It’s always like this. I cannot sit still. It is frustrating.” What is the most likely diagnosis?

A baby is born after the 32nd gestational week by cesarean delivery. The mother suffered from gestational diabetes; however, he had no other pregnancy-related diseases and was otherwise healthy. The baby has a blood pressure of 100/58 mm Hg, heart rate of 104/min, and oxygen saturation of 88%. The child has tachypnea, subcostal and intercostal retractions, nasal flaring, and cyanosis. The cyanosis is responding well to initial administration of oxygen. The nasogastric tube was positioned without problems. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.E: Congenital heart anomaly with right-to-left shunt

question: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of blisters on his forearm that appeared 3 days ago. He also reports pain in his left cheek when eating and pain during sexual intercourse for the past week. He has not been sick for the past 6 months. He has started hiking in the woods on the weekends with his son a couple months ago but has been careful to avoid poison ivy. He has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. He recently started taking captopril and stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago. He has a family history of pernicious anemia and Graves' disease. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearm and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. The total body surface area involvement of the blisters is estimated to be 10%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with moderate right wrist pain after falling on his outstretched hand. He has numbness in the 3 medial digits. The patient has no known previous medical conditions. His family history is not pertinent, and he currently takes no medications. Physical examination shows his blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg, the respirations are 14/min, the pulse is 87/min, and the temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). When asked to make a fist, the patient is able to flex only the lateral 2 digits. Tapping the anterior portion of his wrist elicits tingling in the medial 3 digits. The patient is taken to get an X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient’s injury?

A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of generalized fatigue. On examination, she appears pale. She also has multiple pinpoint, red, nonblanching spots on her extremities. Her spleen is significantly enlarged. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 8.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 81,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 35,600/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows immature cells with large, prominent nucleoli and pink, elongated, needle-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of bizarre and agitated behavior for the last 6 weeks. She thinks that the NSA is spying on him and controlling her mind. Her husband reports that the patient has become withdrawn and at times depressed for the past 3 months. She lost her job because she stopped going to work 4 weeks ago. Since then, she has been working on an invention that will block people from being able to control her mind. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is confused and suspicious with marked psychomotor agitation. Her speech is disorganized and her affect is labile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and uneasiness. She says that symptoms onset acutely half an hour ago while she was watching television. She describes the pain as being 8/10 in intensity, sharp in character, localized to the center of the chest and retrosternal, and radiating to the back and shoulders. The patient denies any associated change in the pain with breathing or body position. She says she has associated nausea but denies any vomiting. She denies any recent history of fever, chills, or chronic cough. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus for which she takes lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, and metformin. She reports a 30-pack-year smoking history and has 1–2 alcoholic drinks during the weekend. Family history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and an ST elevation myocardial infarction in her father and paternal uncle. Her blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg in the right arm and 180/100 mm Hg in the left arm. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic. Cardiac exam reveals a grade 2/6 diastolic decrescendo murmur loudest over the left sternal border. Remainder of the physical examination is normal. The chest radiograph shows a widened mediastinum. The electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals non-specific ST segment and T wave changes. Intravenous morphine and beta-blockers are started. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 16-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of sudden-onset abdominal pain. She was playing football when her symptoms started. The patient’s past medical history is notable only for asthma. Social history is notable for unprotected sex with 4 women in the past month. Her temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 120/88 mmHg, pulse is 117/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is noted for a non-tender abdomen. Testicular exam reveals a right testicle which is elevated with a horizontal lie and the scrotum is neither swollen nor discolored. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea for 4 months. He describes his stools as greasy, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. During this time he has had a 6-kg (13.2-lb) weight loss. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. Physical examination shows pallor and cheilitis. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative and stool microscopy reveals no pathogens and no leukocytes. Analysis of a 24-hour stool sample shows 12 g of fat. The patient is asked to consume 25 g of d-xylose. Five hours later, its concentration is measured in urine at 2 g (N = > 4 g/5 h). The test is repeated after a two-week course of rifaximin, but the urinary concentration of d-xylose remains the same. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine

question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever, itchy rash, and generalized joint pain. The rash initially started in the antecubital and popliteal fossae and then spread to his trunk and distal extremities. One week ago, he was diagnosed with acute sinusitis and was started on amoxicillin. He has no history of adverse drug reactions and immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and multiple erythematous, annular plaques of variable sizes over his entire body. One of the lesions in the right popliteal fossa has an area of central clearing and the patient's mother reports that it has been present for over 24 hours. Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

question: A 7-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother, who notes that the way in which she plays has changed and that she has been limping, favoring her left leg. When asked, the patient states that her left knee hurts. She is afebrile and vital signs are stable. The patient is well nourished and meeting all developmental milestones. On physical examination, the knee has a full range of motion; however, passive motion elicits pain in the left hip. An X-ray is performed and reveals a flattened left femoral head. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of an aggressive cough with copious amounts of thick, foamy, yellow-green sputum. He says he has had this cough for about 11 years with exacerbations similar to his presentation today. He also reports that his cough is worse in the morning. He was evaluated multiple times in the past because of recurrent bouts of bronchitis that have required treatment with antibiotics. He is a non-smoker. On physical examination, the blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, pulse rate is 80/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). Chest auscultation reveals crackles and wheezing over the right middle lobe and the rest of his physical examinations are normal. The chest X-ray shows irregular opacities in the right middle lobe and diffuse airway thickening. Based on this history and physical examination, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of intermittent fever and loss of appetite for the past 2 weeks. He is also concerned about painful genital lesions. Past medical history is noncontributory. He takes oral contraceptives and a multivitamin daily. He has had two male sexual partners in his lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. He admits to being sexually active with 2 partners in the last 3 months and only using condoms on occasion. Today, his vitals are normal. On pelvic exam, there are red-rimmed, fluid-filled blisters over the labia minora (as seen in the photograph below) with swollen and tender inguinal lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 4-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of a generalized rash for 1 day. She was born at term. The mother had no prenatal care and has a history of gonorrhea, which was treated 4 years ago. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for head circumference, 60th percentile for length, and 55th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 152/min, and respirations are 51/min. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules with an erythematous base over the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with weakness. He states that at the end of the day he feels so fatigued and weak that he can hardly care for herself. He currently feels this way. The patient has had multiple illnesses recently and has been traveling, hiking, and camping. His temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 124/84 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for 2/5 strength of the upper extremities and 4/5 strength of the lower extremities. Visual exam is notable for mild diplopia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 18-year-old female is seen for a routine physical prior to starting college. She will be moving from Ohio to California, away from her family for the first time. Her temperature is 36.8 deg C (98.2 deg F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 122/68 mmHg. BMI is 24. On questioning, she reveals that she has a habit of binge eating during times of stress, particularly during exams. She then feels guilty about her behavior and attempts to compensate by going to the gym, sometimes for 4+ hours per day. She is disturbed by this behavior and feels out of control. She denies ever vomiting as a means of loosing weight. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her host parents for evaluation of a progressively pruritic rash over her shoulders and buttocks for the past 6 months. She recently came to the United States from Nigeria to attend a year of high school. She reports that it has been increasingly difficult for him to read the whiteboard during classes. Physical examination shows symmetrically distributed papules 4–8 mm in diameter, excoriation marks, and patchy hyperpigmentation over her shoulders, waist, and buttocks. There is nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy and several firm, nontender subcutaneous nodules along the right iliac crest. Six skin snip biopsies are taken from the pelvic girdle, buttocks, and thigh, and are then incubated in saline. After 24 hours, microscopic examination shows motile microfilariae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic because of persistent sinus infections. For the past 5 years, she has had multiple sinus and upper respiratory infections. She has also had recurrent diarrhea throughout childhood. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), the heart rate is 90/min, the respirations are 16/min, and the blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show abnormally low levels of one immunoglobulin isotype but normal levels of others. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his neighbors 30 minutes after they found his unconscious in his yard. His neighbors report that he has been spending more time at home by herself because he recently lost his job. On arrival, he is unable to provide a history. He appears anxious. His pulse is 76/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination shows significant weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. He is unable to plantarflex the ankle while supine. He is able to stand on his toes. His gait is unsteady. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ and symmetric. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain and MR angiography show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old man presents with his wife because of left leg pain and swelling of 3 days’ duration. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and recent hospitalization for congestive heart failure exacerbation. On physical examination, the left calf is 4 cm greater in circumference than the right. Pitting edema is present on the left leg and there are superficial dilated veins. Venous duplex ultrasound shows an inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches and blurry vision for the past 6 months. She also reports frequent episodes of vomiting over the last month. Her father has died of renal cell carcinoma at the age of 37 years. Examination shows 20/40 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling and growth of capillary vessels in the temporal peripheral retina. An MRI of the brain shows an infratentorial mass. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old man is hospitalized due to depression and suicidal ideation. He has a 5-year history of chaotic relationships that last only a few short weeks or months. Each relationship has left his feeling abandoned, empty, and extremely upset. During these periods, the patient confesses to shopping and making big purchases on impulse. He says he gets bored easily and moves on to the next adventure. The patient denies any changes in appetite, energy level, or concentration. On examination, multiple linear lacerations of varying phases of healing were noted on his forearms and trunk. Following consultation, he praises physicians to be ‘the best people on the planet’, but when the nurse came in to take his blood, he furiously stated that ‘all nurses are incompetent and cruel’. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden loss of vision in his right eye that occurred 50 minutes ago. He does not have eye pain. He had several episodes of loss of vision in the past, but his vision improved following treatment with glucocorticoids. He has coronary artery disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and multiple sclerosis. He underwent a left carotid endarterectomy 3 years ago. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, metformin, glipizide, and weekly intramuscular beta-interferon injections. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/88 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. The direct pupillary reflex is brisk in the left eye and absent in the right eye. The indirect pupillary reflex is brisk in the right eye but absent in the left eye. Intraocular pressure is 18 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye. A white, 1-mm ring is seen around the circumference of the cornea in both eyes. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Fundoscopic examination of the left eye shows a few soft and hard exudates in the superior and nasal retinal quadrants. The optic disc and macula appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain, 35 minutes after she was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. She was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. On arrival, she is alert and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale rating of 14. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over her abdomen and extremities. There is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Bowel sounds are normal. Her hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,110/mm3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy with previously diagnosed sickle cell anemia presents to the emergency room with a low-grade fever, malaise, petechiae on his arms, and a rash on his face. He regularly takes hydroxyurea and receives blood transfusions to treat his condition. His blood tests show a hemoglobin of 4.0 g/dL, MCV of 87 fl, and 2% reticulocyte count. An attempted bone marrow biopsy was  a dry, empty tap. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 13-year-old boy re-presents to her pediatrician with a new onset rash that began a few days after her initial visit. She initially presented with complaints of sore throat but was found to have a negative strep test. Her mother demanded that she be placed on antibiotics, but this was refused by her pediatrician. The boy's father, a neurologist, therefore, started him on penicillin. Shortly after starting the drug, the boy developed a fever and a rash. The patient is admitted and her symptoms worsen. Her skin begins to slough off, and the rash covers over 30% of her body. Her oropharynx and corneal membranes are also affected. You examine him at the bedside and note a positive Nikolsky's sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and discomfort for the past 3 days. He was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) a couple of years ago, managed until recently with imipramine, psyllium, and loperamide. 5 days ago, because he had developed alternating diarrhea and constipation, bloating, and abdominal pain on his medication, he was started on alosetron. His current temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), the heart rate is 115/min, the blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 22/min. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with guarding but no rebound. Bowel sounds are hypoactive on auscultation. A fecal occult blood test is positive and laboratory tests show his white cell count to be 15,800/µL. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals a metabolic acidosis Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 12-year-old boy presents to the pediatric dermatologist with an expanding, but otherwise asymptomatic erythematous patch on his right shoulder, which he first noticed 3 days ago. The boy states the rash started as a small red bump but has gradually progressed to its current size. No similar lesions were observed elsewhere by his or his mother. He has felt ill and his mother has detected intermittent low-grade fevers. During the skin examination, a target-like erythematous patch, approximately 7 cm in diameter, was noted on the left shoulder (as shown in the image). Another notable finding was axillary lymphadenopathy. On further questioning it was revealed that the patient went camping with his grandfather approximately 11 days ago; however, he does not recall any insect bites or exposure to animals. The family has a pet cat living in their household. Based on the history and physical examination results, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a wellness checkup. The patient states she has been doing well and currently has no concerns. The patient's daughter states that she feels she is abnormally fatigued and has complained of light-headedness whenever she gardens. She also admits that she fainted once. The patient has a past medical history of type II diabetes, hypertension, and constipation. She recently had a "throat cold" that she recovered from with rest and fluids. Her temperature is 98.9°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 167/98 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam reveals a systolic murmur heard best along the right upper sternal border. An ECG is performed and demonstrates no signs of ST elevation. Cardiac troponins are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 21 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician for a follow-up prenatal visit. At his previous appointment, his serum α-fetoprotein concentration was elevated. He had smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 3 years but quit at 6 weeks' gestation. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 21-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows fetal viscera suspended freely into the amniotic cavity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with heavy drooling. The patient was being watched by her babysitter when she found him in this manner. Her temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 119/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.
