Physical exam is notable for a young boy in acute distress who is drooling. The boy states she is in pain and can’t swallow. The patient’s tongue seems abnormally enlarged and erythematous. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a severe headache. The patient has had headaches in the past, but he describes this as the worst headache of his life. His symptoms started yesterday and have been getting progressively worse. The patient states that the pain is mostly on one side of his head. There has been a recent outbreak of measles at the patient’s school, and the patient’s mother has been trying to give his daughter medicine to prevent his from getting sick, but the mother fears that his daughter may have caught the measles. On physical exam, you note an obese young boy who is clutching his head with the light in the room turned off. His neurological exam is within normal limits. Fundoscopic exam reveals mild bilateral papilledema. A MRI of the head is obtained and reveals cerebral edema. A lumbar puncture reveals an increased opening pressure with a normal glucose level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 56-year-old man comes to the family physician for a 1-month history of sleep disturbance and sadness. The symptoms have been occurring since his wife died in a car accident. Before eventually falling asleep, he stays awake for multiple hours and has crying spells. Several times he has been woken up by the sound of his wife calling his name. He has lost 3 kg (6.6 lb) over the past month. He has 3 children with whom he still keeps regular contact and regularly attends church services with his friends. He expresses feeling a great feeling of loss over the death of his wife. He has no suicidal ideation. He is alert and oriented. Neurological exam shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?

A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of tinnitus and progressive hearing loss in the left ear. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and Raynaud syndrome. His current medications include metformin, nifedipine, and a multivitamin. He appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Immediately after the patient does not hear a tone, the tuning fork is held over the left ear and he reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the right side and shows the same pattern. The vibration tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound louder in the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man is brought to a psychiatrist’s office by his wife who states that he is worried about his recent behavior, as it has become more violent. The patient’s wife states that his family drove across the country to visit them and that his wife ‘threatened his parents with a knife’ at dinner last night. Police had to be called to calm his down. He states that he has been acting ‘really crazy’ for the last 9 months, and the initial behavior that caused him alarm was his admission that his deceased sister was talking to his through a decorative piece of ceramic art in the living room. Initially, he thought he was joking, but soon realized his complaints of ‘hearing ghosts’ talking to his throughout the house were persisting and ‘getting worse’. There was also a 4-week period where he experienced insomnia and an unintentional weight loss of 12 pounds. He seemed sad throughout these episodes, and, according to his wife, was complaining of feeling ‘worthless’. His general hygiene has also suffered from his recent lack of motivation and he insists that the ‘ghosts’ are asking his to kill as many people as he can so they won’t be alone in the house. His wife is extremely concerned that he may harm herself or someone else. He states that he currently does not take any medications or illicit drugs as far as he knows. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. The patient herself does not make eye contact or want to speak to the psychiatrist, allowing his wife to speak on his behalf. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of malaise, dysuria, blurred vision, and a painful, itchy rash. The rash began on his chest and face and spread to his limbs, palms, and soles. One week ago, he was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on a new medicine. He appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and ulceration on the tongue and palate. There is no lymphadenopathy. Examination of the skin shows confluent annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles. The epidermis separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for knee pain. The pain started yesterday and has not improved since then. The patient is generally in good health. He attends college and plays soccer for his school's team. Three days ago, he was slide tackled during a game and his leg was struck from the outside. He fell to the ground and sat out for the rest of the game. It was not until yesterday that he noticed swelling in his knee. He also feels as if his knee is unstable and does not feel confident bearing weight on his leg during athletic activities. His past medical history is notable for asthma, which is currently treated with an albuterol inhaler. On physical exam, you note bruising over his leg, knee, and lateral thigh, and edema of his knee. Passive range of motion of the knee is notable only for minor clicking and catching of the joint. The patient's gait appears normal, though the patient states that his injured knee does not feel stable. Further physical exam is performed and imaging is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 43-year-old Caucasian male with a long history of uncontrolled migraines presents to general medical clinic with painless hematuria. He is quite concerned because he has never had symptoms like this before. Vital signs are stable, and his physical examination is benign. He denies any groin pain, flank pain, or costovertebral angle tenderness. He denies any recent urinary tract infections or dysuria. Urinary analysis confirms hematuria and a serum creatinine returns at 3.0. A renal biopsy reveals papillary necrosis and a tubulointerstitial infiltrate. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 54-year-old man presents to his primary care physician complaining of watery diarrhea for the last 3 weeks. He reports now having over 10 bowel movements per day. He denies abdominal pain or rash. A basic metabolic profile is notable for the following: Na: 127 mEq/L; K 2.1 mEq/L; Glucose 98 mg/dL. Following additional work-up, octreotide was started with significant improvement in symptoms and laboratory values. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl presents with a history of recurrent bacterial infections, including several episodes of pneumococcal sepsis. Her 2 maternal uncles died after having had similar complaints. Lab investigations reveal an undetectable level of all serum immunoglobulins. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents who are concerned that he is not developing normally. They say he does not talk and avoids eye contact. He prefers to sit and play with blocks by herself rather than engaging with other children. They also note that he will occasionally have violent outbursts in inappropriate situations. He is otherwise healthy. In the office, the patient sits quietly in the corner of the room stacking and unstacking blocks. Examination of the patient shows a well-developed female with no physical abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and nocturnal cough for the past 2 weeks. On two occasions, her cough was bloody. She had a heart condition as a child that was treated with antibiotics. She emigrated to the US from Kazakhstan 15 years ago. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 61-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent fever, easy fatiguability, and a 4.4-kg (9.7-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. The spleen is palpated 5 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 75,300/mm3 with increased basophils, a platelet count of 455,000/mm3, and a decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score. A peripheral blood smear shows increased numbers of promyelocytes, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because he is worried about gaining weight. He reports that at least twice a week, he eats excessive amounts of food but feels ashamed about losing control soon after. He is very active in his high school's tennis team and goes running daily to lose weight. He has a history of cutting his forearms with the metal tab from a soda can. His last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 57 kg (125 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination shows enlarged, firm parotid glands bilaterally. There are erosions of the enamel on the lingual surfaces of the teeth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of lower back pain that began suddenly 2 weeks ago after getting up from his chair. He has hypertension, chronic bilateral knee pain, and a history of breast cancer 15 years ago that was treated with lumpectomy. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Medications include hydrochlorothiazide and acetaminophen. He appears well. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the lower spine. Both knees are enlarged and swollen. Neurologic examination shows sensorineural hearing impairment of the left ear. His gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is 30 U/L (N: 0–30 U/L), alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is 310 U/L, and serum calcium is 10.2 mg/dL. A spinal x-ray shows a fracture in the L4 vertebra. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of right-sided blurry vision and eye pain for 4 days. He has a 6-day history of low-grade fever, headache, and malaise. One year ago, he was diagnosed with Crohn disease. His only medication is prednisone. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 112/75 mm Hg. The right eyelid is erythematous and tender; there are multiple vesicles over the right forehead and the tip of the nose. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/80 in the right eye. Extraocular movements are normal. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and reduced corneal sensitivity. Fluorescein staining shows a corneal lesion with a tree-like pattern. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a follow-up appointment. The patient was the front seat driver in a head-on collision which resulted in a femur and pelvic fracture which was treated appropriately. The patient spent 3 weeks in the hospital and was then discharged 2 weeks ago. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. She smokes 3 packs of cigarettes per day and drinks 4 alcoholic beverages every night. The patient says that she has been attempting to engage in sexual activities with her husband but has been unable to do so. She states this has never been a problem for him before. She also reports new-onset minor headaches and trouble sleeping for which she is taking trazodone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of malaise, dyspnea, and yellow skin and sclera. On examination, she is tachycardic, tachypneic, and the O2 saturation is less than 90%. The levels of unconjugated bilirubin and hemoglobinemia are increased, and there is an increased number of reticulocytes in the peripheral blood. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old girl is brought to the family physician by her parents. They are concerned that she has had multiple nosebleeds in the last 6 months and is always sick compared to other children. During this time period they have also noticed the formation of multiple bruises on her extremities and dry-itching skin on her hands, feet and elbow. On physical exam the physician notes moderate splenomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis in this child?

A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 30 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department because of progressive upper abdominal pain for the past hour. The patient vomited once on his way to the hospital. He states that he initially had dull stomach pain about 6 hours ago, but now the pain is located in the upper abdomen and is more severe. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is sexually active with his wife. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3. Urinalysis shows mild pyuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old construction worker presents to her primary care physician with a painful and swollen wrist joint. A joint aspiration shows crystals, which are shown in the accompanying picture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath for the past two weeks. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds at both lung bases. The abdomen is distended and there is shifting dullness with a positive fluid wave. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a large collection of peritoneal fluid and a hypoechoic mass involving the left ovary. Microscopic examination of a biopsy specimen from the ovarian mass shows clusters of spindle-shaped cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old man presents with convulsions. The patient’s brother says that he found his like that an hour ago and immediately called an ambulance. He also says that he has been extremely distraught and receiving supportive care from a social worker following a sexual assault by a coworker a few days ago. He says that the patient has no history of seizures. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. The patient’s vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 101/min, blood pressure 135/99 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 25/min. On physical examination, the patient is rolling from side to side, arrhythmically thrashing around, and muttering strangely. His eyes are closed, and there is resistance to opening them. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Thirty minutes after delivery, a 3400-g (7.5-lb) female newborn develops cyanosis of his lips and oral mucosa. He was born at 36 weeks of gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Examination shows foaming and drooling at the mouth. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. There is a harsh 3/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and mildly distended. There is an anterior ectopic anus. Insertion of a nasogastric tube is attempted. An x-ray of the chest and abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
answer: Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula to the distal esophageal segment

options.A: Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula to the proximal esophageal segment
options.B: H‑type tracheoesophageal fistula without esophageal atresia
options.C: Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula to the distal esophageal segment
options.D: Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula to the proximal and distal esophageal segments

question: A 35-year-old man presents to his family doctor worried that he might have a heart condition. For the past 7 months, he has been having short panic attacks where he feels short of breath, sweaty, and feels like his heart wants to jump out his chest. During these attacks, he feels like he ‘is going crazy’. He has now mapped out all of the places he has had an attack such as the subway, the crowded pharmacy near his house, and an elevator at his work that is especially slow and poorly lit. He actively avoids these areas to prevent an additional episode. He is afraid that during these attacks he may not be able to get the help he needs or escape if needed. No significant past medical history. The patient takes no current medications. His grandfather died of a heart attack at the age of 70 and he is worried that it might run in the family. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory results are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient’s condition?

A 39-year-old man presents to your office with 4 days of fever, sore throat, generalized aching, arthralgias, and tender nodules on both of his shins that arose in the last 48 hours. His medical history is negative for disease and he does not take oral contraceptives or any other medication regularly. The physical examination reveals the vital signs that include body temperature 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate 85/min, blood pressure 120/65 mm Hg, tender and enlarged submandibular lymph nodes, and an erythematous, edematous, and swollen pharynx with enlarged tonsils and a patchy white exudate on the surface. He is not pregnant. Examination of the lower limbs reveals erythematous, tender, immobile nodules on both shins. You do not identify ulcers or similar lesions on other areas of his body. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 23-year-old female presents to her primary care physician after an injury during a rugby game. The patient states that she was tackled and ever since then has had pain in her knee. The patient has tried NSAIDs and ice to no avail. The patient has no past medical history and is currently taking a multivitamin, fish oil, and a whey protein supplement. On physical exam you note a knee that is heavily bruised. It is painful for the patient to bear weight on the knee, and passive motion of the knee elicits some pain. There is laxity at the knee to varus stress. The patient is wondering when she can return to athletics. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by her foster mother because of complaints from her teachers regarding poor performance at school for the past 8 months. She does not listen to their instructions, often talks during class, and rarely completes her school assignments. She does not sit in her seat in the classroom and often cuts in line at the cafeteria. Her foster mother reports that she runs around a lot inside the house and refuses to help her sister with chores and errands. She frequently interrupts her foster mother's conversations with others and talks excessively. She has found him trying to climb on the roof on multiple occasions. She was placed in foster care because of neglect by her biological parents 3 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Mental status examination shows a neutral affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old boy is brought to a clinic with complaints of fever and sore throat for 2 days. This morning, he developed a rash on his face and neck which is progressing towards the trunk. The teachers in his school report that none of his classmates has similar symptoms. He has a normal birth history. On physical examination, the child looks healthy. The heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. An oropharyngeal examination reveals circumoral pallor with a red tongue, as shown in the photograph below. The chest and cardiac examinations are within normal limits. No hepatosplenomegaly is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of 2 episodes of screaming in the night over the past week. The parents report that their son woke up suddenly screaming, crying, and aggressively kicking her legs around both times. The episodes lasted several minutes and were accompanied by sweating and fast breathing. The parents state that they were unable to stop the episodes and that their son simply went back to sleep when the episodes were over. The patient cannot recall any details of these incidents. She has a history of obstructive sleep apnea. She takes no medications. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after a below-knee amputation of the right lower leg. Three weeks ago, she had an acute arterial embolism that could not be revascularized in time to save the leg. She now reports episodic hot, shooting, and tingling pain in the right lower leg that began shortly after the amputation. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Her current medications are metformin and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a slightly erythematous stump with clean sutures. The skin overlying the stump is warm and well-perfused. Muscle strength and sensation are normal throughout the remaining extremity and the left lower extremity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old African American man comes to the emergency department with intermittent and progressively worsening dizziness with near-fainting incidents for the last 3 weeks. He denies fever, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, or chest pain. His medical history is significant for a chronic cough and intermittent skin rashes that spontaneously resolved after a few weeks. He does not smoke tobacco but drinks alcohol socially. The patient lives alone with no pets. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg, pulse is 43/min, and respirations are 12/min. On physical examination, cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. No heart murmurs are heard. ECG shows sinus rhythm with 2:1 atrioventricular block and left bundle branch block. Chest X-ray shows prominent hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of painless lesions on her face that she has had since shortly after birth. They recently moved to the USA from Indonesia where they had limited access to healthcare. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for 2 days of severe headaches. The pain is most intense on her left forehead and eye. She had similar symptoms last summer. She has been taking indomethacin every 6 hours for the last 24 hours but has not had any relief. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 5 years. She works as an accountant and describes her work as very stressful. Physical examination shows drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea. The left pupil is 2 mm and the right pupil is 4 mm. There is localized tenderness along the right supraspinatus muscle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a seizure. Her husband reports that the patient has been having recurrent headaches and has become increasingly irritable over the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a spastic paresis of the right lower extremity. The Babinski sign is present on the right side. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath and a productive cough for 3 days. She sustained trauma to the right hemithorax during a fight 3 weeks ago. She had significant pain and mild shortness of breath following the incident but did not seek medical care. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is a construction worker. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung fields. CT scan of the chest shows fractures of the right 7th and 8th ribs, right pleural splitting and thickening, and a dense fluid collection in the pleural space. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old boy presents after suffering a tonic-clonic seizure. She says it had a duration of 2 minutes and a postictal period of 10 minutes. Patient denies any similar episodes in the past. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for her mother and older brother who died of colorectal cancer at ages 40 and 20, respectively. On physical examination, the patient is drowsy but arousable and responsive to commands. Both pupils are symmetrical and responsive to light. An MRI of the brain reveals an infratentorial hypointense cerebellar mass with a small cystic area. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of diffuse muscle pain, malaise, pain in both knees, recurrent episodes of abdominal and chest pain. She has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. Four years ago, she was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection and was started on tenofovir. There are several ulcerations around the ankle and calves bilaterally. Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are negative. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Muscle biopsy shows a transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman who was recently placed on TMP-SMX for a urinary tract infection presents to urgent care with a new rash. The vital signs include: blood pressure 121/80 mm Hg, pulse 91/min, respiratory rate 18/min, and temperature 36.7°C (98.2°F). Physical examination reveals a desquamative skin covering both of her lower extremities. A basic chemistry panel reveal sodium 139 mmol/L, potassium 3.8 mmol/L, chloride 110 mmol/L, carbon dioxide 47, blood urea nitrogen 23 mg/dL, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL, and glucose 103 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old woman presents to the physician with fever and malaise for 4 days. She has headaches and joint pain. A pruritic rash appeared on the trunk yesterday. She had blood in her ejaculate twice. Her hearing has become partially impaired. There is no history of serious illnesses or the use of medications. Ten days ago, she traveled to Brazil where she spent most of the time outdoors in the evenings. She did not use any control measures for mosquito bites. Her temperature is 38.2℃ (100.8℉); the pulse is 88/min; the respiratory rate is 13/min, and the blood pressure is 125/60 mm Hg. Conjunctival suffusion is noted. A maculopapular rash is present over the trunk and proximal extremities without the involvement of the palms or soles. Several joints of the hands are tender to palpation. The abdomen is soft with no organomegaly. A peripheral blood smear shows no pathogenic organisms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent lower abdominal cramps associated with diarrhea, bloating, and mild nausea. During this period, he has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He feels like he cannot fully empty his bowels. He has no history of serious illness. He has a high-fiber diet. His father is of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. He appears well. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,000 mm3, platelet count is 480,000 mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 129 mm/h. A barium enema shows ulceration and narrowing of the right colon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old girl with behavioral changes is brought in by her concerned parents. The patient’s parents say that she has been acting very odd and having difficulty academically for the past 4 months. The patient says that she has been worried and distracted because she is certain the government is secretly recording him although she cannot provide a reason why. She mentions that she does feel depressed sometimes and no longer gets joy out of playing the guitar and her other previous activities. She has no significant past medical history. The patient denies any history of smoking, alcohol consumption, or recreational drug use. She is afebrile, and her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. On mental status examination, the patient is slightly disheveled and unkempt. She has a disorganized monotonous speech pattern. She expresses tangential thinking and has a flat affect. During the exam, it is clear that she suffers from auditory hallucinations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right-sided painless scrotal swelling that she noticed yesterday while taking a shower. She is currently sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She immigrated to the US from Argentina 2 years ago. Her immunization records are unavailable. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 5 years. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 24.2 kg/m2. She appears healthy and well nourished. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft with dull lower abdominal discomfort. Testicular examination shows a solid mass in the right testis that is firm and nontender. A light held behind the scrotum does not shine through. The mass is not reduced when the patient is in a supine position. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 70-year-old woman is at her dermatologist’s office for the treatment of a severely pruritic erythroderma with scaling on her buttocks that has been slowly progressing over the past two weeks. The patient works as a truck driver and has a history of hypertension treated with enalapril. The patient reports having tried an over-the-counter cream on the rash without improvement. The vital signs are within normal range. On physical exam, she has multiple confluent and well-demarcated pink patches on her buttocks and legs with some scaling and enlarged inguinal lymph nodes. The dermatologist orders a skin biopsy that reveals Pautrier microabscesses. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a mass in the left breast that he first noticed 2 weeks ago. During this period, the mass has not increased in size and the patient has had no pain. Three months ago, he hit his left chest against the closet door, which was painful for a day. Menses occurs at regular 28-day intervals and last for 5 days with moderate flow. His last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm well-defined, rubbery, mobile mass that is nontender in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no axillary adenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of oligomenorrhea and intermittent vaginal spotting for 5 months. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals and lasted for 5 days with normal flow. He has also noted increased hair growth on his chin. He is not sexually active. He takes no medications. Physical examination shows temporal hair recession and nodulocystic acne on his cheeks and forehead. There is coarse hair on the chin and the upper lip. Pelvic examination shows clitoral enlargement and a right adnexal mass. Laboratory studies show increased serum testosterone concentration; serum concentrations of androstenedione and dehydroepiandrosterone are within the reference ranges. Ultrasonography of the pelvis shows a 10-cm right ovarian tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old woman comes to the military base physician for evaluation of progressive discomfort in her right shoulder for the past 4 months. She joined the military 6 months ago and is part of a drill team. In anticipation of an upcoming competition, she has been practicing rifle drills and firing exercises 8 hours a day. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation and a firm mass in the superior part of the right deltopectoral groove. Range of motion is limited by pain and stiffness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 53-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her son for the evaluation of unusual behavior. She is a shopkeeper by profession and sometimes behaves very rudely to the customers. Recently, she accused one of the customers of using black magic over her shop. She has been increasingly irritable, forgetting things, and having problems managing her finances over the past 8 months. She is also having difficulty finding words and recalling the names of objects during the conversation. There is no history of recent head trauma, fever, hallucinations, or abnormal limb movements. Past medical history is significant for a well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Family history is unremarkable. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are stable with a blood pressure of 134/76 mm Hg, a heart rate of 88/min, and a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, she has problems naming objects and planning tasks. Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score is 26/30. Cranial nerve examination is normal. Muscle strength is normal in all 4 limbs with normal muscle tone and deep tendon reflexes. Sensory examination is also normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room by her mother for weakness, diaphoresis, and syncope. Her mother says that she has never been diagnosed with any medical conditions but has been having “fainting spells” over the past month. Routine lab work reveals a glucose level of 25 mg/dL. The patient is promptly given glucagon and intravenous dextrose and admitted to the hospital for observation. The patient’s mother stays with him during her hospitalization. The patient is successfully watched overnight and her blood glucose levels normalize on her morning levels. The care team discusses a possible discharge during morning rounds. One hour later the nurse is called in for a repeat fainting episode. A c-peptide level is drawn and shown to be low. The patient appears ill, diaphoretic, and is barely arousable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?

A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive left flank pain and increased urinary frequency for the past two weeks. His appetite is normal and he has not had any nausea or vomiting. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus that is poorly controlled with insulin. He is sexually active with his boyfriend, and they use condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 38° C (100.4° F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant; there is no guarding or rebound. There is tenderness to percussion along the left flank. He complains of pain when his left hip is passively extended. His leukocyte count is 16,000/mm3 and urine pregnancy test is negative. Urinalysis shows 3+ glucose. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of an intermittent, diffuse abdominal pain. He has also had a nonpruritic rash on his legs and swelling of his ankles for 1 week. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat, which was treated with oral amoxicillin. Examination of the lower extremities shows non-blanching, raised erythematous papules. The ankle joints are swollen and warm, and their range of motion is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 450,000/mm3. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband due to unusual behavior for the past week. She has noted several incidents when she spoke to her so fast that she could not understand what she was saying. She also says that one evening, she drove home naked after a night where she said she was ‘painting the town red’. She also says she has also been sleeping for about 2 hours a night and has barely had any sleep in the past 2 weeks. She says that she goes ‘to work’ in the morning every day, but she suspects that she has been doing other things. She denies any knowledge of similar symptoms in the past. On physical examination, the patient appears agitated and is pacing the exam room. She compliments the cleanliness of the floors, recommends the hospital change to the metric system, and asks if anyone else can hear ‘that ringing’. Laboratory results are unremarkable. The patient denies any suicidal or homicidal ideations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 67-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of headaches in his left temple and scalp area, neck stiffness, occasional blurred vision, and pain in his jaw when chewing. The appropriate medical therapy is initiated, and a subsequent biopsy of the temporal artery reveals arteritis. Five months later, the patient returns to his physician with a complaint of weakness, leading to difficulty climbing stairs, rising from a chair, and combing his hair. The patient states that this weakness has worsened gradually over the last 2 months. He reports that his headaches, jaw pain, and visual disturbances have resolved. Physical examination is significant for 4/5 strength for both hip flexion/extension as well as shoulder flexion/extension/abduction. Initial laboratory work-up reveals ESR and creatine kinase levels within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient's current presentation?

A 27-year-old man presents to your office complaining of difficulty swallowing, and he describes that "there is something in the back of his throat". Furthermore, he also feels an "achy" chest pain that has been getting progressively worse over the last few weeks. He denies having any fever, shortness of breath, cough, abdominal pain, heartburn, nausea, or vomiting. The patient has a history of wrist fracture as a child, migraines, and a recent diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for the evaluation of recent-onset seizures. He has had 2 episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures in the past 3 days. Each episode lasted for 1–2 minutes and aborted spontaneously. There is no history of fever, headache, altered behavior, diarrhea, vomiting, or previous seizure episodes. Past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals: blood pressure 102/64 mm Hg, heart rate 89/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). He looks anxious but oriented to time and space. Multiple flat hyperpigmented spots are present over his body, each more than 5 mm in diameter. Axillary freckling is present. Cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength is normal in all 4 limbs with a normal sensory examination. Gait is normal. An eye examination is shown in the exhibit. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man presents complaining of nightmares. He reports that these “nightmares” happen when he is asleep and also sometimes when he is awake, but he cannot come up with another description for them. The episodes have been happening for at least 3 weeks now. He states that when it happens he feels “outside of his body,” like she’s “watching myself.” He also reports some chronic fatigue. The patient denies headaches, vision changes, dizziness, or loss in sensation or motor function. He has no notable medical or surgical history. He takes a multivitamin every day. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes a day but denies alcohol or illicit drug use. The patient appears slightly anxious but is in no acute distress. A physical and neurological exam is normal. He denies suicidal or homicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the patient’s symptoms?

A 19-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by her roommates after being found unconscious on their dorm room floor. Her temperature is 102.0°F (38.9°C) and blood pressure is 85/64 mmHg. On physical examination, she has multiple rose-colored spots on the skin covering her abdomen and lower limbs. Lab tests reveal hyperkalemia and an arterial blood gas test that reads pH: 7.04, pCO2: 30.1 mmHg, pO2: 23.4 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient’s condition?

A 24-year-old man at 6 weeks gestation seeks evaluation at a local walk-in clinic because he has noticed a clear, sticky discharge from his right nipple for the past 1 week. The discharge leaves a pink stain on his bra. He does not have pain in his breasts and denies changes in skin color or nipple shape. The past medical history is significant for a major depressive disorder, for which he takes fluoxetine. The family history is negative for breast, endometrial, and ovarian cancers. The physical examination is unremarkable. There are no palpable masses or tenderness on breast exam and no skin discoloration or ulcers. The breasts are symmetric. The nipple discharge on the right side is a pink secretion that is sticky. There are no secretions on the left. The axillary lymph nodes are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the physician because his left breast has become larger, hot, and itchy over the past 2 months. The patient felt a small lump in his left breast 1 year ago but did not seek medical attention at that time. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Menarche was at the age of 11 years and menopause at the age of 46 years. His mother died of breast cancer at the age of 45 years. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include labetalol, simvastatin, and daily low-dose aspirin. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 78 kg (172 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 138/88 mm Hg. Examination shows large dense breasts. There is widespread erythema and edematous skin plaques over a breast mass in the left breast. The left breast is tender to touch and left-sided axillary lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 61-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of fatigue and feeling sad. He reports that ever since his wife passed away 3 months ago, he has noticed a decrease in his energy level and reports frequently awaking at 2 in the morning and cannot fall back asleep. He sometimes wakes up and hears his wife's voice, constantly thinks about how much he misses him, and has recently thought about ways to kill herself including driving through a red light. He used to be an active member of his neighborhood’s bridge club but has stopped playing. He has lost 15 pounds and rarely feels hungry. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by police officers because she was seen acting strangely in public. The patient was found talking nonsensically to the characters on cereal boxes in a grocery store. Past medical history is significant for multiple hospitalizations for alcohol-related injuries and alcohol withdrawal seizures. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is disheveled and oriented x1. Neurologic examination shows horizontal nystagmus and severe ataxia is also noted, that after interviewing the patient, she forgets the face of persons and the questions asked shortly after she walks out the door. He, however, remembers events from her distant past quite well. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 14-year-old female of eastern European descent presents to the free clinic at a university hospital for a respiratory infection, which her mother explains occurs quite frequently. The female is noted to be of short stature, have a gargoyle-like facies, clouded corneas, poor dentition, and is severely mentally retarded. A urinalysis revealed large amounts of heparan and dermatan sulfate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a follow-up examination. He has a history of recurrent asthma attacks. The mother reports that his daughter has also had mild abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. The patient's current medications include daily inhaled fluticasone and inhaled albuterol as needed. He appears well. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Abdominal examination shows a left-sided, nontender, smooth abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old boy is brought into the clinic by his mother who is concerned that he may be depressed. The mother states that his daughter feels unattractive and does not fit into any of the social groups at school. When talking to the patient, it is discovered that he mostly avoids the kids in school because of fear of rejection. He usually keeps to herself and says he hasn’t involved herself in any group activities since elementary school. The patient’s mother is worried that this kind of behavior might continue or worsen if it progresses into his college years. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status for 2 hours. He and his wife were at the grocery store when he suddenly could not remember why he was there or how he got there. He has not had any head trauma. He has a history of depression and migraines. He does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine each night with dinner. He takes fluoxetine daily. He appears distressed and anxious. His vital signs are within normal limits. He is fully alert and oriented to self and place but not to time. Every few minutes he asks how he got to the emergency department. He is able to follow commands and sustain attention. He recalls 3/3 objects immediately and recalls 0/3 objects at 5 minutes. The remainder of the neurological exam shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with anxiety and trouble swallowing. She states that her symptoms have slowly been getting worse over the past year, and she now struggles to swallow liquids. She recently recovered from the flu. Review of systems is notable only for recent weight loss. The patient has a 33 pack-year smoking history and is a former alcoholic. Physical exam is notable for poor dental hygiene and foul breath. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old man has complaints of dyspnea, cough, and arthritis in his ankle joints. A CT scan reveals multiples granulomas in both lungs, as well as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. On examination, cutaneous nodules over the trunk are found. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate, angiotensin-converting enzyme, and serum calcium levels are elevated. He is treated with steroids. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-year-old boy comes to the physician with his mother because of a 2-day history of passing “cola-colored“ urine. During the past week, his mother noticed episodes of facial swelling. The patient had a rash on his face about 4 weeks ago. A renal biopsy after immunofluorescence is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive swelling in his mouth that he first noticed 5 years ago. Initially, the swelling was asymptomatic but has now caused some difficulty while chewing food for the past month. He has no pain. He has not undergone any dental procedures in the past 5 years. He has bronchial asthma. His only medication is an albuterol inhaler. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 1.5-cm smooth, unilobular, bony hard, nontender mass in the midline of the hard palate. There is no cervical or submandibular lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old boy is brought in by his parents to his pediatrician for concerns about their child’s behavior. Since the parents started taking their child to daycare, they have become concerned that their son has not been behaving like other children his age. Most notably, he seldom responds when his name is called at home or at daycare. Additionally, he has been getting in trouble with the day care staff for not following directions but instead demanding to play with the train set at all times. He has been asked numerous times to share the toys, but the patient does not play with the other children. The parents state that the patient was born vaginally following a normal pregnancy, and the patient had been meeting developmental milestones all along. While he does not speak much, he is able to construct sentences up to 4-5 words. On exam, the patient’s temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 106/60 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 14/min. The patient does not cooperate with gross or fine motor testing, but he appears to have no trouble running around the room and draws very detailed trains with crayons. While drawing and standing, he frequently makes flapping motions with his hands. The patient has ample vocabulary, but speaks in a singsong voice mostly to himself and does not engage during the exam. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain. The patient states that she has had right lower quadrant abdominal pain for "a while now". The pain comes and goes, and today it is particularly painful. The patient is a college student studying philosophy. She drinks alcohol occasionally and is currently sexually active. She states that sometimes she feels anxious about school. The patient's father died of colon cancer at the age of 55, and her mother died of breast cancer when she was 57. The patient has a past medical history of anxiety and depression which is not currently treated. Review of systems is positive for bloody diarrhea. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 100/58 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Abdominal exam reveals diffuse tenderness. A fecal occult blood test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old male visits his primary care physician with 2+ pitting edema in his legs. He takes no medications and does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. 4.5 grams of protein are collected during 24-hour urine excretion. A kidney biopsy is obtained. Examination with light microscopy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy shows subepithelial spike and dome deposits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:

A 51-year-old man presents the following significant and unintentional weight loss. He denies any personal history of blood clots in his past, but he says that his mother has also had to be treated for pulmonary embolism in the recent past. He also mentions that he had been struggling with his weight, so he was initially content with losing the weight, but his daughter convinced his to come to the office to be checked out. His past medical history is significant for preeclampsia, hypertension, polycystic ovarian syndrome, and hypercholesterolemia. He currently smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day, drinks a glass of wine per day, and he currently denies any illicit drug use, although he has a remote past of injection drug use with heroin. The vital signs include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), blood pressure 126/74 mm Hg, heart rate 111/min and irregular, and respiratory rate 17/min. On physical examination, his pulses are bounding and complexion is pale, but breath sounds remain clear. Oxygen saturation was initially 91% on room air and electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation. Upon further discussion with the patient, his physician discovers that he is having some cognitive difficulty. His leukocyte count is elevated to 128,000/mm3, and he has elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), uric acid, and B-12 levels. A BCR-ABL translocation is present, as evidenced by the Philadelphia chromosome. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

An 8-year-old boy is brought into your clinic with a 5 day history of decreased oral intake, body aches and lymphadenopathy. He has no significant medical history. Upon further questioning you find that the patient frequently plays outside, where he enjoys chasing the neighborhood cats and dogs. He has had no recent sick contacts or travel to foreign countries. The patients vital signs are: temperature 100.4F, HR 80, BP 105/75 and RR 15. Physical exam is significant for a 1-cm erythematous and tender lymph node in the right posterior cervical area (Figure 1). There is a nearly healed scratch in the right occipital region. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A newborn infant presents with severe weakness. She was born to a G1P1 mother at 40 weeks gestation with the pregnancy attended by a midwife. The mother's past medical history is unremarkable. She took a prenatal vitamin and folic acid throughout the pregnancy. Since birth, the child has had trouble breastfeeding despite proper counseling. She also has had poor muscle tone and a weak cry. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 57/38 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 37/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical exam reveals poor muscle tone. The patient's sucking reflex is weak, and an enlarged tongue is noted. An ultrasound is performed, and is notable for hypertrophy of the myocardium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.E: Spinal muscular atrophy type I disease

question: An 11-year-old boy presents with a 1-day history of frothy brown urine. He has no significant medical history and takes no medications. He reports that several of his classmates have been sick, and he notes that he had a very sore throat with a fever approx. 2 weeks ago. His blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg, heart rate is 74/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Laboratory analysis reveals elevated serum creatinine, hematuria with RBC casts, and elevated urine protein without frank proteinuria. Physical examination reveals a healthy-looking boy with no abdominal or costovertebral angle tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of decreased vision and black spots in front of her left eye for the past 24 hours. She states that it feels as if 'a curtain is hanging over her eye.' She sees flashes of light intermittently. She has no pain or diplopia. She underwent cataract surgery on the left eye 2 weeks ago. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her sister has open-angle glaucoma. Current medications include metformin, linagliptin, ramipril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a visual acuity in the right eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the left eye. The pupils are equal and reactive. The corneal reflex is present. The anterior chamber shows no abnormalities. The confrontation test is normal on the right side and shows nasal and inferior defects on the left side. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is awaiting dilation for fundus examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of severe pain over his neck, back, and shoulders for the past year. The pain worsens with exercise and lack of sleep. Use of over-the-counter analgesics have not resolved his symptoms. He also has stiffness of the shoulders and knees and tingling in his upper extremities that is worse in the morning. He takes escitalopram for generalized anxiety disorder. He also has tension headaches several times a month. His maternal uncle has ankylosing spondylitis. Examination shows marked tenderness over the posterior neck, bilateral mid trapezius, and medial aspect of the left knee. Muscle strength is normal. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and thyroid-stimulating hormone are within the reference ranges. X-rays of his cervical and lumbar spine show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman is seen in the hospital for new onset shortness of breath. The patient was hospitalized 5 days ago after initially presenting with chest pain. She was found to have an ST-elevation myocardial infarction. She underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement with resolution of her chest pain. She states that she was doing well until yesterday when she developed dyspnea while walking around the hall and occasionally when getting out of bed to use the bathroom. Her shortness of breath has since progressed, and she is now having trouble breathing even at rest. Her medical history is also significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. She takes aspirin, clopidogrel, metformin, and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 97°F (36.1°C), blood pressure is 133/62, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On physical examination, there is a holosystolic murmur that radiates to the axilla and an S3 heart sound. Coarse crackles are heard bilaterally. An electrocardiogram, a chest radiograph, and cardiac enzyme levels are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Her mother says her teachers report him being easily distracted, lagging behind her classmates in most of the subjects, and frequently falling asleep during class. She says that her son has complained of leg pain on multiple occasions. She is at the 45th percentile for height and 35th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows ptosis and a high-arched palate. Muscle strength is decreased in the face and hands. Muscle strength of the quadriceps and hamstrings is normal. Sensation is intact. Percussion of the thenar eminence causes the thumb to abduct and then relax slowly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because he complained of very fast heartbeats. The patient has previously been healthy without any childhood illnesses and has not needed to visit a physician in the past 2 years. On examination, the heart rate is 198/min. Further examination by the physician reveals a grade III holosystolic murmur over the anterior chest wall. ECG is immediately performed after his heart rate is reduced, and shows a short P-R interval with a slow upstroke of the QRS complex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 32-year-old man presents to a psychiatrist to discuss a recent event in his life. At a social function 2 days back, he met a man who introduced himself as having worked with his at another private company 3 years ago. However, he did not recognize him. He also says that he does not remember working at any such company at any time during his life. However, the patient’s wife says that he had indeed worked at that company for three months and had quit due to his boss’s abusive behavior towards her. The man who met his at the function had actually been his colleague at that job. The man asks the doctor, “How is it possible? I am really not able to recall any memories of having worked at any such company. What’s going on here?”. His wife adds that after he quit the job, his mood frequently has been low. The patient denies any crying episodes, suicidal ideas, not enjoying recreational activities or feelings of worthlessness. His appetite and sleep patterns are normal. He is otherwise a healthy man with no significant medical history and lives a normal social and occupational life. The patient reports no history of smoking, alcohol, or substance use. On physical examination, he is alert and well-oriented to time, place and person. During memory testing, he correctly remembers the date of his marriage that took place 5 years back and the food he ate over the last 2 days. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal and lower back pain. He describes it as intense cramping and states that he experienced severe pain roughly 1 month ago that was similar. The patient's past medical history is non-contributory, and he states that his menses cause his to soak through 1 pad in a day. He is currently sexually active and does not use any contraception. His vitals are within normal limits. The patient's abdominal exam is non-focal, and his pelvic exam reveals no adnexal masses or tenderness and no cervical motion tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for pain and swelling of her left knee one day after injuring it while playing soccer. While sprinting on the field, she slipped as she attempted to kick the ball and landed on the anterior aspect of her knee. She underwent an appendectomy at the age of 16 years. Her vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The tibial tuberosity shows tenderness to palpation. The left tibia is displaced posteriorly when force is applied to the proximal tibia after flexing the knee. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the left knee joint shows an avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 49-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-month history of mild abdominal pain, nausea, and several episodes of vomiting. He often feels full after eating only a small amount of food. Abdominal examination shows mild right upper quadrant tenderness and a liver span of 16 cm. Ultrasonography shows a 5 x 4 cm hyperechoic mass in the left lobe of the liver. The mass is surgically excised. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male teacher presents to the clinic with complaints of discoloration of the skin around the right ankle accompanied by itching. He began noticing it a month ago and the pruritus worsened over time. He also has some pain and swelling of the region every night, especially on days when he teaches late into the evening. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2, for which he takes metformin. He lives with his wife and takes oral contraceptive pills. On examination, the physician observes hyperpigmentation of the medial aspect of his right ankle. The skin is dry, scaly, and edematous along with some superficial varicosities. Dorsiflexion of the foot is extremely painful. Peripheral pulses are equally palpable on both lower limbs. There is a small 2 cm ulcer noted near the medial malleolus with thickened neighboring skin and indurated edges. Laboratory studies show D-dimer of 1,000 µg/L and HbA1c of 9%. Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremity reveals an intramural thrombus in the popliteal vein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because she believes she has low testosterone. She states that she is embarrassed at her lack of musculature, despite lifting weights twice daily. Every day, she drinks a gallon of milk and several protein shakes in addition to 3 large meals. She is convinced that her female classmates at the community college she attends are secretly laughing at her scrawny appearance. Over the course of the semester, she has attended fewer and fewer classes out of embarrassment and shame. She is also concerned that her hair is thinning and applies topical minoxidil to her scalp 3 times daily. She spends 2 hours daily anxiously examining himself in the mirror. Today, she is wearing a long-sleeved shirt and a hat. Her BMI is 26 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she has an anxious mood and a full range of affect. Serum studies show a normal testosterone concentration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old student presents to the college health clinic with a 1-week history of fever, sore throat, nausea, and fatigue. She could hardly get out of bed this morning. There are no pets at home. She admits to having recent unprotected sex. The vital signs include: temperature 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse 72/min, blood pressure 118/63 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 15/min. On physical examination, she has bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, exudates over the palatine tonsil walls with soft palate petechiae, an erythematous macular rash on the trunk and arms, and mild hepatosplenomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old man presents with exertional dyspnea and fatigue for the past 3 months. His past medical history is significant for multiple episodes of mild diarrhea for many years, which was earlier diagnosed as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). He denies any current significant gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals oral aphthous ulcers and mild conjunctival pallor. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. There is a rash present on the peripheral extremities bilaterally (see image). Laboratory findings are significant for evidence of microcytic hypochromic anemia. FOBT is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of slurred speech and left facial droop for the past 30 minutes. During this period, he has also had numbness on the left side of his face. He has never had such an episode before. He has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His father died of lung cancer 1 week ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks one glass of wine daily. His current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 30.5 kg/m2. He is oriented to time, place, and person. His temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left side of the face. His speech is clear. Examination shows full muscle strength. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. A finger-nose test and his gait are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a right-sided carotid bruit. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, glucose, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows no abnormalities. On the way back from the CT scan, his presenting symptoms resolve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of intermittent buzzing in both his ears. He says he sometimes has episodes of mild dizziness which resolve spontaneously. He has a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and episodes of low back pain. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin and aspirin. He works as a trombonist for a symphony orchestra. His vital signs are within normal limits. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears normal. Bone conduction is greater than air conduction in both ears. Weber test shows no lateralization. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old girl with a sore throat, fever, and generalized malaise is admitted to the pediatric floor. On physical examination, she has diffuse white exudate on both tonsils, and also a palpable spleen with mild hepatomegaly. Her blood smear shows large and abundant lymphocytes with blue-gray cytoplasm, irregular nuclei, and dark chromatin with inconspicuous nucleoli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening cough and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows wheezing over the right lung fields. Laboratory studies show a serum calcium concentration of 12.5 mg/dL. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old girl presents with recurrent joint pain that migrates from joint to joint and intermittent fever for the last several weeks. She also says that she has no appetite and has been losing weight. The patient is afebrile, and vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, she is pale with diffuse petechial bleeding and bruises on her legs. An abdominal examination is significant for hepatosplenomegaly. Ultrasound of the abdomen confirms hepatosplenomegaly and also shows multiple enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes. A complete blood count (CBC) shows severe anemia and thrombocytopenia with leukocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 2-year-old male with abdominal pain undergoes laparoscopic surgery. An outpouching of tissue is excised from the ileum and sent to the laboratory for evaluation. The pathologist notes inflammation and the presence of mucosa, submucosa, and muscle in the walls of the specimen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of multiple red spots on her trunk. She first noticed these several months ago, and some appear to have increased in size. One day ago, she scratched one of these spots, and it bled for several minutes. Physical examination shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 73-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 2 years. Initially, he used to misplace keys and forget his dog's name or his phone number. Now, he often forgets about what he has seen on television or read about the day before. He used to go for a walk every morning but stopped one month ago after he became lost on his way back home. His son has prevented his from cooking because he has had episodes of leaving the gas stove oven on after making a meal. He becomes agitated when asked questions directly but is unconcerned when his son reports his history and says he is overprotective of her. He has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, enalapril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin. He is alert and oriented to place and person but not to time. Vital signs are within normal limits. Short- and long-term memory deficits are present. His speech rhythm is normal but is frequently interrupted as he thinks of words to frame his sentences. He makes multiple errors while performing serial sevens. His clock drawing is impaired and he draws 14 numbers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old is brought into your office by her mother. Her mother states that she is having 10-20 episodes per day where she stops responding to her mother and is found staring out of the window. During these periods, she blinks more frequently than normal, but returns to her normal self afterwards. These episodes last 30 to 60 seconds. Her mother states that all of her milestones have been normal and she had an uncomplicated birth. Her mother also denies any other recent illness. On exam, her vitals are normal. During one of these episodes in the office, her EEG shows three-per-second spike and wave discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department with persistent vomiting overnight. She spent all day drinking beer yesterday at a college party according to her friends. She appears to be in shock and when asked about vomiting, she says that she vomited up blood about an hour ago. At the hospital, her vomit contains streaks of blood. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respirations are 15/min, pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 90/68 mm Hg. A physical examination is performed and is within normal limits. Intravenous fluids are started and a blood sample is drawn for typing and cross-matching. An immediate upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a longitudinal mucosal tear in the distal esophagus. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of increasingly withdrawn behavior for the last two years. Her mother reports that in the last 2–3 years of high school, her daughter has spent most of her time in her room playing video games. She does not have any friends and has never had a boyfriend. She usually refuses to attend family dinner and avoids contact with her siblings. The patient states that she prefers being on her own. When asked how much playing video games means to her, she replies that “it's okay.” When her mother starts crying during the visit, she appears indifferent. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. On mental status examination, her thought process is organized and logical. Her affect is flattened. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 93-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a purple area on his right arm that has been growing for one month. He has not had any pain or itching of the area. He has hyperlipidemia, a history of basal cell carcinoma treated with Mohs surgery 2 years ago, and a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast treated with radical mastectomy 57 years ago. He has had chronic lymphedema of the right upper extremity since the mastectomy. His only medication is simvastatin. He lives in an assisted living facility. He is content with his living arrangement but feels guilty that he is dependent on others. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the right arm. Skin exam of the proximal upper right extremity shows three coalescing, 0.5–1.0 cm heterogeneous, purple-colored plaques with associated ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old girl presents with a long-standing history of anemia. Past medical history is significant for prolonged neonatal jaundice and multiple episodes of jaundice without fever. On physical examination, the patient shows generalized pallor, scleral icterus, and splenomegaly. Her hemoglobin is 10 g/dL, and examination of a peripheral blood smear shows red cell basophilic stippling. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 26-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine physical exam. She is concerned about a burning sensation that she feels in her throat whenever she eats large meals and is concerned she may have esophageal cancer like her uncle. The patient has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome and constipation. Her current medications include whey protein supplements, fish oil, a multivitamin, and sodium docusate. The patient is concerned about her performance in school and fears she may fail out. She recently did poorly on an exam and it has caused him significant stress. She also is worried that her boyfriend is going to leave him. The patient claims that she thought she was going to be an incredible doctor some day, but now she feels like a terrible person. The patient also states that she feels guilty about her grandfather's death which occurred 1 year ago and she often reexperiences the funeral in her mind. She regularly has trouble sleeping for which she takes melatonin. The patient has been praying every 4 hours with the hopes that this will make things go better for him. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
