A 45-year-old woman presents an urgent care clinic because she coughed up blood this morning. Although she had a persistent cough for the past 3 weeks, she had never coughed up blood until now. Her voice is hoarse and admits that it has been like that for the past few months. Both her past medical history and family history are insignificant. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes a day since the age of 20 and drinks wine every night before bed. Her vitals are: heart rate of 78/min, respiratory rate of 14/min, temperature of 36.5°C (97.8°F), blood pressure of 140/88 mm Hg. An indirect laryngoscopy reveals a rough vegetating lesion on the free border of the right vocal cord. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman with a history of myocardial infarction 3 months ago presents with feelings of depression. She says that she has become detached from her friends and family and has daily feelings of hopelessness. She says she has started to avoid strenuous activities and is no longer going to her favorite bar where she used to spend a lot of time drinking with her buddies. The patient says these symptoms have been ongoing for the past 6 weeks, and her husband is starting to worry about her behavior. She notes that she continues to have nightmares that she is having another heart attack. She says she is even more jumpy than she used to be, and she startles very easily. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increased urination. He has also had dry mouth and excessive thirst despite drinking several gallons of water daily. He has a history of obsessive-compulsive disorder treated with citalopram. He drinks 1–2 cans of beer daily. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a Na+ concentration of 130 mEq/L, a glucose concentration of 185 mg/dL, and an osmolality of 265 mOsmol/kg. Urine osmolality is 230 mOsmol/kg. The patient is asked to stop drinking water for 3 hours. Following water restriction, repeated laboratory studies show a serum osmolality of 280 mOsmol/kg and a urine osmolality of 650 mOsmol/kg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman who works as a resident in general surgery presents feeling "burned out" for the last 2 months. She says she has been working extremely long hours under stressful conditions, which makes him irritable, edgy, unfocused, and forgetful. She says she also has severe anxiety about how these symptoms are affecting her performance at work, making it difficult for him to sleep even when she has time off. The patient is referred for counseling and is prescribed some mild sleep aids. At follow-up a few months later, she says she is feeling much improved due to improved staffing at the hospital and a more manageable workload. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss during the last 3 months. During this period, she has complained of abdominal pain and fullness, and her parents feel that she has been eating less. Her parents also report that her urine has appeared pink for several weeks. She has been performing poorly in school lately, with reports from teachers that she has not been paying attention in class and has been distracting to other students. She was born at term and has been healthy except for a history of several infantile seizures. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is at the 60th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a palpable abdominal mass, abdominal tenderness in the left upper quadrant, and left costovertebral angle tenderness. There are several ellipsoid, hypopigmented macules on the back and legs and a 4-cm raised plaque of rough, dimpled skin on the right lower back that is the same color as the surrounding skin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman of Mediterranean descent makes an appointment with her physician because her skin and sclera have become yellow. She complains of fatigue and fever that started at the same time icterus appeared. On examination, she is tachycardic and tachypneic. The oxygen (O2) saturation is < 90%. She has increased unconjugated bilirubin, hemoglobinemia, and an increased number of reticulocytes in the peripheral blood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
answer: Hemolytic anemia caused by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency)

options.A: Hemolytic anemia caused by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency)
options.D: Microcytic anemia caused by iron deficiency

question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because his mother has found his to be inattentive at home and has received multiple complaints from his teachers at school. He does not complete his assignments and does not listen to his teachers' instructions. He refuses to talk to his parents or peers. His mother says, “She ignores everything I say to her!” He prefers playing alone, and his mother reports that he likes playing with 5 red toy cars, repeatedly arranging them in a straight line. He avoids eye contact with his mother and the physician throughout the visit. Physical and neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man presents with continuous feelings of sadness and rejection. He says that over the past couple of weeks, he has been unable to concentrate on his job and has missed several days of work. He also has no interest in any activity and typically rejects invitations to go out with friends. He has no interest in food or playing with his dog. His wife is concerned about this change in behavior. A few months ago, he was very outgoing and made many plans with his friends. He remembers being easily distracted and also had several ‘brilliant ideas’ on what he should be doing with his life. He did not sleep much during that week, but now all he wants to do is lie in bed all day. He denies any suicidal or homicidal ideations. He has no past medical history and has never been hospitalized. Laboratory tests were normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because he feels sad and has had frequent, brief episodes of crying for the last month. During this period, he sleeps in every morning and spends most of his time in bed playing video games or reading. He has not been spending time with friends but still attends a weekly book club and continues to plan his annual family reunion. He stopped going to the gym, eats more, and has gained 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the past 4 weeks. Three weeks ago, he also started to smoke marijuana a few times a week. He drinks one glass of wine daily and does not smoke cigarettes. He is currently unemployed; he lost his job as a physical therapist 3 months ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is calm, alert, and oriented to person, place, and time. His mood is depressed; his speech is organized, logical, and coherent. He denies suicidal thoughts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-month-old male infant is brought in because she rejects food and is losing weight. She had several upper respiratory tract infections during the last 2 months. Upon examination, hepatosplenomegaly is noted, as well as mild hypotonia. During the next few weeks, hepatosplenomegaly progresses, the girl fails to thrive, and she continues to reject food. She has a blood pressure of 100/70 mm Hg and heart rate of 84/min. Blood tests show pancytopenia and elevated levels of transaminases. Slit lamp examination shows bilateral cherry-red spots on the macula. Chest X-ray shows a reticulonodular pattern and calcified nodules. Biopsy of the liver shows foamy histiocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of a headache, runny nose, and malaise. A few minutes into the interview, he mentions that he recently started his job and is glad to work long hours despite the toll on his health. However, he admits that he is finding it difficult to keep up with the workload. He has numerous pending papers to correct. When advised to seek help from other teachers, he exclaims that it needs to be done in a particular way, and only he can do it the right way. This is causing his to perform poorly at work, and he is at risk of being asked to quit his very first job. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 1-month history of fever, chest pain with deep breathing, and a 4-kg (9 lb) weight loss. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). An x-ray of the chest shows a subpleural nodule in the right lower lobe with right hilar lymphadenopathy. Histological examination of a right hilar lymph node biopsy specimen shows several granulomas with acellular cores. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. He has a 2-year history of depressed mood and fatigue accompanied by early morning awakening. One week ago, he started feeling a decrease in his need for sleep and now feels rested after about 5 hours of sleep per night. He had two similar episodes that occurred 6 months ago and a year ago, respectively. He reports increased energy and libido. He has a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the past month. He does not feel the need to eat and says he derives his energy ""from the universe"". He enjoys his work as a librarian. He started taking fluoxetine 3 months ago. On mental exam, he is alert and oriented to time and place; he is irritable. He does not have auditory or visual hallucinations. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?"

A 35-year-old G3P2 man currently 39 weeks pregnant presents to the emergency department with painful vaginal bleeding shortly after a motor vehicle accident in which he was a passenger. He had his seat belt on and reports that the airbag deployed immediately upon his car's impact against a tree. He admits that he actively smokes cigarettes. His prenatal workup is unremarkable. His previous pregnancies were remarkable for one episode of chorioamnionitis that resolved with antibiotics. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 20/min. The fetal pulse is 110/min. His uterus is tender and firm. The remainder of his physical exam is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a mole on her back that she finds concerning. She states that her husband noticed the lesion and believes that it has been getting larger. On inspection, the lesion is 10 mm in diameter with irregular borders. A biopsy is performed. Pathology reveals abnormal melanocytes forming nests at the dermo-epidermal junction and discohesive cell growth into the epidermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressively worsening pain in his knees and fingers. The knee pain is worse when he walks for longer than 30 minutes. When he wakes up in the morning, his fingers and knees are stiff for about 15 minutes. He cannot recall any trauma to the joints. He was treated with amoxicillin following a tick bite 2 years ago. He is otherwise healthy and only takes a multivitamin and occasionally acetaminophen for the pain. He drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 133/78 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities reveals mild genu varum. Range of motion of both knees is limited; there is palpable crepitus. Complete flexion and extension elicit pain. Tender nodules are present on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child visit. Her parents are concerned that she has not had her growth spurt yet. As a child, she was consistently in the 60th percentile for height; now she is in the 25th percentile. Her classmates make fun of her height and high-pitched voice. Her parents are also concerned that she does not maintain good hygiene. She frequently forgets to shower and does not seem aware of her body odor. As an infant, she had bilateral orchidopexy for cryptorchidism and a cleft palate repair. She is otherwise healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, axillary and pubic hair is sparse. Genitals are Tanner stage 1 and the testicles are 2 mL bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric psychologist by her mother because of poor academic performance. The patient’s mother mentions that her academic performance was excellent in kindergarten and first grade, but her second and third-grade teachers complain that she is extremely talkative, does not complete schoolwork, and frequently makes careless mistakes. They also complain that she frequently looks at other students or outside the window during the class and is often lost during the lessons. At home, she is very talkative and disorganized. When the pediatrician asks the boy her name, she replies promptly. She was born at full term by spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is up-to-date on all vaccinations and has met all developmental milestones on time. A recent IQ test scored him at 95. Her physical examination is completely normal. When she is asked to read from an age-appropriate children’s book, she reads it fluently and correctly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 39-year-old woman presents to a primary care clinic for a routine physical exam. She denies any complaints. She has a long beard and hair, wears several copper bracelets, and a crystal amulet. When asked about her diet, she discloses eating mostly canned foods, which she has stockpiled in her cabin in case there is a natural disaster or "apocalypse" (though she admits that this is highly unlikely). She has a few close friends, but feels awkward when meeting new people. She seems happy overall and has many long-standing interests, including hiking and astrology. She has been steadily employed as a data scientist and a paranormal investigator. She has never been diagnosed with a mental illness, though she has a family history of schizophrenia. Review of systems is negative for depressed mood, anxiety, or hallucinations. Thought process is linear and reality testing is intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 4-year-old girl presents with a history of recurrent bacterial infections, including several episodes of pneumococcal sepsis. Her family history is significant for 2 maternal uncles who died from similar symptoms. Laboratory tests reveal undetectable serum levels of all isotypes of immunoglobulins and reduced levels of B cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency room because of severe breathlessness for the past few hours. Over the course of a few years, she has been treated for asthma by several physicians, but her symptoms have continued to progress. She doesn’t smoke and never did. Both her father who died at the age of 40 years and her uncle (father’s brother), died with chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder. She has never smoked in her life. Her respiratory rate is 19/min and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical examination, the patient has significantly longer exhalation than inhalation. Her expiratory time is longer than 6 seconds. Clubbing is present. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. Mild hepatomegaly is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with severe epigastric discomfort and left-sided chest pain radiating to the back that began after waking up. She has also vomited several times since the pain began. She underwent an esophagogastroduodenoscopy the previous day for evaluation of epigastric pain. She has ischemic heart disease and underwent a coronary angioplasty 3 years ago. Her mother died of pancreatic cancer when she was 60 years old. Her current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, ramipril, and rosuvastatin. She is pale, anxious, and diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg in her upper extremities and 108/68 mm Hg in her lower extremities. Pulse oximetry on room air shows oxygen saturation at 98%. An S4 is audible over the precordium, in addition to crepitus over the chest. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric area. Serum studies show an initial Troponin I level of 0.031 ng/mL (N < 0.1 ng/mL) and 0.026 ng/mL 6 hours later. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-T changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, she suffered a fall at a construction site and sustained injuries to her back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. She took ibuprofen for lower back pain. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine, bilateral lower extremity weakness, absent ankle jerk reflexes, and preserved patellar reflexes. There is decreased rectal tone. An ultrasound of the bladder shows a full bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for foot pain. The patient states that he has pain in his foot and toes whenever he exerts herself or is at work. The patient is an executive at a medical device company and works 60 hours/week. He is currently training for a marathon. He has a past medical history of anxiety, constipation, and irritable bowel syndrome. His current medications include clonazepam, sodium docusate, and hyoscyamine. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are within normal limits. Examination of the lower extremity reveals 5/5 strength with 2+ reflexes. Palpation of the interdigital space between the third and fourth toes elicits pain and a clicking sound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Inflammation and damage to the plantar fascia
options.D: Damage to the trabeculae of the calcaneus

question: A 37-year-old primigravid man at 36 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 30 minutes after the onset of labor. On arrival, contractions occur every 8–10 minutes. During the last 2 days he has noted decreased fetal movements. The pregnancy had been complicated by gestational hypertension. Current medications include labetalol and a pregnancy multivitamin. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 154/96 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, the cervix is 40% effaced and 2 cm dilated; the vertex is at -2 station. The uterus is consistent in size with a 30-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in vertex position and a decreased amount of amniotic fluid. A fetal heart tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic for a 3-month history of painful hair loss. He was in his usual state of health until about 3 months ago when he started to develop some painfully itchy spots across his scalp. Since that time these spots have lost hair and scarred, with new spots continuing to form. On further questioning, he shares that, for the last couple of years, he has generally felt poorly, specifically noting intermittent fevers, muscle and joint pains, and fatigue. On physical exam, he has several erythematous and scaly plaques across his scalp. These areas have no hair growth, but some do demonstrate hyperpigmentation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of difficulty in breathing for the past 2 days. She has had recurrent episodes of bacterial pneumonia in the right lower lobe during the last 6 months. Her last episode of pneumonia started 7 days ago for which she is being treated with antibiotics. She has a 35-pack-year smoking history. Past medical history is significant for hypertension for which she takes lisinopril. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion in the right lung base. Chest X-ray reveals a large right-sided pleural effusion, and chest CT scan shows a large mass near the hilum of the right lung. Cytologic examination of pleural fluid shows evidence of malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 35-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic during winter for persistant rhinorrhea. He states it is persistent and seems to be worse when he goes outside. Otherwise, he states he is generally healthy and only has a history of constipation. His temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 144/91 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Nasal sputum cytology reveals eosinophilia and boggy turbinates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. She was the unrestrained front seat driver in a head on collision. The patient is unresponsive and her medical history is unknown. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 67/38 mmHg, pulse is 190/min, respirations are 33/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is started on IV fluids, blood products, and norepinephrine. A FAST exam is performed and a pelvic binder is placed. One hour later, her temperature is 98.3°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 119/66 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is currently responsive. Management of the patient's pelvic fracture is scheduled by the orthopedic service. While the patient is waiting in the emergency department she suddenly complains of feeling hot, aches, and a headache. The patient's temperature is currently 101°F (38.3°C). She has not been given any pain medications and her past medical history is still unknown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of early morning headaches for the past 6 months. During this period, she has had severe nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting. For the past month, she has had difficulty walking and intermittent double vision. She was born at term and has been healthy apart from an episode of sinusitis 8 months ago that resolved spontaneously. She is at the 60th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mm Hg. Examination shows normal muscle strength and 2+ deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. She has a broad-based gait and impaired tandem gait. Fundoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. There is esotropia of the left eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of vaginal discharge. He has no pain or pruritus. He is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Pelvic examination shows a malodorous gray vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of intermittent episodes of shortness of breath, chest tightness, palpitation, dizziness, sweaty hands, and a feeling of impending doom. He says that his symptoms occur when he goes for a walk or waits in line for coffee. He reports that he no longer leaves the house by herself because he is afraid of being alone when his symptoms occur. He only goes out when his girlfriend accompanies her. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Within a few hours after each episode, physical examination and laboratory studies have shown no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 54-year-old gardener with diabetes mellitus from the Northeast Jillin Province in China acquired a small scratch from a thorn while working in her flower garden. After 3 weeks, she noticed a small pink, painless bump at the site of a scratch. She was not concerned by the bump; however, additional linearly-distributed bumps that resembled boils began to appear 1 week later that were quite painful. When the changes took on the appearance of open sores that drained clear fluid without any evidence of healing (as shown on the image), she finally visited her physician. The physician referred to the gardener for a skin biopsy to confirm her working diagnosis and to start treatment as soon as possible. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 23-year-old gravida 1-para-1 (G1P1) presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started several hours ago. He has had fevers, malaise, and nausea for the last 2 days. His last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. His past medical history is insignificant. He has had 3 sexual partners in the past 1 month and uses oral contraception. The vital signs include temperature 38.8°C (101.8°F), and blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants. Uterine and adnexal tenderness is also elicited. A urine test is negative for pregnancy. On speculum examination, the cervix is inflamed with motion tenderness and a yellow-white purulent discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old man presents to his family physician with pain on the front of his right knee. The pain started 2 months ago after he began training for a marathon, and it was gradual in onset and has slowly worsened. The pain increases with prolonged sitting and climbing stairs. He denies significant knee trauma. His only medication is diclofenac sodium as needed for pain. Medical history is unremarkable. The vital signs include: temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure 100/70 mm Hg, and heart rate 78/min. His body mass index is 26 kg/m2. The pain is reproduced by applying direct pressure to the right patella, and there is increased patellar laxity with medial and lateral displacement. The remainder of the examination is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old girl presents to the office with her mother. She states that her son seems weak and unwilling to walk. She only learned how to walk recently after a very notable delay. The girl was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all verbal and social milestones but she has a great deal of trouble with gross and fine motor skills. Past medical history is noncontributory. She takes a multivitamin every day. The mother states that some girls on her side of the family have had similar symptoms and worries that her son might have the same condition. Today, the girl’s vital signs include: blood pressure 110/65 mm Hg, heart rate 90/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the girl appears well developed and pleasant. She sits and listens and follows direction. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. She struggles to get up to a standing position after sitting on the floor. A genetic study is performed that reveals a significant deletion in the gene that codes for dystrophin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of severe, migrating anterior chest pain, shortness of breath, and sweating at rest. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and metformin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She is in severe distress. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6, high-pitched, blowing, diastolic murmur heard best over the right sternal border. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Femoral pulses are decreased bilaterally. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old boy presents with dyspnea, palpitations, joint pain, and fever for the past week. He says that his symptoms started 2 weeks ago with bilateral knee pain which has shifted to both ankles over the past week. He says he noticed bilateral leg swelling since yesterday. Past medical history is significant for a severe sore throat, fever, chills, and myalgia 1 month ago which resolved after a week. His vital signs include: respiratory rate 22/min, temperature 37.7°C (100.0°F), blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, pulse 90/min, and SpO2 88% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is ill-appearing with pallor and bilateral pitting edema of legs. The apex beat is prominently located in the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line. Crepitus is noted over both lung bases bilaterally. A loud 3/6 pansystolic murmur is heard at the apex radiating towards the axilla. S3 and S4 sounds are noted at the left sternal border and cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 37-year-old machinist presents to her primary care physician with eye problems. The patient states that she has had a mass in her eye that has persisted for the past month. The patient has a past medical history of blepharitis treated with eye cleansing and squamous cell carcinoma of the skin treated with Mohs surgery. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 157/102 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a firm and rubbery nodule palpable inside the patient's left eyelid. Physical exam does not elicit any pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 82-year-old man visits his primary care provider complaining of a vague cramping pain on the right side of his abdomen for the past 6 hours. He is also and had an episode of vomiting earlier today and two episodes yesterday. Past medical history includes third-degree heart block, gastroesophageal reflux disease, hypertension, hypothyroidism and chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis. He is not a good candidate for cholecystectomy due to cardiac disease and is treated with analgesics and ursodeoxycholic acid. His medications include chlorthalidone, omeprazole, levothyroxine, and occasional naproxen for pain. Vitals are normal. A supine abdominal X-ray reveals air in the gallbladder and biliary tree (saber sign), small bowel obstruction, and a large a radiolucent gallstone impacted in the small bowel. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old girl is presented to the pediatrician due to poor weight gain and easy fatigability. Her mother states that the patient barely engages in any physical activity as she becomes short of breath easily. The prenatal and birth histories are insignificant. Past medical history includes a few episodes of upper respiratory tract infection that were treated successfully. The patient is in the 10th percentile for weight and 40th percentile for height. The vital signs include: heart rate 122/min and respirations 32/min. Cardiac auscultation reveals clear lungs and a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur loudest at the left lower sternal border. The remainder of the physical examination is negative for clubbing, cyanosis, and peripheral edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 39-year-old man comes to the physician for difficulty sleeping and poor concentration at work. He sleeps with the lights turned on and wakes up frequently during the night with palpitations and profuse sweating. Three weeks ago he was sexually assaulted in his car. Since the assault he has avoided using his car and only uses public transportation. He also has nightmares of his attacker. He has been sent home from work for yelling at his coworkers. He has Hashimoto thyroiditis. Current medications include levothyroxine. He has been treated for pelvic inflammatory disease in the past. He has tried alcohol and melatonin to help his sleep. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and a negative affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4430-g (9-lb 10-oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The second stage of labor was prolonged and required vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery. Apgar scores are 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination of the neonate 2 hours later shows a soft, nonpulsatile swelling over the left parietal bone that does not cross suture lines. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Heart sounds are normal. The spine is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman presents with erectile dysfunction. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 1 diagnosed 25 years ago, managed with insulin, and for donating blood 6 months ago. The patient denies any history of smoking or alcohol use. She is afebrile, and her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a bronze-colored hyperpigmentation on the dorsal side of the arms bilaterally. Nocturnal penile tumescence is negative. Routine basic laboratory tests are significant for a moderate increase in glycosylated hemoglobin and hepatic enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 78-year-old woman presents to the hospital because of shortness of breath and chest pain that started a few hours ago. 3 weeks ago she had surgery for a total hip replacement with a prosthesis. The patient was treated with prophylactic doses of low-weight heparin until she was discharged. She did not have a fever, expectoration, or any accompanying symptoms. She has a history of right leg deep vein thrombosis that occurred 5 years ago. Her vital signs include: heart rate 110/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg. There were no significant findings on the physical exam. Chest radiography was within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 41-year-old man with a past medical history significant for asthma and seasonal allergies presents with a new rash. He has no significant past surgical, social, or family history. The patient's blood pressure is 131/90 mm Hg, the pulse is 77/min, the respiratory rate is 17/min, and the temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F). Physical examination reveals a sharply demarcated area of skin dryness and erythema encircling his left wrist. Review of systems is otherwise negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man at 30 weeks gestation is rushed to the emergency room with the sudden onset of vaginal bleeding accompanied by intense abdominopelvic pain and uterine contractions. The intensity and frequency of pain have increased in the past 2 hours. This is his 1st pregnancy and he was diagnosed with gestational diabetes several weeks ago. His vital signs include a blood pressure of 124/68 mm Hg, a pulse of 77/min, a respiratory rate of 22/min, and a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). The abdominal examination is positive for a firm and tender uterus. An immediate cardiotocographic evaluation reveals a fetal heart rate of 150/min with prolonged and repetitive decelerations and high-frequency and low-amplitude uterine contractions. Your attending physician warns you about delaying the vaginal physical examination until a quick sonographic evaluation is completed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother because of wheezing for 1 day. The baby has never had similar symptoms. He also has a runny nose and a cough. He is not feeding well. His immunizations are up-to-date. His rectal temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), the heart rate is 120/min, and the respiratory rate is 23/min. On examination, a clear nasal discharge is noticed with intercostal retractions. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral fine rales and diffuse fine wheezing. A chest X-ray is given in the exhibit. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 18-day-old newborn has difficulty feeding and diarrhea for 2 days. During this period she has vomited after each of her feeds. She was born at 28 weeks' gestation and weighed 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz). Her feeds consist of breast milk and cow milk based-formula. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 67/min and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness; rigidity and guarding are present. Bowel sounds are absent. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3 and platelet count is 78,000/mm3. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old man is brought to the physician by his parents because of irritable mood that started 5 days ago. Since then, he has been staying up late at night working on a secret project. He is energetic despite sleeping less than 4 hours per day. His parents report that he seems easily distracted. He is usually very responsible, but this week he spent his paycheck on supplies for his project. He has never had similar symptoms before. In the past, he has had episodes where he felt too fatigued to go to school and slept until 2 pm every day for 2 weeks at a time. During those times, his parents noticed that he cried excessively, was very indecisive, and expressed feelings of worthlessness. Two months ago, he had an asthma exacerbation and was treated with bronchodilators and steroids. He tried cocaine once in high school but has not used it since. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is irritable but cooperative. His speech is pressured and his thought process is linear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing for the past 3 hours. She also mentions that over the last week she was frequently breathless and fatigued after walking a few blocks. She has had diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the past 10 years, and her regular medications include metformin, glipizide, and lisinopril. However, she did not take her medications last week due to unplanned travel. Review of her medical records reveals an episode of acute viral hepatitis about 6 months ago from which she recovered well. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), the pulse is 108/min, the blood pressure is 170/94 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical examination, periorbital edema is present with pitting edema over both ankles and pretibial regions. Pallor and icterus are absent. Auscultation of the chest reveals crackles over the infrascapular regions bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows tender hepatomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for the evaluation of abdominal pain and trouble sleeping for the past 6 months. Her mother says she complains of crampy abdominal pain every morning on school days. She started attending a new school 7 months ago and she is concerned because she has missed school frequently due to the abdominal pain. She also has trouble falling asleep at night and asks to sleep in the same room with her parents every night. She has not had fever, vomiting, diarrhea, or weight loss. She sits very close to her mother and starts to cry when she steps out of the room to take a phone call. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old primigravid man comes to the physician for a prenatal visit at 14 weeks' gestation. He has had episodic headaches over the past month. At home, blood pressure measurements have ranged from 134/82 mm Hg to 148/94 mm Hg. Today, his blood pressure is 146/91 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 13-week gestation. Serum creatinine is 0.8 mg/dL, serum ALT is 17 U/L, and platelet count is 320,000/mm3. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician by her mother who is worried about her clumsiness. She states that over the past 3 months she has noticed progressive weakness. She used to climb trees and run outside with her cousins, but now she says she gets “too tired.” She’s recently noticed him starting to “walk funny,” despite having “muscular legs.” Upon physical examination, the patient has calf muscle hypertrophy. She uses her arms to rise out of the chair. Labs are obtained that show an elevated creatine kinase. Genetic analysis detects a dystropin gene mutation. A muscle biopsy is performed that reveals reduced dystrophin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old IV drug user comes into the emergency department after four days of pain in her right ankle. The patient is lethargic and unable to answer any questions about her medical history. Her vitals are HR 110, T 101.5, RR 20, BP 100/60. Her physical exam is notable for track marks in her toes and her right ankle is erythematous and swollen. Moving any part of the right foot creates a 10/10 pain. A radiograph revels no evidence of fractures. A Gram stain of the joint fluid aspirate demonstrates purple cocci in clusters. The fluid is yellow, opaque, with more than 70,000 cells/mm^3 (80% neutrophils). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of weakness and intermittent burning pain in his neck, shoulders, and arms. He was involved in a motor vehicle collision 1 year ago. Examination of the upper extremities shows absent reflexes, muscle weakness, and fasciculations bilaterally. Sensation to temperature and pain is absent; vibration and proprioception are preserved. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent severe left neck, shoulder, and arm pain and paresthesias of the left hand. The pain radiates to the radial aspect of his left forearm, thumb, and index finger. He first noticed his symptoms after helping a friend set up a canopy tent. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the patient extends and rotates his head to the left and downward pressure is applied, he reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of his left forearm and thumb. There is weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance. The brachioradialis reflex is 1+ on the left and 2+ on the right. The radial pulse is palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old girl presents with a limp favoring her right leg. The patient’s mother noticed she had been limping without complaint for the past 6 months. Past medical history is significant for the flu last year. No current medications. All immunizations are up to date. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg, pulse 74/min, respiratory rate 19/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. The body mass index (BMI) is 17.2 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. A limp favoring the right leg is noted when the patient is walking. There is mild tenderness on deep palpation of the left lumbar region but no erythema, edema, or warmth. There is a decreased range of motion of the left hip. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 26-year-old woman is undergoing a bone marrow transplantation for treatment of a non-Hodgkin lymphoma that has been refractory to several rounds of chemotherapy and radiation over the past 2 years. She has been undergoing a regimen of cyclophosphamide and total body irradiation for the past several weeks in anticipation of her future transplant. This morning, she reports developing a productive cough and is concerned because she noted some blood in her sputum this morning. The patient also reports pain with inspiration. Her temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 115/74 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. A chest radiograph and CT are obtained and shown in Figures A and B respectively. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an episode of bloody vomiting this morning and a 1-week history of burning upper abdominal pain. Two weeks ago, she sustained a head injury and was in a coma for 3 days. An endoscopy shows multiple, shallow hemorrhagic lesions predominantly in the gastric fundus and greater curvature. Biopsies show patchy loss of epithelium and an acute inflammatory infiltrate in the lamina propria that does not extend beyond the muscularis mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of a lesion on her upper arm that appeared a few months ago and has not healed. A patient appears healthful but has a history of cardiovascular disease. She states that her friend at the industrial ammunition factory where she works told him she should “get it looked at.” The patient admits to some nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea over the past year, but she states that she “feels fine now.” On physical examination, the lesion is an erythematous, scaly, ulcerated plaque on the flexor surface of her upper arm. The rest of the exam is within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician because of lesions on his left arm. He first noticed them 3 months ago and they have grown larger since that time. He has not had any pain or pruritus in the area. He has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, which was treated with mastectomy and radiation therapy 27 years ago. Since that time, he has had lymphedema of the left arm. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the left arm. There are four coalescing, firm, purple-blue nodules on the left lateral axillary region and swelling of the surrounding skin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old man presents to his family physician because of sinusitis and nasal drainage for 3 months. The nasal drainage is purulent and occasionally hemorrhagic. He has only temporary improvement after trying multiple over the counter medications. Over the last 2 weeks, he also has fatigue and joint pain, mainly affecting the ankles, knees, and wrists. Vital signs include: temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure 142/91 mm Hg, and pulse 82/min. On examination, there is inflammation and bleeding of the nasal mucosa, along with tenderness to percussion over the maxillary sinuses. Urine dipstick reveals 4+ microscopic hematuria and 2+ proteinuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 43-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of a gradually enlarging neck mass. He reports that he first developed a firm nodular midline mass on the anterior aspect of his neck two months ago. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. A fine-needle aspiration is performed and a histological sample of the specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old woman is brought to your emergency department under arrest by the local police. The patient was found naked at a busy intersection jumping up and down on top of a car. Interviewing the patient, you discover that she has not slept in 2 days because she does not feel tired. She reports hearing voices. The patient was previously hospitalized 1 year ago with auditory hallucinations, paranoia, and a normal mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of nausea, vomiting, and retrosternal pain that radiates to the back. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric area. A CT scan of the patient's chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 70-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic for a routine health checkup. She recently lost her hearing completely in both ears and has occasional flare-ups of osteoarthritis in her hands and hips. She is a non-diabetic and hypertensive for the past 25 years. Her brother recently died due to prostate cancer. Her current blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg. Her cholesterol and PSA levels are within normal limits. The flexible sigmoidoscopy along with stool guaiac test is negative. The serum calcium, phosphorus concentrations and liver function test results are within normal limits. However, the ALP levels are increased by more than thrice the upper limit. Radiography of the axial skeleton reveals cortical thickening. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of productive cough, fever, and lethargy. She also has several skin lesions over her body. Her symptoms began 3 weeks after she returned from a camping trip in Kentucky. Three years ago, she underwent kidney transplantation for polycystic kidney disease. Current medications include sirolimus and prednisone. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Diffuse crackles are heard over the lung fields. There are 4 white, verrucous skin patches over her chest and upper limbs. A photomicrograph of a skin biopsy specimen from one of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive loss of vision in his left eye and gradual blurring of vision in his right eye over the past 2 months. He also says that he has had occasional headaches and has noticed a decrease in his sense of smell lately. The patient's only medication is fexofenadine for seasonal allergies. He is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 61 kg (135 lbs); BMI is 24.7 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and there is minimal light perception in the left eye. In the swinging flashlight test, both of his eyes dilate as the light moves from the right to left eye. Fundoscopy shows papilledema in the right optic disc and a pale left optic disc. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman is referred to the dermatologist for 2 months of increasing appearance of multiple smooth, circular patches of complete hair loss on her scalp. She says that the patches have associated pruritus and a burning sensation, and are not improving with the over-the-counter products recommended by her hair stylist. She denies pulling her hair intentionally. Physical examination reveals no epidermal inflammation or erythema, and no fluorescence is detected under Wood’s lamp. A punch biopsy shows a peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate surrounding anagen follicles, resembling a swarm of bees. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of increasing swelling of her legs and generalized fatigue for 1 month. During this period she has also had a productive cough and shortness of breath. She has been unable to carry out her daily activities. She has a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections and chronic nasal congestion since childhood. She has a 3-month history of foul-smelling and greasy stools. She is at 4th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 104/64 mm Hg. Examination shows clubbing of her fingers and scoliosis. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Jugular venous distention is present. Inspiratory crackles are heard in the thorax. Cardiac examination shows a loud S2. The abdomen is mildly distended and the liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Hepato-jugular reflux is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old boy presents to his primary care physician with left knee pain for the past 6 weeks. He recently joined the field hockey team at his school. The pain is the most severe when he is running up and down the stairs at the school stadium. The pain decreases when he goes home and rests after practice. He additionally admits to tripping and landing on his left knee 5 days ago. Physical exam shows a knee with a healing abrasion over the left patella. The tibial tuberosity is tender to palpation. A radiograph of the knee is presented in figure A. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a swollen and painful knee. She says that she was exploring with her friends when she tripped and hit her knee against the ground. She didn't feel like she hit it very hard but it started swelling and becoming very painful. Her mom reports that she has always been prone to bleeding from very minor trauma and that others in the family have had similar problems. Based on clinical suspicion a coagulation panel was obtained showing a prothrombin time (PT) of 10 seconds (normal range 9-11 seconds), a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 45 seconds (normal 20-35 seconds), and a normal ristocetin cofactor assay (equivalent to bleeding time). Mixing tests with factor IX and XI do not show complementation, but mixing with factor VIII reverses the coagulation abnormality. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 3-month history of right flank pain. Urinalysis shows 60 RBC/hpf. Renal ultrasound shows a 3 cm, well-defined mass in the upper pole of the right kidney. A photomicrograph of a section of the resected mass is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man is brought to the physician by his father because of irritability, mood swings, and difficulty sleeping over the past 10 days. A few days ago, he quit his job and spent all of his savings on supplies for a “genius business plan.” He has been energetic despite sleeping only 1–2 hours each night. He was diagnosed with major depressive disorder 2 years ago. Mental status examination shows pressured speech, a labile affect, and flight of ideas. Throughout the examination, he repeatedly states “I feel great, I don't need to be here.” Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old man presents for a pre-employment health assessment. He has no complaints. His last annual physical examination 8 months ago was normal. He has no significant past medical history. He is a nonsmoker and says he quit all alcohol consumption last year. A complete hepatic biochemistry panel is performed, which is significant for a serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level 5 times the upper limit of the normal range. Immunologic tests are positive for antimitochondrial antibodies. A liver biopsy is performed and reveals an inflammatory infiltrate surrounding the biliary ducts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 43-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic in significant pain. He reports a sharp, stabbing electric-like pain on the right side of his face. The pain started suddenly 2 weeks ago. The pain is so excruciating that he can no longer laugh, speak, or eat his meals as these activities cause episodes of pain. He had to miss work last week as a result. His attacks last about 3 minutes and go away when he goes to sleep. He typically has 2–3 attacks per day now. The vital signs include: blood pressure 132/84 mm Hg, heart rate 79/min, and respiratory rate 14/min. A neurological examination shows no loss of crude touch, tactile touch, or pain sensations on the left side of the face. The pupillary light and accommodation reflexes are normal. There is no drooping of his mouth, ptosis, or anhidrosis noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician with fever, diarrhea and bilateral red eye for 7 days. Her parents noted that she has never had an episode of diarrhea this prolonged, but several other children at daycare had been ill. Her immunization history is up to date. Her vitals are normal except for a temperature of 37.5°C (99°F). A physical exam is significant for mild dehydration, preauricular adenopathy, and bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of persistent sadness for the past 2 months. During this period, he also has had difficulty sleeping and an increased appetite. He had similar episodes that occurred 2 years ago and 9 months ago that each lasted for 4 months. Between these episodes, he reported feeling very energetic and rested after 3 hours of sleep. He often went for long periods of time without eating. He works as a stock market trader and received a promotion 5 months ago. He regularly attends yoga classes on the weekends with his friends. On mental status examination, he has a blunted affect. He denies suicidal thoughts and illicit drug use. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern
options.E:
Major depressive disorder with atypical features
"

question: A 57-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after an episode of syncope. She states that she was at home when she suddenly felt weak and experienced back pain that has been persistent. She states that she vomited forcefully several times after the episode. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and depression. She smokes 1.5 packs of cigarettes per day and drinks 10 alcoholic beverages each night. Her temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 107/48 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. A chest radiograph is within normal limits. Physical exam is notable for abdominal tenderness and a woman resting in an antalgic position. Urinalysis is currently pending but reveals a concentrated urine sample. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old female presents to clinic complaining of coughing up small amounts of blood daily for the past week. She denies smoking, sick contacts, or recent travel. Chest radiographs demonstrates interstitial pneumonia with patchy alveolar infiltrates suggestive of multiple bleeding sites. Urinalysis is positive for blood and protein. A positive result is returned for anti-glomerular basement membrane antibody (anti-GBM Ab). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old girl is brought to a pediatric clinic by her mother because she had difficulty swallowing for 4 days. She was diagnosed with asthma 3 months ago and has been using an inhaler as directed by the pediatrician. The child does not have a fever or a cough and is not short of breath. She denies pain during swallowing. Her vital signs include: temperature 35.8℃ (96.5℉), respiratory rate 14/min, blood pressure 90/40 mm Hg, and pulse 80/min. The oral examination reveals a slightly raised white lesion over her tongue (as shown in the provided photograph) and oropharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old woman and recent immigrant from Brazil present to the clinic. She has no known past medical, past surgical, or family history. The patient admits to having several regular sexual partners. Today, she complains of a skin rash on her back. She is unclear when it started but became aware when one of her partners pointed it out. A review of systems is otherwise negative. Physical examination reveals numerous hypopigmented skin lesions over her upper back. When questioned, she states that they do not get darker after spending time in the sun. On examination, there is a 5 cm (1.9 in) patch of hypopigmented skin in the center of her back with a fine-scale overlying it. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An otherwise healthy 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of an itchy rash on his left nipple. The rash began as small vesicles on the nipple and spread to the areola. It has become a painful ulcer with yellow, watery discharge that is occasionally blood-tinged. He has asthma treated with theophylline and inhaled salbutamol. His younger sister was diagnosed with endometrial cancer a year ago. Examination shows a weeping, ulcerated lesion involving the entire left nipple-areolar complex. There are no breast masses, dimpling, or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man is brought to a counselor by his father after he found out that he is being physically abused by his wife. The father reports that he refuses to end the relationship with his wife despite the physical abuse. He says that he feels uneasy when his wife is not around. He adds, “I'm worried that if I leave him, my life will only get worse.” He has never been employed since they got married because he is convinced that nobody would hire her. His wife takes care of most household errands and pays all of the bills. Physical examination shows several bruises on the thighs and back. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman presents with 2 days of severe, generalized, abdominal pain that is worse after meals. She is also nauseated and reports occasional diarrhea mixed with blood. Apart from essential hypertension, her medical history is unremarkable. Her vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure of 145/92 mm Hg, and an irregularly irregular pulse of 105/min. Physical examination is only notable for mild periumbilical tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man presents to his physician concerned about wet spots on the inside part of his dress shirts, which he thinks it may be coming from one of his breasts. He states that it is painless and that the discharge is usually blood-tinged. He denies any history of malignancy in his family and states that he has been having regular periods since they first started at age 13. He does not have any children. The patient has normal vitals and denies any cough, fever. On exam, there are no palpable masses, and the patient does not have any erythema or induration. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old college student comes to the physician because he has been extremely sad for the past 3 weeks and has to cry constantly. Three weeks ago, his girlfriend left him after they were together for 4 years. He has no appetite and has had a 2.3-kg (5.1-lb) weight loss. He has missed several classes because he could not stop crying or get out of bed. He thinks about his ex-girlfriend all the time. He says that he experienced similar symptoms for about 2 months after previous relationships ended. The patient is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (100 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination he appears sad and cries easily. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with minor injuries sustained in a motor vehicle accident. She says that she is fine. She also witnessed the death of a teenage girl in the accident who was her sister’s friend. She is able to return to work within a few days. A month later, she presents being withdrawn and increasingly irritable. She says recently she has been experiencing depressed moods and higher anxiety than usual. She says that she feels guilty about the girl’s death, stating that she could have saved her if only she had acted quicker. She adds that she became extremely anxious while driving by a car accident on the freeway recently, and that, even when watching television or a movie, she feels panicked during a car crash scene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 35-year-old man who was recently ill with an upper respiratory infection presents to the emergency department with weakness in his lower limbs and difficulty breathing. His symptoms began with a burning sensation in his toes along with numbness. He claims that the weakness has been getting worse over the last few days and now involving his arms and face. Currently, he is unable to get up from the chair without some assistance. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), the blood pressure is 145/89 mm Hg, the heart rate is 99/min, the respiratory rate is 12/min, and the oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, he has diminished breath sounds on auscultation of bilateral lung fields with noticeably poor inspiratory effort. Palpation of the lower abdomen reveals a palpable bladder. Strength is 3 out of 5 symmetrically in the lower extremities bilaterally. The sensation is intact. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after an episode of syncope. She states that for the past month ever since starting a new job she has experienced an episode of syncope or near-syncope every morning while she is getting dressed. The patient states that she now gets dressed, shaves, and puts on her tie sitting down to avoid falling when she faints. She has never had this before and is concerned it is stress from her new job as she has been unemployed for the past 5 years. She is wondering if she can get a note for work since she was unable to head in today secondary to her presentation. The patient has no significant past medical history and is otherwise healthy. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 122/83 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Cardiopulmonary and neurologic exams are within normal limits. An initial ECG and laboratory values are unremarkable as well. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of fever and a cough for 3 days. Her mother reports that she has had multiple episodes of loose stools over the past 3 months. She has been treated for otitis media 4 times and bronchiolitis 3 times during the past 3 months. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation and the neonatal period was uncomplicated. She is at the 10th percentile for height and 3rd percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 126/min, and respirations are 35/min. Examination shows an erythematous scaly rash over the trunk and extremities. There are white patches on the tongue and buccal mucosa that bleed when scraped. Inspiratory crackles are heard in the right lung base. An x-ray of the chest shows an infiltrate in the right lower lobe and an absent thymic shadow. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 31-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of chest pain for the last 3 hours. She describes the pain as a sharp, substernal chest pain that radiates to the right shoulder; she says “Please help me. I'm having a heart attack.” She has been admitted to the hospital twice over the past week for evaluation of shortness of breath and abdominal pain but left the hospital the following day on both occasions. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol but is a known user of intravenous heroin. She has been living in a homeless shelter for the past 2 weeks after being evicted from her apartment for failure to pay rent. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The patient seems anxious and refuses a physical examination of her chest. Her cardiac troponin I concentration is 0.01 ng/mL (N = 0–0.01). An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific ST-T wave changes. While the physician is planning to discharge the patient, the patient reports numbness in her arm and insists on being admitted to the ward. On the following day, the patient leaves the hospital without informing the physician or the nursing staff. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of pain and stiffness in his fingers and knees. The stiffness lasts for about 10 minutes after he wakes up in the morning. He also reports that his knee pain is worse in the evening. He drinks one glass of wine daily. His only medication is acetaminophen. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers of both hands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and nausea. He has had one episode of nonbloody vomiting. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated, except for a blood pressure measurement of 150/90 mm Hg on his last prenatal visit. His first child was delivered vaginally; his second child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. He appears anxious and pale. His temperature is 36.1°C (96°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 92/65 mm Hg. Extremities are cool and clammy. Pelvic examination shows a rigid, tender uterus. The cervix is 30% effaced and 1 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is 100/min. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her stepmother because of multiple injuries. She says that she sustained these injuries while playing. Radiographic findings show multiple fractures in various stages of healing. Physical examination shows the findings in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 31-year-old woman is brought in to the clinic by her sister because she is concerned about her behavior since the death of their mother 2 months ago. The patient’s sister states that she has always been a ‘loner’ and preferred being by himself than socializing with others. Her social isolation resulted in him being ‘socially awkward’, as described by her family. However, 2 months ago, when she found out about the death of their mother, she showed little emotion and attended her funeral in jeans and a dirty T-shirt which upset the rest of their family. When asked about it, she shrugged and said she was in a hurry to get to the funeral and “just left the house with what I had on.” She does not speak much during the interview, allowing her sister to speak on her behalf. Her sister insists that she has ‘always been like this’, quiet and a complacent child who had no interest in playing with other children. The patient currently lives alone and spends her time repairing and building electrical appliances, and her sister is worried that her self-imposed isolation is making it ‘impossible for him to interact with other people normally’. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 75-year-old man presents to the physician with a complaint of a frequent need to void at nighttime, which has been disrupting his sleep. He notes embarrassingly that he is often unable to reach the bathroom in time, and experiences urinary leakage throughout the night as well as during the day. The patient undergoes urodynamic testing and a urinalysis is obtained which is normal. He is instructed by the physician to perform behavioral training to improve his bladder control. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis contributing to this patient’s symptoms?

A 77-year-old man is brought to the physician for gradually increasing confusion and difficulty walking for the past 4 months. His daughter is concerned because he has been forgetful and seems to be walking more slowly. He has been distracted during his weekly bridge games and his usual television shows. He has also had increasingly frequent episodes of urinary incontinence and now wears an adult diaper daily. He has hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 139/83 mmHg. He is confused and oriented only to person and place. He recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. He has a broad-based gait and takes short steps. Sensation is intact and muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 32-year-old man is brought into the emergency department at 5 AM because of chest pain that woke his up at 3 AM. The pain is constant and has not decreased in intensity during this time. He has no history of any similar episodes. He has systemic lupus erythematosus without major organ involvement. He takes prednisone, calcium, alendronate, and hydroxychloroquine. The blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, and the temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F). An examination of the chest including the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows no abnormalities. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest shows esophageal thickening near the mid-portion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old female graduate student comes to the physician for a two-month history of repeated thoughts and anxiety that she is going to be harmed by someone on the street. The anxiety worsened after witnessing a pedestrian getting hit by a car two weeks ago. She says, “That was a warning sign.” On her way to school, she now often leaves an hour earlier to take a detour and hide from people that she thinks might hurt him. She is burdened by her coursework and fears that her professors are meaning to fail him. She says her friends are concerned about him but that they do not understand because they were not present at the accident. The patient has no known history of psychiatric illness. On mental status exam, she is alert and oriented, and shows full range of affect. Thought processes and speech are organized. Her memory and attention are within normal limits. She denies auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 24-day-old infant boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of fever, vomiting, and diarrhea. He has fed less and has had decreased urine output for 1 day. He was born at 33 weeks' gestation and weighed 1400-g (3-lb 1-oz). His diet consists of breast milk and cow milk protein-based formula. Examination shows abdominal rigidity, distention, and absent bowel sounds. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. An x-ray of the abdomen shows gas within the intestinal wall and the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of blindness in his right eye that suddenly started 1 hour ago. He has no feeling of pain, pressure, or sensation of a foreign body in the right eye. He has a history of major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. The patient attends college and states that he has had a lot of stress lately due to relationship problems with his partner. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He does not use illicit drugs. He appears anxious. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows a normal-appearing eye with no redness. Slit lamp examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. A visual field test shows nonspecific visual field defects. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with several days of vomiting and diarrhea. He also complains of headaches, muscle aches, and fever, but denies tenesmus, urgency, and bloody diarrhea. Past medical history is insignificant. When asked about any recent travel he says that he just came back from a cruise ship vacation. His temperature is 37°C (98.6° F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 122/98 mm Hg. Physical examination is non-contributory. Microscopic examination of the stool is negative for ova or parasites. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of right-sided inguinal pain for the past 8 weeks. During this period, the patient has had increased pain during activities such as walking and standing. He has no nausea, vomiting, or fever. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a visible and palpable groin protrusion above the inguinal ligament on the right side. Bulging is felt during Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man is brought to the hospital by his mother because he has "not been herself" for the past 3 months. The patient says he hears voices in his head. The mother said that when he is talking to his daughter he can’t seem to make out what he is saying; it is as if his thoughts are disorganized. When talking with the patient, you notice a lack of energy and an apathetic affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 66-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department by her daughter for a change in behavior. Yesterday the patient seemed more confused than usual and was asking the same questions repetitively. Her symptoms have not improved over the past 24 hours, thus the decision to bring him in today. Last year, the patient was almost completely independent but she then suffered a "series of falls," after which her ability to care for himself declined.
