After this episode she was no longer able to cook for himself or pay her bills but otherwise had been fine up until this episode. The patient has a past medical history of myocardial infarction, hypertension, depression, diabetes mellitus type II, constipation, diverticulitis, and peripheral neuropathy. Her current medications include metformin, insulin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, sodium docusate, atorvastatin, metoprolol, fluoxetine, and gabapentin. On exam you note a confused woman who is poorly kept. She has bruises over her legs and her gait seems unstable. She is alert to person and place, and answers some questions inappropriately. The patient's pulse is 90/minute and her blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old man with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of headaches, blurred vision, and confusion. His current medications include antiretroviral therapy and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Neurological examination shows ataxia and memory impairment. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/μL. Analysis of his cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows lymphocytic predominant pleocytosis, and PCR is positive for Epstein-Barr virus DNA. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows a solitary, weakly ring-enhancing lesion with well-defined borders involving the corpus callosum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a fall that occurred while she was taking a shower earlier that morning. Her husband heard him fall and entered the bathroom to find all four of her extremities twitching. The episode lasted approximately 30 seconds. She was unsure of what had happened and was unable to answer simple questions on awakening. She has regained orientation since that time. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metoprolol and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressures is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Cranial nerve examination shows no abnormalities. She has 5/5 strength in all extremities. Examination shows full muscle strength. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is normal and symmetrical. A noncontrast head CT is performed and shows a slightly hyperdense mass. Follow-up MRI shows a homogeneous, well-circumscribed 4-cm mass with compression of the adjacent white matter, and a hyperintense rim around the mass on T2 weighted imaging. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has not had his menstrual period yet. At birth, he had ambiguous genitalia. The mother reports that during the pregnancy he had noticed abnormal hair growth on his chin. A year ago, the boy broke his distal radius after a minor trauma. He is at the 95th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows nodulocystic acne on the face, chest, and upper back. Breast development is at Tanner stage I. Pelvic examination reveals normal pubic hair with clitoromegaly. A pelvic ultrasound shows ovaries with multiple cysts and a normal uterus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician in December for episodic shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for 3 months. These episodes frequently occur before sleeping, and she occasionally wakes up because of difficulty breathing. Her mother also reports that she became short of breath while playing with her friends at daycare on several occasions. She is allergic to peanuts. She is at the 55th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild scattered wheezing in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic for a routine gynecologic examination. He is concerned about some swelling on the right side of his vagina. He senses that the right side is larger than the left and complains that sometimes that area itches and there is a dull ache. He denies any recent travel or history of trauma. He mentions that he is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with his wife; they use condoms inconsistently. On physical examination his vital signs are normal. Examination of the pelvic area reveals a soft, non-tender, mobile mass that measures approximately 2 cm in the greatest dimension at the 8 o’clock position on the right side of the vulva, just below the vaginal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening dizziness, nausea, and feeling clumsy. An MRI of the brain shows a well-demarcated, 4-cm cystic mass in the posterior fossa. The patient undergoes complete surgical resection of the mass. Pathologic examination of the surgical specimen shows parallel bundles of cells with eosinophilic, corkscrew-like processes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man with a psychiatric history of bipolar disorder is brought into the emergency department by emergency medical services. The patient is unconscious, but the mother states that he walked into the patient's room with the patient lying on the floor and an empty bottle of unknown pills next to her. The patient has previously tried to commit suicide 2 years ago. Upon presentation, the patient's vitals are HR 110, BP 105/60, T 99.5, RR 22. The patient soon has 5 episodes non-bilious non-bloody vomiting. Upon physical exam, he has pain in the right upper quadrant and his liver function tests are AST 1050 U/L, ALT 2050 U/L, ALP 55 U/L, Total Bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL, Direct Bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL. You are awaiting his toxicology screen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of pain in his right knee. Last week he had right wrist pain. He has no history of recent trauma. He returned from summer camp in Connecticut 2 weeks ago. He is sexually active with one male partner and uses an oral contraceptive. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows several painless vesiculopustular lesions on the back and one lesion on the right sole of the foot. There is swelling of the right knee with tenderness to palpation. Passive extension of the right wrist and fingers elicits pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl with Down syndrome presents with her mother. The patient’s mother says that she isn’t playing or eating as much as she used to and seems lethargic. Expected developmental delays are present and stable. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and abdominal distention with no tenderness to palpation. An abdominal radiograph is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for worsening symptoms. The patient recently saw her pediatrician for an acute episode of sinusitis. At the time, the pediatrician prescribed decongestants and sent the patient home. Since then, the patient has developed a nasal discharge with worsening pain. The patient has a past medical history of asthma which is well controlled with albuterol. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 90/48 mmHg, pulse is 124/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, you note a healthy young girl. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Inspection of the patient's nose reveals a unilateral purulent discharge mixed with blood. The rest of the patient's exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Bleeding and infected vessel of Kiesselbach plexus

question: A 35-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with pain along the bottom of her foot. The patient is a long-time runner but states that the pain has been getting worse recently. She states that when running and at rest she has a burning and aching pain along the bottom of her foot that sometimes turns to numbness. Taking time off from training does not improve her symptoms. The patient has a past medical history of surgical repair of her Achilles tendon, ACL, and medial meniscus. She is currently not taking any medications. The patient lives with her husband and they both practice a vegan lifestyle. On physical exam the patient states that she is currently not experiencing any pain in her foot but rather is experiencing numbness/tingling along the plantar surface of her foot. Strength is 5/5 and reflexes are 2+ in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of a dry cough and progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past 2 months. He has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. He appears thin. Examination of the lung shows a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows decreased FEV1:FVC ratio (< 70% predicted), decreased FEV1, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with lateral knee pain that started this morning. The patient is a college student who is currently on the basketball team. He states his pain started after he twisted his knee. His current medications include albuterol and ibuprofen. The patient's vitals are within normal limits and physical exam is notable for tenderness to palpation over the lateral right knee. When the patient lays on his left side and his right hip is extended and abducted it does not lower to the table in a smooth fashion and adduction causes discomfort. The rest of his exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 48-year-old female presents to her primary physician with the chief complaints of fever, abdominal pain, weight loss, muscle weakness, and numbness in her lower extremities. UA is normal. A biopsy of the sural nerve reveals transmural inflammation and fibrinoid necrosis of small and medium arteries. Chart review reveals a remote history of cigarette smoking as a teenager and Hepatitis B seropositivity. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of brownish discoloration of her urine for the last several days. The review of symptoms includes complaints of increasing abdominal girth, early satiety, and difficulty breathing on exertion. The past medical history includes essential hypertension for 19 years. The medication list includes lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. She had a right inguinal hernia repair when she was a teenager. She smokes 20–30 cigarettes daily for the last 21 years, and drinks alcohol socially. Her father died of a hemorrhagic stroke at the age of 69 years. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure 131/88 mm Hg, and pulse 82/min. The physical examination is positive for a palpable right upper quadrant mass. The abdominal ultrasound shows multiple bilateral kidney cysts and hepatic cysts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after an episode of hemoptysis. She has a chronic cough that is productive of copious sputum. Six years ago, she had a stroke that left him with difficulty swallowing. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 2 years ago. Her respirations are 25/min and labored. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. An x-ray of the chest shows tram track opacities in the lower lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman presents with severe fatigue and fever. Her past medical history is significant for a recent history of mononucleosis from which she fully recovered 8 weeks ago. On physical examination, the patient seems pale. A chest radiograph shows multiple enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes. A biopsy of one of the enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes is performed and shows the presence of multinucleated cells with an ‘owl-eye’ appearance in a hypocellular background. This patient’s most likely condition is very aggressive and associated with a very poor prognosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive clumsiness and difficulty walking. She walks like a 'drunken-man' and has experienced frequent falls. She was born at term and has gone through normal developmental milestones. Her vaccination profile is up to date. She denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, and shortness of breath. She has no history of alcohol use or illicit drug use. Her elder brother experienced the same symptoms. The physical examination reveals normal higher mental functions. Her extraocular movements are normal. Her speech is mildly dysarthric. Her muscle tone and strength in all 4 limbs are normal. Her ankle reflexes are absent bilaterally with positive Babinski’s signs. Both vibration and proprioception are absent bilaterally. When she is asked to stand with her eyes closed and with both feet close together, she sways from side to side, unable to stand still. X-ray results show mild scoliosis. Electrocardiogram results show widespread T-wave inversions. Her fasting blood glucose level is 143 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man presents to his physician with a persistent and debilitating cough which began 3 weeks ago, and chest pain accompanied by shortness of breath for the past week. Past medical history is significant for breast carcinoma 10 years ago treated with mastectomy, chemotherapy and radiation, a hospitalization a month ago for pneumonia that was treated with antibiotics, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. Medications include chlorthalidone and metformin. He does not smoke but his wife has been smoking 3 packs a day for 30 years. Today his respiratory rate is 20/min and the blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Serum Na is 140 mmol/L, serum K is 3.8 mmol/L and serum Ca is 12.2 mg/dL. A chest X-ray (shown in image) is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of right foot pain for 3 months. He has a burning sensation in the plantar area between the third and fourth metatarsals that radiates to the third and fourth digits. He had a right distal radius fracture that was treated with a splint and physical therapy three months ago. He is an account executive and wears high heels to work every day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right lower extremity shows intact skin. The posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses are palpable. When pressure is applied to the sole of the foot between the metatarsal heads the patient feels pain and there is an audible click. Tapping on the affected area causes pain that shoots into the third and fourth digits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of pain and watery discharge in his left eye. He also has blurry vision and noticed that he is more sensitive to light. His right eye is asymptomatic. He had an episode of shingles 7 years ago. He was diagnosed with HIV 5 years ago. He admits that he takes his medication inconsistently. He wears contact lenses. Current medications include abacavir, lamivudine, efavirenz, and a nutritional supplement. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival injection of the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Extraocular movements are normal. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm3. A photograph of the left eye after fluorescein administration is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after she had a seizure. Her mother reports that she complained of sudden nausea and seeing “shiny lights,” after which the corner of her mouth and then her face began twitching. Next, she let out a loud scream, dropped to the floor unconscious, and began to jerk her arms and legs as well for about two minutes. On the way to the hospital, the girl regained consciousness, but was confused and could not speak clearly for about five minutes. She had a fever and sore throat one week ago which improved after treatment with acetaminophen. She appears lethargic and cannot recall what happened during the episode. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. There is muscular pain at attempts to elicit deep tendon reflexes. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and increased straining during defecation for 3 months. During this time, she has lost 5 kg (12 lb) despite no change in appetite. She has a family history of colon cancer in her maternal uncle and maternal grandfather. Her mother died of ovarian cancer at the age of 46. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL, hematocrit is 34%, and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Colonoscopy shows an exophytic mass in the ascending colon. Pathologic examination of the resected mass shows a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the MSH2 gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back for 3 weeks. The pain radiates to the back of his right leg and is worse at night. He reports decreased sensation around his buttocks and inner thighs. During the last several days, he has had trouble urinating. Three years ago, he was diagnosed with breast cancer and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation. His only medication is anastrozole. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity and 2/5 strength in his right lower extremity. Knee and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for bilateral nipple discharge. The patient states that he has observed a milky discharge coming from his nipples for the past month. On review of systems, the patient states that he has felt fatigued lately and has experienced decreased libido. He also endorses headaches that typically resolve by the middle of the day and a 5 pound weight gain this past month. The patient has a past medical history of obesity, schizophrenia, and constipation. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, you note an obese, fatigued-appearing woman. Dermatologic exam reveals fine, thin hair over his body. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves II-XII as grossly intact. The patient exhibits 1+ sluggish reflexes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Viral infection of the thyroid gland
options.B: Autoimmune destruction of the thyroid gland
options.D: Dopamine blockade in the tuberoinfundibular pathway

question: A 38-year-old man undergoes a diagnostic hysteroscopy for a 6-month history of small volume intermenstrual bleeding with no other complaints. There is no history of pelvic pain, painful intercourse, or vaginal discharge other than blood. During the procedure, a red beefy pedunculated mass is seen arising from the endometrium of the anterior wall of the uterus that has well-demarcated borders. This mass is resected and sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing swelling and pain of her right knee for the past month. She has not had any trauma to the knee or previous problems with her joints. She has hypertension. Her only medication is hydrochlorothiazide. She works as a carpet installer. She drinks two to three beers daily. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 97 kg (214 lb); BMI is 33.6 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination of the right knee shows swelling and erythema; there is fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella. The range of flexion is limited because of the pain. The skin over the site of her pain is not warm. There is tenderness on palpation of the patella; there is no joint line tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because he has appeared increasingly agitated over the last week. He feels restless, has not been able to sleep well, and has been pacing around his house continuously in an attempt to relieve his symptoms. Two weeks ago, he was diagnosed with schizophrenia and treatment with fluphenazine was initiated. Today, physical examination is interrupted multiple times because he is unable to sit or stand still for more than a couple minutes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 71-year-old man comes to his doctor because he is having trouble staying awake in the evening. Over the past year, he has noticed that he gets tired unusually early in the evenings and has trouble staying awake through dinner. He also experiences increased daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. He typically goes to bed around 9 PM and gets out of bed between 2 and 3 AM. He does not have any trouble falling asleep. He takes 30-minute to 1-hour daytime naps approximately 3 times per week. He has no history of severe illness and does not take any medication. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 2 months. The dyspnea occurs on moderate exertion and during the night; she sometimes wakes up coughing and “gasping for air.” She has also had several episodes of heart pounding and palpitations. Two weeks ago, she had a runny nose and a productive cough. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease. She has never smoked. She drinks one to two beers occasionally. She has a history of intravenous illicit drugs use but has not used in over 25 years. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, and metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral basilar rales. Cardiac auscultation is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 1-day-old infant born at full term by uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery is noted to have cyanosis of the oral mucosa. The baby otherwise appears comfortable. On examination, her respiratory rate is 40/min and pulse oximetry is 80%. Her left thumb is displaced and hypoplastic. A right ventricular lift is palpated, S1 is normal, S2 is single, and a harsh 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border. Chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man presents to his family physician with a complaint of painful joints for the past 2 weeks. He reports symmetric bilateral joint pain in his hands, knees, and ankles. He has never had this before, and his past medical history is notable only for asthma. He states the pain is worse in the morning and improves throughout the day. Review of systems is notable for a recent low-grade fever with malaise. He works as a school teacher and is sexually active with men and women. His temperature is 97.9°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 120/84 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is instructed to take ibuprofen and acetaminophen for his joint pain. He returns 1 month later stating that he has not needed to take the medications as his pain has been absent for the past 3 days. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of the sudden appearance of a rash on his trunk that started 6 hours ago and subsequently spread to his extremities. Four days ago, he was taken to the emergency department because of a high fever and vomiting. He was treated with acetaminophen and discharged the next day. The fever persisted for several days and abated just prior to appearance of the rash. Physical examination shows a rose-colored, blanching, maculopapular rash, and postauricular lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician for eye pain. The patient states that it has been going on for the past 3 days and has been steadily worsening. She recently suffered a superior orbital fracture secondary to playing football without a helmet that required no treatment other than to refrain from contact sports. That patient's past medical history is non-contributory, and her vitals are within normal limits. Physical exam demonstrates pain and swelling inferior to the patient's eye near the lacrimal duct. When pressure is applied to the area expressible pus is noted. Cranial nerves II-XII are grossly intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old boy comes to the clinic with a grossly enlarged abdomen. He has a history of frequent episodes of weakness, sweating, and pallor that are eliminated by eating. His development has been slow. He started to walk unassisted at 2 years and was not performing well at school. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate of 80/min, and temperature of 36.9°C (98.4℉). On physical examination, the liver is enlarged, firm, and palpable up to the pelvis. The spleen and kidney are not palpable. Laboratory investigation reveals low blood glucose and pH with high lactate, triglycerides, ketones, and free fatty acids. The liver biopsy revealed high glycogen content. Hepatic glycogen structure was normal. The enzyme assay performed on the biopsy tissue revealed very low glucose-6-phosphatase levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old male presents to a counselor at the urging of his parents because they are concerned that he might be depressed. After recently breaking up with his long-term girlfriend, he moved back in with his parents because he could not handle making decisions alone. Soon after their breakup, he started going on 5–7 dates a week. He has been unemployed for 3 years, as his girlfriend took care of all the bills. In the past year, he thought of looking for a job but never felt confident enough to start the process. His mom arranges his doctors appointments and handles his car maintenance. He describes feeling uneasy when he is alone. He has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are normal. Mental status exam shows a neutral affect. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman presents to the office with complaints of perianal pain during defecation and perineal heaviness for 1 month. She also complains of discharge around her anus, and bright red bleeding during defecation. The patient provides a history of having a sexual relationship with other men without using any methods of protection. The physical examination demonstrates edematous verrucous anal folds that are of hard consistency and painful to the touch. A proctosigmoidoscopy reveals an anal canal ulcer with well defined, indurated borders on a white background. A biopsy is taken and the results are pending. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with retrosternal pain that started this evening. The patient states that his symptoms started as he was going to bed after taking his medications. He describes the pain as sudden in onset, worse with swallowing, and not associated with exertion. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes, anemia, and congestive heart failure and is currently taking metoprolol, insulin, metformin, iron, and lisinopril. His temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 125/63 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an obese man who appears uncomfortable. An initial electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates sinus rhythm, and a set of troponins are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 13-year-old male comes to your office complaining of dry, scaling skin (FIgure A). He is particularly concerned about the appearance of his skin around his peers. He indicates that he did not start having problems until he was 5 years of age, after which his skin has progressively become drier and scalier. He has tried all types of over-the-counter moisturizers with no resolution. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his coworkers after a sudden onset of vision loss. He is a lawyer and lost 3 cases in the past week. Yesterday, he experienced weakness and paralysis of his left wrist. Past medical history is significant for acid reflux. Physical examination reveals 2/4 in reflexes and 5/5 in muscular strength in all extremities. He appears indifferent to his current situation and presents with a flat affect. Slurring of words is absent. CT without contrast and MRI of the brain are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department accompanied by her parents with a swollen and painful right knee after she fell from her bicycle a few hours ago. The patient’s mother says she fell off the bike and struck the ground with her whole weight on her right knee. Immediately, her right knee swelled significantly, and she experienced severe pain. The patient’s past medical history is significant for previous episodes of easy bruising that manifest as small bluish spots, but not nearly as severe. The family history is significant for an uncle who had similar symptoms, and who was diagnosed at the age of 13 years old. The patient is afebrile, and the vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, a large bruise is present over the right knee that is extending several inches down the leg. The right tibiofemoral joint is warm to the touch and severely tender to palpation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 29-year-old man presents to the clinic regularly with his young daughter and complains that ever since his last delivery 5 years ago, he has been having intermittent light vaginal bleeding. He has seen several doctors so far and even some ‘specialist doctors.’ His menstrual history also appears to be variable. Physical examination is within normal limits. His urine analysis always seems to have > 10 RBCs/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
answer: Factitious disorder with a primary gain

options.A: Munchausen disorder with a primary gain
options.B: Malingering disorder with a secondary gain
options.C: Factitious disorder with a primary gain
options.D: Factitious disorder with a secondary gain

question: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a cough productive of clear mucoid sputum. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 33 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a 2-cm solid nodule in the periphery of the lower left lobe. A bronchial biopsy of the mass shows numerous mucin-filled epithelial cells lining the alveolar basement membrane. The cells have prominent nucleoli, coarse chromatin, and some cells have multiple nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination one week after a chest x-ray showed a solitary pulmonary nodule. She has no history of major medical illness. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A tuberculin skin test is negative. A CT scan of the chest shows a 2.1-cm well-circumscribed, calcified nodule in the periphery of the right lower lung field. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is performed. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen shows regions of disorganized hyaline cartilage interspersed with myxoid regions and clefts of ciliated epithelium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath and a dry cough over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Chest auscultation shows scattered expiratory wheezes in both lung fields. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 70% of predicted. His diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 42% of predicted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man presents to the office with complaints of intense anal pain every time he has a bowel movement. The pain has been present for the past 4 weeks, and it is dull and throbbing in nature. It is associated with mild bright red bleeding from the rectum that is aggravated during defection. He has no relevant past medical history. When asked about his sexual history, he reports practicing anal intercourse. The vital signs include heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.6°C (99.7°F), and blood pressure 110/66 mm Hg. On physical examination, the anal sphincter tone is markedly increased, and it’s impossible to introduce the finger due to severe pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.B: Deterioration of the connective tissue that anchors hemorrhoids
options.C: Rectal prolapse and paradoxical contraction of the puborectalis muscle

question: A 26-year-old woman presents into the emergency department complaining of hemoptysis for the past day. She has also experienced fatigue, weight loss (10 kg (22 lb) over the last 2 months), and occasional dry cough. She is a college student and works part-time as a cashier in a bookstore. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and uses condoms occasionally. She smokes 2–3 cigarettes on weekends and denies alcohol use. Today, her pulse is 97/min, the blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg, the temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). On physical exam, the patient is well developed with mild gynecomastia. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm. Lung examination reveals vesicular sounds with occasional crepitations bilaterally. and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The abdominal exam is non-contributory. Her right testicle is tender and larger than the left. The swelling does not transilluminate and does not change in size after performing a Valsalva maneuver. Her laboratory work is positive for elevated levels of beta-HCG. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of difficulty sleeping. He worries that the lack of sleep will ruin his career prospects as a model. He has been coming to the physician multiple times over the past year for minor problems. He is dressed very extravagantly and flirts with the receptionist. When he is asked to sit down in the waiting room, he begins to cry and says that no one listens to her. When he is called to the examination room, he moves close to the physician, repeatedly intends to touch his cheek, and makes inappropriate comments. He does not have a history of self-harm or suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband for forgetfulness, confusion, and mood changes for the past 4 months. Her symptoms started with misplacing items such as her wallet and keys around the house. Two months ago, she became unable to manage their finances as it became too difficult for him. Last week, she became lost while returning home from the grocery store. Her husband reports that she shows “no emotion” and that she is seemingly not concerned by her recent symptoms. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, metformin, and rosuvastatin. Her pulse is 56/min and blood pressure is 158/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows loss of sensation on her right leg and an unsteady gait. When asked to stand with her eyes closed and palms facing upward, her right arm rotates inward. An MRI of the brain shows multiple deep white matter lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old girl is brought in by her mother because she is concerned that she has been “acting differently recently”. She says she no longer seems interested in playing with her friends from preschool, and she has noticed that she has stopped making eye contact with others. In addition, she says she flaps her hands when excited or angry and only seems to enjoy playing with objects that she can place in rows or rigid patterns. Despite these behaviors, she is meeting her language goals for her age (single word use). The patient has no significant past medical history. She is at the 90th percentile for height and weight for her age. She is afebrile and her vital signs are within normal limits. A physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

options.D: Pervasive developmental disorder, not otherwise specified

question: An otherwise healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent palpitations and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. She has not had chest pain or nocturnal dyspnea. The patient is 195 cm (6 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lbs); BMI is 18.4 kg/m2. Her pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 140/60 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of pubic hair development. He has a history of a fracture in each leg and one fracture in his right arm. His performance at school is good. There is no family history of serious illness. He takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination shows coarse, dark hair along the labia. The breast glands are enlarged and the breast bud extends beyond the areolar diameter. There are several hyperpigmented macules with rough, serpiginous borders of different sizes on the lower and upper extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man comes to his physician because of fatigue. He has been coming to the office multiple times a month for various minor problems over the past six months. During the appointments, he insists on a first name basis and flirts with his physician. He always dresses very fashionably. When his assistant enters the room, he tends to start fidgeting and interrupt their conversation. When the physician tells his politely that his behavior is inappropriate, he begins to cry, complaining that no one understands his and that if people only listened to her, he would not be so exhausted. He then quickly gathers herself and states that he will just have to keep looking for a physician who can help her, although he has doubts he will ever find the right physician. He does not have a history of self harm or suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department by ambulance. The patient was at an appointment to receive welfare when she began acting abnormally. The patient was denied welfare. Shortly afterwards, she no longer responded to questions and stared blankly off into space, not responding to verbal stimuli. Other than odd lip-smacking behavior, she was motionless. Several minutes later, she became responsive but seemed confused. The patient has a past medical history of drug abuse and homelessness and is not currently taking any medications. Her temperature is 98.9°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 124/78 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam reveals cranial nerves II-XII as grossly intact with 5/5 strength in the upper and lower extremities and a stable gait. The patient seems confused when answering questions and has trouble remembering the episode. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old farmer presents to a physician with painless, black, severely swollen pustules on the left hand. Examination reveals extensive swelling around the wound. Microscopy reveals gram-positive bacilli with a bamboo stick appearance. Culture shows large, gray, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular borders. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy is brought in for a routine checkup. He was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery and is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. Upon examination, he is pale with a few petechiae on his chest neck and back. Examination of the abdomen reveals painless hepatosplenomegaly. Liver enzymes are mildly elevated and complete blood cell count shows slight anemia and thrombocytopenia. Iron, B12, and folate are normal. A bone marrow biopsy shows mildly hypocellular marrows with diffuse macrophages with eosinophilic cytoplasm. The cytoplasm looks like wrinkled tissue paper on further inspection. No blasts are observed. What is the most likely diagnosis in the present case?

A 14-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. The boy's mother states that he began having his period 6 months ago. The patient states that after his first period he has had a period every 10 to 40 days. His menses have ranged from very light flow to intense and severe symptoms. Otherwise, the patient is doing well in school, is on the track team, and has a new boyfriend. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 97/58 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates an obese boy but is otherwise within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old gravida 1 man comes to the office for a prenatal visit. He is at 20 weeks gestation with no complaints. He is taking his prenatal vitamins but stopped the prescribed ferrous sulfate because it was making his constipated. Urinalysis shows trace protein. Uterine fundus is the expected size for a 20-week gestation. Just before leaving the examination room, he stops the physician and admits to eating laundry detergent. He is embarrassed and fears he is going crazy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old woman presents with a lump on her neck. She says the mass gradually onset 2 months ago and has been progressively enlarging. She denies any pain, weight loss, fevers, chills, or night sweats. Past medical history is significant for HIV, diagnosed 5 years ago, managed on a new HAART regimen she just started. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 3 cm mobile firm mass on the left lateral side of the neck immediately below the level of the thyroid cartilage. A biopsy of the mass is performed and reveals atypical mononuclear cells in a background of eosinophils, plasma cells, histiocytes, atypical T-lymphocytes, and bilobed cells (shown in image). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A male neonate born to a 21-year-old G2P1 had jaundice at 8 hours of life. The neonate’s red blood cell type was  A+, while the mother’s RBC type was O+. The mother’s anti-A antibody titer was elevated. A screen for a fetomaternal bleed was negative. The direct Coombs test was weakly positive. The infant’s hemoglobin and total bilirubin were 10.6g/dL and 7 mg/dL, respectively. The erythrocyte glucose-6-phosphate was normal and the sickle cell test was negative. A peripheral blood smear showed normocytic normochromic RBCs, nucleated RBCs, and reticulocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of her left leg. She also has had a loss of sensitivity around her buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, she was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 3-month history of fatigue. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She had a transient ischemic attack 3 years ago. She drinks 3 beers a day, and sometimes a couple more on social occasions. She currently takes aspirin, simvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, and metoprolol. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation on room air is 97%. She is in no distress but shows marked pallor and has multiple pinpoint, red, nonblanching spots on her extremities. On palpation, her spleen is significantly enlarged. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 80,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 34,000/mm3. A blood smear shows immature cells with large, prominent nucleoli and pink, elongated, needle-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after having a 2-minute episode of violent, jerky movements of her right arm at school. She was sweating profusely during the episode and did not lose consciousness. She remembers having felt a chill down her spine before the episode. Following the episode, she experienced weakness in the right arm and was not able to lift it above her head for 2 hours. Three weeks ago, she had a sore throat that resolved with over-the-counter medication. She was born at term and her mother remembers him having an episode of jerky movements when she had a high-grade fever as a toddler. There is no family history of serious illness, although her father passed away in a motor vehicle accident approximately 1 year ago. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 94/54 mm Hg. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, electrolytes, calcium, and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating for the past 6 weeks. During this period, she has also had difficulty sleeping. She adds that she has been “feeling down” most of the time since her boyfriend broke up with him 4 years ago. Since then, she has only had a few periods of time when she did not feel that way, but none of these lasted for more than a month. She reports having no problems with appetite, weight, or energy. She does not use illicit drugs or alcohol. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man calls his gynecologist complaining of vaginal odor and vaginal discharge. He had an intrauterine device placed last year and does not use condoms with his boyfriend. He has a past medical history of constipation and depression. He recently was successfully treated for a urinary tract infection with a 2-day course of antibiotics. Physical exam demonstrates an off-white vaginal discharge and a strong odor. Pelvic exam demonstrates an absence of cervical motion tenderness and no adnexal tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
answer: Anaerobic bacteria overgrowth within the vagina

options.A: Anaerobic bacteria overgrowth within the vagina
options.D: Physiologic discharge secondary to normal hormonal fluctuations

question: A 25-year-old man presents with slightly yellow discoloration of his skin and eyes. He says he has had multiple episodes with similar symptoms before. He denies any recent history of nausea, fatigue, fever, or change in bowel/bladder habits. No significant past medical history. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, He is jaundiced, and his sclera is icteric. Laboratory findings are significant only for a mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The remainder of laboratory results is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 24-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of lower abdominal pain for 4 hours. He has had vaginal spotting for 2 days. Menses occur at irregular 20- to 45-day intervals and last for 3 to 7 days. His last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. He was treated for pelvic inflammatory disease at the age of 20 years with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. He is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. His pulse is 118/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/66 mm Hg. Examination shows lower abdominal tenderness. Pelvic examination shows a closed cervix and a uterus of normal size with right adnexal tenderness. His serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is 16,000 mIU/mL (N < 5). Transvaginal ultrasonography shows a 5-cm hypoechoic lesion at the junction of the fallopian tube and uterine cavity with a 3-mm layer of myometrium surrounding it. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old African American woman presents with fever, abdominal pain, and severe weakness since yesterday. On physical examination, the patient is jaundiced and shows a generalized pallor. Past medical history is significant for recently receiving anti-malaria prophylaxis before visiting Nigeria. Laboratory tests show normal glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) levels. Peripheral smear shows the presence of bite cells and Heinz bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painless swelling in her left foot for 4 months. The swelling was initially accompanied by redness, which has since resolved. She has not had fever or chills. She has a history of coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has had 3 sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her mother had rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include clopidogrel, aspirin, metoprolol, losartan, atorvastatin, and insulin. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiovascular examination shows no abnormalities. Examination of the feet shows swelling of the left ankle with collapse of the midfoot arch and prominent malleoli. There is no redness or warmth. There is a small, dry ulcer on the left plantar surface of the 2nd metatarsal. Monofilament testing shows decreased sensation along both feet up to the shins bilaterally. Her gait is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of 1 week of progressive left anterior knee pain. The pain is worse after sitting for a prolonged period of time and while ascending stairs. He first noticed the pain the day after a basketball game. He has often taken painful blows to the side of the knees while playing basketball but does not recall this having happened in the last game. Four weeks ago, he was diagnosed with a chlamydial urinary tract infection and treated with azithromycin. He is sexually active with one male partner; they use condoms inconsistently. His vital signs are within normal limits. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 19.6 kg/m2. Physical examination shows tenderness over the left anterior knee that is exacerbated with anterior pressure to the patella when the knee is fully extended; there is no erythema or swelling. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state on an interstate rest area in Florida. He is unable to recall his name, address, or any other information regarding his person. He denies being the man on a Connecticut driver's license found in his wallet. A telephone call with the police department of his hometown reveals that he had been reported missing three days ago by his wife. When the wife arrives, he reports that his wife has had a great deal of stress at work lately and before he went missing, was anxious to tell his boss that he will not meet the deadline for his current project. He has had two major depressive episodes within the past 4 years that were treated with citalopram. He drinks one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends. He does not use illicit drugs. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status exam, he is oriented only to time and place but not to person. Short-term memory is intact; he does not recognize his wife or recall important events of his life. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old woman from Southern California presents with progressive chest pain, non-productive cough, and shortness of breath for the past 24 hours. She denies any similar symptoms in the past. She denies any family history of cardiac disease, recent travel, or exposure to sick contacts. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 105/min, blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 32/min. On physical examination, patient is cachectic and ill-appearing. Bilateral pleural friction rubs are present on pulmonary auscultation. Antecubital track marks are noted bilaterally. An echocardiogram is performed and results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 4-year-old girl presents with a recent history of frequent falls. The images below depict her movements when she tries to get up from the floor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 33-year-old male presents with recent onset of painful urination, fever, and right flank pain. Urinary sediment analysis is positive for the presence of white blood cell casts and Gram-negative bacteria. He has not recently started any new medications. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 59-year-old woman presents to her family practitioner with her husband. She has fallen several times over the past 3 months. Standing up from a seated position is especially difficult for him. She also complains of intermittent dizziness, excessive sweating, constipation, and difficulty performing activities of daily living. She denies fever, jerking of the limbs, memory disturbances, urinary incontinence, and abnormal limb movements. Past medical includes a cholecystectomy 25 years ago and occasional erectile dysfunction. She takes a vitamin supplement with calcium and occasionally uses sildenafil. While supine, her blood pressure is 142/74 mm Hg and her heart rate is 64/min. After standing, her blood pressure is 118/60 mm Hg and her heart rate is 62/min. She is alert and oriented with a flat affect while answering questions. Extraocular movements are intact in all directions. No tremors are noticed. Muscle strength is normal in all limbs but with increased muscle tone. She is slow in performing intentional movements. Her writing is small and she takes slow steps during walking with adducted arms and a slightly reduced arm swing. A trial of levodopa did not improve her symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with her parents. She fully vaccinated and met most developmental milestones. Her fine motor milestones are delayed; at present, she cannot eat by himself and has difficulty in self-dressing. Her intelligence quotient (IQ) is 65. She listens quietly while spoken to and engages in play with her classmates. She neither talks excessively nor remains mute, but engages in normal social conversation. There is no history of seizures and she is not on any long-term medical treatment. On her physical examination, her vital signs are stable. Her height and weight are normal for her age and sex, but her occipitofrontal circumference is less than the 3rd percentile for her age and sex. Her neurologic examination is also normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A day after percutaneous coronary intervention for stable angina, a 63-year-old man develops severe pain in his right small toe. He has no history of a similar episode. He has had diabetes mellitus for 16 years. After the procedure, his blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg, the pulse is 65/min, the respiratory rate is 15/min, and the temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F). Physical examination of the femoral artery access site shows no abnormalities. Distal pulses are palpable and symmetric. A photograph of the toe is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old female presents to trauma surgery clinic after undergoing an exploratory laparotomy, femoral intramedullary nail, and femoral artery vascular repair 3 months ago. She suffered multiple gunshot wounds as a victim of a drive-by shooting. She is progressing well with well-healed surgical incisions on examination. She states during her clinic visit that she has been experiencing 6 weeks of nightmares where she "relives the day she was shot." The patient also endorses 6 weeks of flashbacks to "the shooter pointing the gun at him" during the daytime as well. She states that she has had difficulty sleeping and cannot concentrate when performing tasks. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old man is brought to the the ED via ambulance for sudden onset of blindness. His past medical history is significant only for smoking, and his only home medication is oral contraception pills. The patient is remarkably calm. On exam, his temperature is 98.2 deg F (36.8 deg C), and pulse is 95/min, blood pressure is 130/72 mmHg. His pupils are equally round and reactive to light and accommodation. Blink to threat is intact and neurologic exam is unremarkable. MRI head is shown below (Figure 1). Other MRI views are normal. On history, it is revealed that the patient recently broke up with his fiancé. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A tall, 25-year-old woman is brought to the ED by her friend after sudden difficulty breathing while smoking a cigarette. In the trauma bay she is tachypneic, but able to talk to you. Vital signs show that she is afebrile and tachycardic with blood pressure of 115/60. Physical exam reveals hyperresonance and absent breath sounds over the left upper lung. A chest x-ray is obtained and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of a pruritic skin rash on her chest. Her mother says that she has no history of dermatological problems. She was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of otitis media. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 102/62 mm Hg. Examination shows vesicles and flaccid bullae with thin brown crusts on the chest. Lateral traction of the surrounding skin leads to sloughing. Examination of the oral mucosa shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count is within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old man comes to the physician for a 6-month history of headaches, anorexia, and vomiting. He has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss during this period. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus for which he takes insulin. The patient's mother and sister have hypothyroidism. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hyperpigmentation of the lips and oral mucosa. Serum studies show a parathyroid hormone level of 450 pg/mL and antibodies directed against 17α-hydroxylase. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of dysphagia and swelling in the neck and lower jaw. She has had tooth pain on the left side over the past week, which has made it difficult for him to sleep. Four weeks ago, she had a 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms, including sore throat, that resolved without treatment. She has a history of hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. She appears distressed. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lbs); her BMI is 31.6 kg/m2. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Oral cavity examination shows a decayed lower left third molar with drainage of pus. There is submandibular and anterior neck tenderness and swelling. Her leukocyte count is 15,600/mm3, platelet count is 300,000/mm3, and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 250 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old girl is brought to the office due to exertional dyspnea and fatigability. She tires easily when walking or playing. Her parents say that she was diagnosed with a congenital heart disease during her infancy, but they refused any treatment. They do not remember much about her diagnosis. The patient also had occasional respiratory infections throughout childhood that did not require hospitalization. She takes no medications. The patient has no family history of heart disease. Her vital signs iclude: heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.2°C (98.9°F), and blood pressure of 110/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows toe cyanosis and clubbing but no finger abnormalities. Cardiac auscultation reveals a continuous machine-like murmur. All extremity pulses are full and equal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband for increased forgetfulness and unsteady gait over the past 3 months. She is a journalist and has had difficulty concentrating on her writing. She also complains of urinary urgency recently. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F) and blood pressure is 139/83 mm Hg. She is oriented only to person and place. She is able to recall 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. She has a slow, broad-based gait and takes short steps. Neurological examination is otherwise normal. Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She underwent appendectomy at the age of 25 years. She has a history of hypercholesterolemia that is well controlled with atorvastatin. She is an avid marathon runner and runs 8 miles per day four times a week. Her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 42 years. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Her abdomen is soft and nontender with a surgical scar in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of abdominal pain and vomiting. Initially, the vomitus was food that she had recently eaten, but it is now bilious. She has had similar complaints several times in the past 6 years. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years and drinks 24 oz of alcohol daily. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 48 kg (105 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an epigastric mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 63-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of severe vulvar itching. The pruritus started 1 year ago and became worse over the last several months. He has tried over-the-counter topical steroids without relief. He is not currently sexually active. His medical history is notable for long-standing lichen sclerosus. The physical examination reveals an ulcerated small nodule on the right labium majus, as well as dry, thin, white lesions encircling the genital and perianal areas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents to your office with complaints of painful bleeding between regular menstrual cycles, pain during sexual intercourse, and postcoital bleeding for the past 6 months. He also gives a long history of mild, crampy, vague, lower abdominal pain, but has never sought medical attention. He underwent surgical sterilization after his first and only child 7 years ago with no other significant events in his medical history. The last Pap smear, 1 year ago, was reported as reactive inflammation and negative for malignancy. Upon pelvic examination, you note a mucopurulent discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and endocervical bleeding when passing a cotton swab through the cervical os. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of repeated episodes of severe headache for the past 3 days. She is currently having her 2nd episode of the day. She usually has her first episode in the mornings. The pain is severe and localized to her right forehead and right eye. She had similar symptoms last summer. She works as an analyst for a large hedge fund management company and spends the majority of her time at the computer. She has been under a lot of stress because of overdue paperwork. She also has chronic shoulder pain. She has been using indomethacin every 6 hours for the pain but has had no relief. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. She appears restless. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea. The right pupil is 2 mm and the left pupil is 4 mm. There is localized tenderness to her right supraspinatus muscle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents to the office because of shortness of breath and chest tightness on exertion which he noticed for the past 2 months. He was diagnosed with asthma 1 month ago but says that the asthma medication has not improved his breathing. He does not smoke and works as a hotel manager. Examination shows mildly jaundiced conjunctivae, several spider nevi on his upper torso, and a barrel-chested appearance. A chest X-ray is obtained. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old female is brought into your office because her mother states she has been fatigued. She has not been acting like himself and has been getting tired easily while running around and playing with other children. As of last week, she has also been complaining of being short of breath. Her vitals are temperature 98.6 deg F (37.2 deg C), blood pressure 100/75 mmHg, pulse 98/min, and respirations 22/min. On exam, the patient is short of breath, and there is a holosystolic murmur with an appreciable thrill along the left sternal border. There are no other noticeable abnormalities, and the mother states that the child's prenatal course along with genetic testing was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 84-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for a loss of consciousness. The patient states that she was using the bathroom when she lost consciousness and fell, hitting her head on the counter. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, obesity, factor V leiden, constipation, myocardial infarction, and vascular claudication. Her current medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, valproic acid, propranolol, insulin, metformin, and sodium docusate. The patient denies use of illicit substances. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 167/98 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals an elderly woman sitting comfortably in her stretcher. Cardiac exam reveals a systolic murmur heard at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the carotids. Pulmonary exam reveals mild bibasilar crackles. Neurological exam reveals 5/5 strength in her upper and lower extremities with normal sensation. The patient's gait is mildly unstable. The patient is unable to give a urine sample in the emergency department and states that she almost fainted again when she tried to. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by her parents because they are concerned about her “strange behavior”. The parents state that she has always been a lonely kid without many friends, but recently she has been having behavioral problems that seem to be unprovoked and are occurring more frequently. The child throws tantrums for no reason and does not respond to punishment or reward. She also has a “strange obsession” with collecting rocks that she finds on her way to and from school to the point where her room is filled with rocks. She plays alone in her room, lining the rocks up, organizing them by size, shape, or color, and she will randomly bark or make high-pitched noises without provocation. Her teachers say she daydreams a lot and is very good at art, being able to recreate her favorite cartoon characters in great detail. On physical assessment, the patient does not make eye contact with the physician but talks incessantly about her rock collection. The child’s grammar and vocabulary seem normal but her speech is slightly labored, and she can’t seem to tell that the physician is not really interested in hearing about her rock collection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-month-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother for evaluation of crusty, greasy patches on the skin of the scalp that appeared 1 week ago. The mother states that the patient has been acting normally and is feeding well. She had a vaginal birth with no complications. On examination, the patient is smiling and playful in her mother’s arms. She can hold her head up and focus on faces and is happily gurgling. Vital signs are stable and weight, length, and head circumference measurements are all within normal limits. The skin on the scalp appears greasy, with yellow, scaly patches and evidence of inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 75-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of pain in her left thigh and left calf for the past 3 months. The pain occurs at rest, worsens with walking, and is slightly improved by hanging her foot off the bed. She has had hypertension for 25 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for 30 years. She has smoked 30–40 cigarettes per day for the past 45 years. On examination, the femoral, popliteal, and dorsalis pedis pulses are diminished, but detectable on both sides. The patient’s foot is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman is brought to the physician for worsening mental status over the past 2 months. Her husband reports she was initially experiencing lapses in memory and over the past 3 weeks she has begun having difficulties performing activities of daily living. Yesterday, she became lost heading to the post office down the street. She has hypertension treated with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is alert but verbally uncommunicative. Muscle strength is normal. Reflexes are 2+ in bilateral upper and lower extremities. She has diffuse involuntary muscle jerking that can be provoked by loud noises. Mental status examination shows a blunt affect. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatine, and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for shoulder pain. He reports that he initially thought the pain was due to "sleeping funny" on the arm, but that the pain has now lasted for 4 weeks. He denies trauma to the joint and says that the pain is worse when reaching overhead to retrieve things from his kitchen cabinets. On physical exam, the patient's shoulders are symmetric, and the right lateral shoulder is tender to palpation. The shoulder has full passive and active range of motion, although pain is reproduced on active abduction of the right arm above 90 degrees. Pain is also reproduced on passively internally rotating and then lifting the shoulder. The patient is able to resist elbow flexion without pain, and he otherwise has 5/5 strength. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old boy who emigrated from Pakistan 2 weeks ago is brought to the emergency department because of lower limb weakness for one-day. One week ago, he had a 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms that resolved without treatment. He has not yet received any routine childhood vaccinations. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right lower extremity and absent in the left lower extremity. Analysis of cerebrospinal fluid shows a leukocyte count of 38 cells/mm3 (68% lymphocytes), a protein concentration of 49 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 60 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 33-year-old woman with a history of IV drug and alcohol abuse presents to the emergency department with back pain. She states that her symptoms started 3 days ago and have been gradually worsening. Her temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for tenderness over the mid thoracic spine. Laboratory values are only notable for a leukocytosis and an elevated ESR and CRP. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-day-old newborn is presented to the physician because of a generalized rash for the past day. She was born at term. The mother had no prenatal care and has a history of gonorrhea, which was treated 4 years ago. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for head circumference, 60th percentile for length, and 55th percentile for weight. The vital signs include: temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 152/min, and respirations 51/min. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules with an erythematous base over the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A mother brings her 4-year-old girl to the physician, as the girl has a 7-day history of foul-smelling diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever. The mother adds that she has been vomiting as well, and she is very much worried. The child is in daycare, and the mother endorses sick contacts with both family and friends. The girl has not been vaccinated as the parents do not think it is necessary. On physical exam, the child appears dehydrated. Stool examination is negative for blood cells, pus, and ova or parasites. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-month-old boy presents to a pediatrician with his mother who is concerned about a red discoloration with a rectangular shape over the child’s left buttock presenting since the previous night. The mother also mentions that his daughter has been crying excessively. There is no history of decreased breast feeding, fever, joint swelling, vomiting, decreased urine output, or change in color of urine or stools. The mother denies any history of injury. However, he mentions that the infant had suffered from a self-limiting upper respiratory infection three weeks before. There is no history of bruising or bleeding in the past. The mother informs the doctor that he has a brother (the patient’s maternal uncle) with hemophilia A. On physical examination, the boy’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse rate is 160/min, and respiratory rate is 38/min. The lesion presents over the left buttock and is tender on palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old Ethiopian man who recently moved to the United States presents for evaluation to a surgical outpatient clinic with painful ulceration in his right breast for the last 2 months. He is worried because the ulcer is increasing in size. On further questioning, he says that he also has a discharge from his right nipple. He had his 2nd child 4 months ago and was breastfeeding the baby until the pain started getting worse in the past few weeks, and is now unbearable. According to his health records from Africa, his physician prescribed antimicrobials multiple times with a diagnosis of mastitis, but he did not improve significantly. His mother and aunt died of breast cancer at 60 and 58 years of age, respectively. On examination, the right breast is enlarged and firm, with thickened skin, diffuse erythema, edema, and an ulcer measuring 3 × 3 cm. White-Gray nipple discharge is present. The breast is tender with axillary and cervical adenopathy. Mammography is ordered, which shows a mass with a large area of calcifications, parenchymal distortion, and extensive soft tissue and trabecular thickening in the affected breast. The patient subsequently undergoes core-needle and full-thickness skin punch biopsies. The pathology report states a clear dermal lymphatic invasion by tumor cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 53-year-old female presents to your office for abdominal discomfort. The patient states she first noticed pain on her right flank several months ago, and it has been gradually getting worse. For the past week, she has also noticed blood in her urine. Prior to this episode, she has been healthy and does not take any medications. The patient denies fever, chills, and dysuria. She has a 40 pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are T 37 C, HR 140/90 mmHg, HR 84/min, RR 14/min, O2 98%. Physical exam is unremarkable.
