CBC reveals a hemoglobin of 17 and hematocrit of 51%, and urinalysis is positive for red blood cells, negative for leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old man visits your office with his pathology report after being subjected to total abdominal hysterectomy a month ago. He explains that he went through this procedure after a long history of lower abdominal pain that worsened during menses and heavy menstrual bleeding. He is a mother of 5 children, and they are all delivered by cesarean section. The pathology gross examination report and microscopic examination report from the specimen from surgery describes an enlarged, globular uterus with invading clusters of endometrial tissue within the myometrium. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of bleeding from the nipple of his right breast for 3 months. There is no bleeding from the other breast. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and lasts for 5 days with moderate flow. His last menstrual period was 1 week ago. His mother died of breast cancer at the age of 53 years. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Breast examination shows bleeding of the right breast on application of pressure with no palpable mass. The left breast shows no abnormalities. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Ultrasonography shows a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A concerned mother presents to clinic stating that her 14-year-old son has not gone through her growth spurt. She states that, although shorter, she had been growing at the same rate as her peers until the past year. There is no evidence of delayed puberty in the mother, but the father's history is unknown. The patient has no complaints. On physical exam, the patient is a healthy-appearing 14-year-old girl whose height is below the third percentile and whose weight is at the 50th percentile. Her bone age is determined to be 11 years. A laboratory workup, including thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of blisters on his forearms and pain during sexual intercourse. His only medications are metformin and glyburide. Examination reveals multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearms and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 47-year-old taxi driver visits an ophthalmologist after failing a routine eye test for her driver’s license renewal. The patient reports a slight blurring of her vision, headaches, and occasional dizziness for the past month. On further questioning, she admits to feeling tired and out of sorts most of the time. She attributes it to working overtime and experiencing stress at home. She also complains of decreased libido, decreased appetite, and some weight loss over the past 2 months. There is no history of cold intolerance or hoarseness of voice. On examination, the patient appears malnourished. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is firm and normal in size. Genital examination reveals small, soft testes with patchy pubic hair. Ophthalmic examination reveals decreased visual acuity. The visual field of the patient is shown in the image (black indicates loss of vision while white indicates full vision). Her laboratory results are significant for decreased serum ACTH, decreased serum cortisol, normal serum TSH, normal serum T4, decreased serum LH, decreased serum FSH, and decreased serum GH. On suspicions raised by the patient’s physical examination and lab studies, the clinician orders a brain MRI. The scan shows a pituitary macroadenoma impinging on and displacing the optic chiasm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A mother brings his 3-year-old son to the doctor because he is worried that he might be harming himself by constantly banging his head on the wall. He has been exhibiting this behavior for a few months. He is also worried because he has started to speak less than he used to and does not respond when his name is called. He seems aloof during playtime with other children and seems to have lost interest in most of his toys. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old woman comes to the office complaining of dysphagia that started 4-5 months ago. She reports that she initially she had difficulty swallowing only solid foods. More recently, she has noticed some trouble swallowing liquids. The patient also complains of fatigue, a chronic cough that worsens at night, and burning chest pain that occurs after she eats. She says that she has used over-the-counter antacids for “years” with mild relief. She denies any change in diet, but says she has “gone down a pant size or 2.” The patient has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes amlodipine and atorvastatin. She smoked 1 pack of cigarettes a day for 12 years while in the military but quit 35 years ago. She drinks 1-2 beers on the weekend while she is golfing with her friends. Her diet consists mostly of pasta, pizza, and steak. The patient's temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 143/91 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Her BMI is 32 kg/m^2. Physical examination reveals an obese woman in no acute distress. No masses or enlarged lymph nodes are appreciated upon palpation of the neck. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. An endoscopy is performed, which identifies a lower esophageal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old boy presents to the office with his parents who are concerned about their daughter and slow, progressive changes in his behavior. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and was meeting all developmental milestones until about 2 years ago. At one point he had a vocabulary of several words and now he verbalizes in grunts. He also flaps his hands in a repeated motion and has difficulty walking. His parents have tried several home therapies to improve their daughter's symptoms including restricted diets, hydrotherapy, and a variety of nutritional supplements. The vital signs include: heart rate 90/min, respiratory rate 22/min, blood pressure 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F). On physical exam, he is well nourished and stares absently out the window. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. He has mild scoliosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man presents with erosions in his mouth that are persistent and painful. He says that symptoms appeared gradually 1 week ago and have progressively worsened. He also notes that, several days ago, flaccid blisters appeared on his skin, which almost immediately transformed to erosions as well. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. The patient was the back seat restrained passenger in a vehicle that was rear ended at 25 miles/hour. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Her temperature is 97.5°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 97/68 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is subsequently worked up receiving a chest radiograph, ECG, FAST exam, and serum chemistries. A cardiac catheterization reveals equilibration in diastolic pressure across all cardiac chambers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is no family history of serious illness. She works as an engineer at a local company. She does not smoke. She drinks one glass of red wine every other day. She does not use illicit drugs. Her only medication is metformin. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show an aspartate aminotransferase concentration of 100 U/L and an alanine aminotransferase concentration of 130 U/L. Liver biopsy shows hepatocyte ballooning degeneration, as well as inflammatory infiltrates with scattered lymphocytes, neutrophils, and Kupffer cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old man thinks poorly of herself and is extremely sensitive to criticism. He is socially inhibited and has never had a romantic relationship, although he desires one. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 64-year-old man with a history of rheumatic fever presents to his primary care clinician complaining of excessive fatigue with walking and difficulty lying flat. He had no prior physical limitations, but recently has been unable to walk more than 3 blocks without needing to stop and rest. His cardiac exam is notable for a late diastolic murmur heard best at the apex in the left lateral decubitus position with no radiation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for a headache. The patient states her symptoms started thirty minutes ago. She states she experienced a sudden and severe headache while painting her house, causing him to fall of the ladder and hit her head. She has also experienced two episodes of vomiting and difficulty walking since the fall. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, obesity, and atrial fibrillation. Her current medications include lisinopril, rivaroxaban, atorvastatin, and metformin. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 150/105 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the patient localizes her headache to the back of her head. Cardiac exam reveals a normal rate and rhythm. Pulmonary exam reveals minor bibasilar crackles. Neurological exam is notable for minor weakness of the muscles of facial expression. Examination of cranial nerve three reveals a notable nystagmus. Heel to shin exam is abnormal bilaterally. The patient's gait is notably ataxic. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is currently pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old woman presents to her physician for difficulty swallowing for 2 months. She describes food getting stuck down her windpipe and has been feeling very anxious around meal time because she is thinking that she may have esophageal cancer. She has had an influenza-like infection that lasted about 6 weeks in the past 3 months which exacerbated her asthma attacks. She used her puffers to relieve her symptoms and did not seek medical treatment. She is otherwise healthy. On examination, her blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg, respirations are 17/min, pulse is 78/min, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F). There is no evidence of enlarged lymph nodes or a sore throat. On palpation, the thyroid gland is enlarged and tender. She is a non-smoker with a BMI of 25 kg/m2. She has not used any medications recently. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of difficulty swallowing of both solids and liquids for 1 month. During the past 5 months, she has also had increased weakness of her hands and legs. She sails regularly and is unable to hold the ropes as tightly as before. Ten years ago, she was involved in a motor vehicle collision. Examination shows atrophy of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. There is muscle stiffness in the left lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right upper and lower extremities, 3+ in the left upper extremity, and 4+ in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left foot. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration is intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

question: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with hematuria and hemoptysis that started in the morning. She notes that she has had frequent lung infections throughout her adult life, the most recent being 2 weeks ago. She also mentions that she has had hematuria twice before but never as severe as she is having currently. Her medical history is otherwise non-significant, and her only medication is acetaminophen as needed. Her blood pressure is 136/92 mm Hg, heart rate is 86/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Chest radiography shows a resolving right middle lobe airspace opacity. Her initial laboratory tests are notable for elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level. While in the examination room, the patient develops a spontaneous nosebleed. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman with asthma comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath and cough. She also has a history of chronic sinusitis and foot drop. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and inhaled corticosteroid. Physical examination shows diffuse wheezing over both lung fields and tender subcutaneous nodules on both elbows. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 23,000/mm3 with 26% eosinophils and a serum creatinine of 1.7 mg/dL. Urine microscopy shows red blood cell casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department acutely confused. The patient was found down at a local construction site by her coworkers. The patient has a past medical history of a seizure disorder and schizophrenia and is currently taking haloperidol. She had recent surgery 2 months ago to remove an inflamed appendix. Her temperature is 105°F (40.6°C), blood pressure is 120/84 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a confused woman who cannot answer questions. Her clothes are drenched in sweat. She is not making purposeful movements with her extremities although no focal neurological deficits are clearly apparent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after a loss of consciousness. Her husband said she suddenly fainted while she was adjusting her necktie. She regained consciousness within 30 seconds and was fully alert and oriented. She has had two similar episodes in the last year. She has anxiety and takes alprazolam as needed. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks two glasses of wine with dinner each night. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 70/min and regular, respirations are 13/min, blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg when supine and 122/80 mm Hg while standing. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count shows no abnormalities. Bedside cardiac monitoring shows infrequent premature ventricular contractions and QRS voltage below 5 mm in leads II and III. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3175-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at 37 weeks to a 26-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy had been uncomplicated. The mother had no prenatal care. He immigrated to the US from Brazil 2 years ago. Immunization records are not available. One day after delivery, the newborn's temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 182/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 82/60 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There are several discolored areas on the skin that are non-blanchable upon pressure application. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass his auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic for a recurrent rash that has remitted and relapsed over the last 2 years. The patient states that he has tried multiple home remedies when he has flare-ups, to no avail. The patient is wary of medical care and has not seen a doctor in at least 15 years. On examination, he has multiple disc-shaped, erythematous lesions on his neck, progressing into his hairline. The patient notes no other symptoms. Lab work is performed and is positive for antinuclear antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with complaints of several episodes of palpitations accompanied by panic attacks over the last month. He also is concerned about many instances over the past few weeks where food has been getting stuck in his throat and he has had trouble swallowing. He denies any prior medical problems and reports a family history of cancer in his mother and maternal grandfather but cannot recall any details regarding the type of cancer(s) or age of diagnosis. His vital signs at today's visit are as follows: T 37.6 deg C, HR 106, BP 158/104, RR 16, SpO2 97%. Physical examination is significant for a nodule on the anterior portion of the neck that moves with swallowing, accompanied by mild lymphadenopathy. A preliminary work-up is initiated, which shows hypercalcemia, elevated baseline calcitonin, and an inappropriately elevated PTH level. Diagnostic imaging shows bilateral adrenal lesions on an MRI of the abdomen/pelvis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing generalized fatigue for 3 months. She is having more difficulty with keeping up with her activities of daily living and has lost 2.5 kg (5.5 lb) over the past month. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She does not smoke and drinks two to three beers on weekends. Her medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 125/73 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hematocrit is 27.3%, leukocyte count is 4500/mm3, and platelet count is 102,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows numerous blast cells that stain positive for myeloperoxidase, CD33, and CD34. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of weakness that has progressively worsened over the past 2 weeks. He states that he has a hard time lifting both his arms but that they function normally. He notes no history of trauma or other deficits. On examination, that patient has 2/5 muscle strength on shoulder shrug and arm abduction bilaterally, but all other neurological exam findings are normal. You notice some skin changes and ask the patient about them. He states that he has had a rash around his eyes as well as on his lower face, going down to his neck and chest. He notes that the rashes started around the same time as the weakness began. Labs are drawn and a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling of his hands and wrists for 3 days. He has been unable to continue his daily activities like writing or driving. He has had a nonpruritic generalized rash for 4 days. He had fever and a runny nose one week ago which resolved with over-the-counter medication. He is sexually active with a male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. He works as an attendant at an amusement park. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the wrists as well as the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Range of motion at the wrists is limited. A lacy macular rash is noted over the trunk and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and anti-nuclear antibody and anti-dsDNA serology, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she claims to have spoken to her recently-deceased grandfather. The grandfather, who lived with the family and frequently watched the girl for her parents, died 2 months ago. The girl was taken out of preschool for 3 days after her grandfather's death but has since returned. Her teachers report that the girl is currently doing well, completing her assignments, and engaging in play with other children. When asked about how she feels, the girl becomes tearful and says, “I miss my grandpa. I sometimes talk to him when my mom is not around.” Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for evaluation because of extreme irritability, fatigue, and loss of appetite for 3 weeks. Five months ago, her grandfather, whom she was very close to, passed away from chronic lymphocytic leukemia. She used to enjoy playing soccer but quit her soccer team last week. When she comes home from school she goes straight to bed and sleeps for 11–12 hours each night. She previously had good grades, but her teachers report that she has been disrespectful and distracted in class and failed an exam last week. She tried alcohol twice at a party last year and she has never smoked cigarettes. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she avoids making eye contact but cooperates with the exam. Her affect is limited and she describes an irritable mood. She is easily distracted and has a difficult time focusing for an extended conversation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his coach, 30 minutes after injuring his left knee while playing field hockey. He was tackled from the left side and has been unable to bear weight on his left leg since the accident. He fears the left knee may be unstable upon standing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The medial joint line is tender to touch. The patient's hip is slightly flexed and abducted, and the knee is slightly flexed while the patient is in the supine position. Gentle valgus stress is applied across the left knee and medial joint laxity is noted. The remainder of the examination shows no further abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with constant and gnawing lower abdominal pain for 2 days. The pain has been steadily worsening in intensity. She says the pain occasionally radiates to her lower back and groin bilaterally. While she cannot identify any aggravating factors, she feels that the pain improves with her knees flexed. Her medical history is notable for hypertension which is well controlled with medications. She has smoked 40–50 cigarettes daily for 35 years. On examination, there is a palpable pulsatile mass just left of midline below the umbilicus. She is immediately referred for definitive management but during transfer, she becomes hypotensive and unresponsive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old girl presents with a 7-day history of fever and abdominal pain for the past 4 days. Past medical history is significant for an exchange transfusion for neonatal hyperbilirubinemia and recurrent attacks of pallor during the course of upper respiratory tract infections. Her vital signs include: blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg, pulse 105/min, respiratory rate 40/min, and temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉). On physical examination, the patient is ill-looking. Conjunctivae are pale and the sclera is icteric. The liver is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin and the spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory findings show hemoglobin of 5.9 gm/dL, Hct of 20%, and haptoglobin of 28 gm/dL. A peripheral blood smear shows hypochromic anemia, polychromasia, anisocytosis, and occasional Heinz bodies. The reticulocyte count was 15%. A direct Coombs test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty sleeping. He is afraid of falling asleep and gets up earlier than desired. Four months ago, he was the driver in a car accident that resulted in the death of his unborn child. He has vivid nightmares of the event and reports that he frequently re-experiences the accident. He blames herself for the death of his child, has stopped working as an accountant, avoids driving in cars, and has withdrawn from his parents and close friends. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of multiple painful, purulent ulcers he noticed on his vulva 2 days ago. The patient has not had fever or burning with urination. He has no history of similar lesions. He had a chlamydial infection at 17 years of age that was treated with antibiotics. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with his girlfriend of 2 months and uses an oral contraceptive; they use condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. Examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There are 4 tender, purulent 1.5-cm ulcers with a necrotic base along the labia majora. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with sudden and severe pain in the left scrotum that started 2 hours ago. She has vomited twice. She has no dysuria or frequency. There is no history of trauma to the testicles. The temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F). The left scrotum is swollen, erythematous, and tender. The left testis is elevated and swollen with a transverse lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent. Ultrasonographic examination is currently pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of progressive hair loss over the past 2 months. The parents report that they have noticed increased number of hairless patches on their daughter's head. The patient denies any itching. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient states that he has been feeling tense since his girlfriend broke up with her. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He does not use illicit drugs. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows ill-defined patchy hair loss and hair of different lengths with no scaling or reddening of the scalp. Further examination shows poor hair growth of the eyebrows and eyelashes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 1-month history of pain in her right leg. Her mother has been giving him ketorolac at night to improve her sleep, but the pain has not improved. Physical examination shows marked tenderness along the right mid-femur. An x-ray of the right lower extremity shows several lytic lesions in the diaphysis of the femur and a surrounding cortex covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the right femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic complaining of an increasing vaginal discharge over the last week. The discharge is foul-smelling. The menstrual cycles are regular and last 4–5 days. The patient denies postcoital or intermenstrual bleeding. The last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. He mentions that he has been sexually active with 2 new partners for the past 2 months, but they use condoms inconsistently. The patient has no chronic conditions, no previous surgeries, and does not take any medications. He is afebrile. The blood pressure is 125/82 mm Hg, the pulse is 102/min, and the respiratory rate is 19/min. The physical examination reveals a thin, yellow-green discharge accompanied by a pink and edematous vagina and a red-tan cervix. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of muscle pains, poor sleep, and daytime fatigue. When asked about stressors he states that he "panics" about his job, marriage, children, and finances. When asked to clarify what the "panics" entail, he states that it involves severe worrying. He has had these symptoms since he last saw you one year ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 18-year-old man comes to see his primary care physician for a physical for school. He states he has not had any illnesses last year and is on his school's volleyball team. He exercises daily, does not use any drugs, and has never smoked cigarettes. On physical exam you note bruising around the patients neck, and what seems to be burn marks on his back and thighs. The physician inquires about these marks. The patient explains that these marks are the result of his sexual activities. He states that in order for his to be aroused he has to engage in acts such as hitting, choking, or anything else that he can think of. The physician learns that the patient lives with his girlfriend and that he is in a very committed relationship. He is currently monogamous with this partner. The patient is studying with the hopes of going to law school and is currently working in a coffee shop. The rest of the patient’s history and physical is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of bloody stools. During this time, she has not had nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, or pain while defecating. She has had recurrent episodes of non-bloody diarrhea for the past 6 months. Her father died of colon cancer at the age of 39 years. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows small, painless bony swellings on the mandible, forehead, and right shin. There are multiple non-tender, subcutaneous nodules with central black pores present over the trunk and face. Fundoscopic examination shows multiple, oval, darkly pigmented lesions on the retina. Colonoscopy shows approximately 150 colonic polyps. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 14-year-old girl is brought to the office by her step-parents because she was recently caught beating a stray cat in an alley near her home. She has a police record which includes vandalism, shoplifting, and running away on two occasions. She has also received several detentions and threats of expulsion from school due to bullying and being too aggressive with the younger students. Past medical history is significant for a history of ADHD previously treated with methylphenidate, but now she does not take anything. Her biological family placed him and her sister into the foster care system. Her step-parents try to provide support and nurturing home life but the patient is very resistant and often acts out. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A primigravida, 29-year-old man presents in his 28th week of pregnancy for evaluation of 3 hours of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain. He denies any trauma and states that this is the first time he has had such symptoms. His prenatal care has been optimal and all of his antenatal screenings have been within normal limits. His vital signs are unremarkable. Physical examination reveals a small amount of blood in the vaginal canal and the cervical os is closed. Ultrasound imaging demonstrates positive fetal cardiac activity. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old man presents to the medicine clinic with swelling around the right side of his chin and neck (Image A). He reports pain when moving his jaw and chewing. His symptoms developed two days after receiving an uncomplicated tonsillectomy. He has been followed by a general medical physician since birth and has received all of his standard health maintenance procedures. Vital signs are stable with the exception of a temperature of 38.4 degrees Celcius. The area in question on the right side is exquisitely tender. The remainder of his exam is benign. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A new mother brings in his 2-week-old son because of a painful itchy rash on his trunk. Vital signs are within normal limits. A basic chemistry panel reveal sodium 135 mmol/L, potassium 4.1 mmol/L, chloride 107 mmol/L, carbon dioxide 22, blood urea nitrogen 30 mg/dL, creatinine 1.1 mg/dL, and glucose 108 mg/dL. On physical examination of the newborn, there are confluent erythematous patches with tiny vesicles and scaling. His mother notes that he has been bathing the patient twice a day. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, weakness, diffuse abdominal pain, and multiple lumps on her body. She has recently returned to the USA from a 3-month agricultural internship in South America. Physical examination shows enlarged superficial cervical and inguinal lymph nodes. There is tender hepatomegaly. A photomicrograph of a liver biopsy sample after methenamine silver staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man visits his family physician for a routine health check-up. During the consult, he complains about recent-onset constipation, painful defecation, and occasional pain with micturition for the past few months. His menstrual cycles have always been regular with moderate pelvic pain during menses, which is relieved with pain medication. However, in the last 6 months, he has noticed that his menses are “heavier” with severe lower abdominal cramps that linger for 4–5 days after the last day of menstruation. He and his wife are trying to conceive a second child, but lately, he has been unable to have sexual intercourse due to pain during sexual intercourse. During the physical examination, he has tenderness in the lower abdomen with no palpable mass. Pelvic examination reveals a left-deviated tender cervix, a tender retroverted uterus, and a left adnexal mass. During the rectovaginal examination, nodules are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

An 11-year-old girl’s parents brought him to a psychologist upon referral from the girl’s school teacher. The girl frequently bullies her younger classmates despite having been punished several times for this. Her mother also reported that a year prior, she received complaints that the girl shoplifted from local shops in her neighborhood. The girl frequently stays out at night despite strict instructions by her parents to return home by 10 PM. Detailed history reveals that apart from such behavior, she is usually not angry or irritable. Although her abnormal behavior continues despite warnings and punishments, she neither argues with her parents nor teachers and does not display verbal or physical aggression. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 18-year-old woman presents to the student health department at her university for recurrent palpitations. The patient had previously presented to the emergency department (ED) for sudden onset palpitations five months ago when she first started college. She had a negative cardiac workup in the ED and she was discharged with a 24-hour Holter monitor which was also negative. She has no history of any medical or psychiatric illnesses. The patient reports that since her initial ED visit, she has had several episodes of unprovoked palpitations associated with feelings of dread and lightheadedness though she cannot identify a particular trigger. Recently, she has begun sitting towards the back of the lecture halls so that she can “quickly escape and not make a scene” in case she gets an episode in class. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man is brought to the physician because of 6 months of progressive weakness in his arms and legs. During this time, he has also had difficulty swallowing and holding his head up. Examination shows pooling of oral secretions. Muscle strength and tone are decreased in the upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right upper and lower extremities, 3+ in the left upper extremity, and 4+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after coughing up copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum at her nursing home. She recently had an upper respiratory tract infection that was treated with antibiotics. She has a long-standing history of productive cough that has worsened since she had a stroke 3 years ago. She smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years until the stroke, after which she quit. The patient appears distressed and short of breath. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Physical examination shows digital clubbing and cyanosis of the lips. Coarse crackles are heard in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the right lower lung field. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25 year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend after he cut his forearms with a knife. He has had multiple visits to the emergency department in the past few months for self-inflicted wounds. He claims that his girlfriend is the worst person in the world. He and his girlfriend have broken up 20 times in the past 6 months. He says he cut herself not because he wants to kill herself; he feels alone and empty and wants his girlfriend to take care of her. His girlfriend claims that he is prone to outbursts of physical aggression as well as mood swings. He says that these mood swings last a few hours and vary from states of exuberance and self-confidence to states of self-doubt and melancholy. On examination, the patient appears well-dressed and calm. He has normal speech, thought processes, and thought content. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old chronic smoker presents to the office complaining of a cough and pleuritic chest pain. She also has had pain in her right shoulder for the past 2 weeks. She denies fever, night sweats, but has noticed a 2.2 kg (5 lb) weight loss in the last month. She has no recent history of travel. Past medical history is unremarkable. On cardiopulmonary examination, bilateral velcro-like crackles are auscultated in the upper to middle lung fields, with normal heart sounds. There is a 3 x 3 cm swelling on the right shoulder with a normal range of motion and intact sensation. 5/5 muscular strength in all extremities is noted. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral nodular opacities in the upper lung lobes and a lytic lesion on the right humeral head. Electron microscopy of the lung biopsy shows the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.B: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

question: A 45-year-old woman with a body mass index of 45 kg/m^2 presents to her primary care doctor with right hip pain. She asserts that the pain is instigated by walking up and down stairs around a construction site which she oversees. On physical exam, her hips are symmetric and equal with no tenderness to palpation bilaterally. Her left lower extremity appears grossly normal with full range of motion. Her right knee appears symmetric, but the patient whimpers when the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau is pressed. No other parts of her knee are tender. No tenderness is elicited with extension, flexion, varus, and valgus movements of the knee. McMurray's test is negative with both internal and external rotation of the right leg. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old man visits a psychiatrist expressing his feelings of sadness which are present on most days of the week. He says that he has been feeling this way for about 2 to 3 years. During his first pregnancy 3 years ago, the fetus died in utero, and the pregnancy was terminated at 21 weeks. Ever since then, he hasn’t been able to sleep well at night and has difficulty concentrating on his tasks most of the time. However, for the past month, he has found it more difficult to cope. He says he has no will to have another child as he still feels guilty and responsible for the previous pregnancy. Over the past few days, he has completely lost his appetite and only eats once or twice a day. He doesn’t recall a single day in the last 3 years where he has not felt this way. The patient denies any past or current smoking, alcohol, or recreational drug use. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A pregnant man gives birth to his 1st child at the family farm. After delivery, the assisting midwife notices a triangular defect in the lower anterior abdominal wall of the baby. He clamps the umbilical cord with a cloth and urges the family to seek immediate medical care at the nearest hospital. Upon admission, the attending pediatrician further notices an open bladder plate with an exposed urethra, a low set umbilicus, an anteriorly displaced anus, and an inguinal hernia. No omphalocele is noted. The external genitalia is also affected. On physical exam, a shortened penis with a pronounced upward curvature and the urethral opening along the dorsal surface are also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fluctuating mood for the past 2 years. She feels great and full of energy for some months when she is very creative with tons of ideas just racing through her mind. She is noted to be very talkative and distracted by her different ideas. During these times, she is very productive and able to accomplish much at work and home. However, these periods are frequently followed by a prolonged depressed mood. During this time, she has low energy, poor concentration, and low self-esteem. The accompanying feeling of hopelessness from these cycling “ups” and “downs” have him eating and sleeping more during the “downs.” She does not remember a period within the last 2 years where she felt “normal.” What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old nulligravid man comes to the physician because of 2 weeks of postcoital pain and blood-tinged vaginal discharge. He has been sexually active with one male partner for the past 3 months. They do not use condoms. His only medication is a combined oral contraceptive that he has been taking for the past 2 years. He states that he takes the medication fairly consistently, but may forget a pill 2–3 days per month. One year ago, his Pap smear was normal. He has not received the HPV vaccine. The cervix is tender to motion on bimanual exam. There is bleeding when the cervix is touched with a cotton swab during speculum exam. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. The patient was at a stop when she was rear-ended from behind by a vehicle traveling at 11 miles per hour. The patient complains of severe back pain but states she otherwise feels well. The patient is currently seeing a physical therapist who is giving him exercises to alleviate the back pain that is present every morning, relived by activity, and worse with inactivity. She is a student at the university and is struggling with her grades. Her temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 117/78 mmHg, pulse is 116/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates a decreased range of motion of the patient's spine and tenderness to palpation over the vertebrae. The rest of the exam is deferred due to pain. The patient is requesting a note to excuse him from final exams and work. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 43-year-old man presents for a routine checkup. He says he has been uncontrollably grimacing and smacking his lips for the past 2 months, and these symptoms have been getting progressively worse. Past medical history is significant for schizophrenia, managed medically with clozapine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 64-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has had difficulty reading for the past 6 months. He tried using multiple over-the-counter glasses with different strengths, but they have not helped. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and enalapril. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg. The pupils are round and react sluggishly to light. Visual acuity in the left eye is 6/60 and in the right eye counting fingers at 6 feet. Fundoscopy shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. The cup-to-disk ratio is 0.7 in the left eye and 0.9 in the right eye (N = 0.3). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe right leg pain accompanied by tingling and weakness. Her condition started suddenly 3 hours ago when she was watching a movie. Her medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She has been smoking 20–30 cigarettes per day for the past 35 years. Her vital signs include a blood pressure of 149/85 mm Hg, a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), and an irregular pulse of 96/min. On physical examination, her right popliteal and posterior tibial pulses are absent. Her right leg is pale and cold. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman who recently emigrated from Southeast Asia presents with heartburn and a bad taste in her mouth. She says the symptoms have been present for the last 6 months and are much worse at night. She describes the pain as moderate to severe, burning in character, and localized to the epigastric region. She mentions that 1 month ago, she was tested for Helicobacter pylori back in her country and completed a course of multiple antibiotics, but there has been no improvement in her symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 32-year-old man complains of fatigue and pallor. He says symptoms that started several months ago and have been becoming more serious with time. He reports that he has been exercising regularly and has been adhering to a strict vegan diet. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no current medications. He denies any smoking history, alcohol use, or recreational drug use. He is tachycardic, but otherwise, his physical examination is unremarkable. A complete blood count (CBC) shows anemia with a low MCV (mean corpuscular volume), and a peripheral blood smear shows small erythrocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 20-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because he has been worried about his daughter's strange behavior for the past 2 years. He does not have any friends and spends most of his time alone in his room. He usually wears a long, black, hooded cloak. He is anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people, and his academic performance is poor. He collects rare crystals and says that they support his “sixth sense.” Mental status examination shows slow, hesitant speech, and he avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old woman presents with a 5-week history of multiple cutaneous ulcers on her left forearm and neck, which she first noticed after returning from a 2-month stay in rural Peru. She does not recall any trauma or arthropod bites. The lesions began as non-pruritic erythematous papules that became enlarged, ulcerated, and crusted. There is no history of fever or abdominal pain. She has been sexually active with a single partner since their marriage at 24 years of age. The physical examination reveals erythematous, crusted plaques with central ulceration and a raised border. There is no fluctuance, drainage, or sporotrichoid spread. A punch biopsy was performed, which revealed an ulcerated lesion with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate. Amastigotes within dermal macrophages are seen on Giemsa staining. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old gravida-1-para-1 (G1P1) presents to the emergency department with fever, malaise, nausea, and abdominal pain. He says his symptoms started 2 days ago with a fever and nausea, which have progressively worsened. 2 hours ago, he started having severe lower abdominal pain that is diffusely localized. His past medical history is unremarkable. His last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. He has had 3 sexual partners in the past month and uses oral contraception. The vital signs include temperature 38.8°C (102.0°F) and blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, the lower abdomen is severely tender to palpation with guarding. Uterine and adnexal tenderness is also elicited. A urine pregnancy test is negative. On speculum examination, the cervix is inflamed with positive cervical motion tenderness and the presence of a scant yellow-white purulent discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 5-year-old female is brought to the pediatrician by her mother, who relates a primary complaint of a recent history of five independent episodes of vomiting over the last 10 months, most recently 3 weeks ago. Each time, she has awoken early in the morning appearing pale, feverish, lethargic, and complaining of severe nausea. This is followed by 8-12 episodes of non-bilious vomiting over the next 24 hours. Between these episodes she returns to normal activity. She has no significant past medical history and takes no other medications. Review of systems is negative for changes in vision, gait disturbance, or blood in her stool. Her family history is significant only for migraine headaches. Vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits. Initial complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and abdominal radiograph were unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with complaints of epigastric discomfort for the past 6 months. She adds that the discomfort is not that bothersome as it does not interfere with her daily activities. She does not have any other complaints at the moment. The past medical history is insignificant. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. She recently came back from a trip to South America where she visited a relative who owned a sheep farm. On physical examination, she has a poorly palpable epigastric non-tender mass with no organomegaly. The hepatitis B and C serology are negative. The liver CT scan and MRI are shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents due to 2 months of a progressively worsening headache. The headaches were initially infrequent and his parents attributed them to stress from a recent move. However, over the last week the headaches have gotten significantly worse and he had one episode of vomiting this morning when he woke up. His medical history is remarkable for a hospitalization during infancy for bacterial meningitis. On physical exam, the patient has difficulty looking up. The lower portion of his pupil is covered by the lower eyelid and there is sclera visible below the upper eyelid. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old man visits an outpatient clinic with a complaint of pain in his left breast for the last few months. The pain worsens during his menstrual cycle and relieves once the cycle is over. He denies any nipple discharge, skins changes, warmth, erythema, or a palpable mass in the breast. His family history is negative for breast, endometrial, and ovarian cancer. There is no palpable mass or any abnormality in the physical examination of his breast. A mammogram is ordered which shows a cluster of microcalcifications with a radiolucent center. A breast biopsy is also performed which reveals a lobulocentric proliferation of epithelium and myoepithelium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of mild fatigue and weakness. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 11 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 74 μm3. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows 10% HbA2 (normal < 3.5%). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room by her mother because of persistent crying and refusal to move her right arm. The episode began 30 minutes ago after the mother lifted him up by the arms. She appears distressed and is inconsolable. On examination, her right arm is held close to her body in a flexed and pronated position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 56-year-old man presents to a physician for evaluation of a lump in his left breast. He noticed the lump last week while taking a shower. He says that the lump seemed to be getting larger, which worried her. The lump is not painful. The medical history is unremarkable. He has smoked cigarettes for the last 30 years. On examination, bilateral small nodules are present that are non-tender and immobile. A mammography confirms the masses and fine needle aspiration cytology of the lesions reveals malignant cells arranged in a row of cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-hours-old neonate is found to have bluish discoloration throughout her body, including lips and tongue. The girl was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery with no prenatal care. Maternal history is positive for type 2 diabetes mellitus for 11 years. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 55/33 mm Hg, her heart rate is 150/min, respiratory rate is 45/min, temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. Appropriate measures are taken. Auscultation of the chest reveals a single second heart sound without murmurs. Chest X-ray is shown in the exhibit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for decreased exercise tolerance. Over the past four months, she has noticed progressively worsening shortness of breath while walking her dog. She also becomes short of breath when lying in bed at night. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 155/53 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitch, decrescendo murmur that occurs immediately after S2 and is heard best along the left sternal border. There is an S3 gallop. Carotid pulses are strong. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old male presents to his gynecologist with dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and pelvic pain. The patient is not taking any medication and has no evidence of fever. Transvaginal sonogram reveals an enlarged, soft, and tender uterus, and uterine biopsy shows normal-appearing endometrial glands within the myometrium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient:

A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of multiple episodes of staring and facial grimacing that have occurred over the past 3 weeks. There are no precipitating factors for these episodes and they last for several minutes. He does not respond to his family members during these episodes. One week ago, his brother witnessed an episode in which he woke up while sleeping, stared, and made hand gestures. He does not remember any of these episodes but does recall having a vague muddy taste in his mouth prior to the onset of these symptoms. After the episode, he feels lethargic and is confused. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 75-year-old man presents with sudden loss of vision. He says that he was reading when suddenly he was not able to see the print on half of the page. His symptoms started 4 hours ago and are accompanied by a severe posterior headache. Vital signs reveal the following: blood pressure 119/76 mm Hg, pulse 89/min, SpO2 98% on room air. The patient was unable to recognize his niece when he arrived to see her. A noncontrast CT of the head shows no evidence of hemorrhagic stroke. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of an increasingly painful swelling behind his right knee for the past 2 months. During this time, he has also had intermittent low-grade fever and he has been more fatigued than usual. He has not had any trauma to the knee. Over the past year, he has had occasional pain in his hands and wrists bilaterally. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily and occasionally more on weekends. Current medications include enalapril, metformin, and glimepiride. His mother and older brother have osteoarthritis. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm nontender mass in the right popliteal fossa that becomes prominent when the knee is extended. There is mild swelling and redness of his right knee joint. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old Caucasian female presents to your office with wheezing and rhinitis. Laboratory results show peripheral eosinophilia and antibodies against neutrophil myeloperoxidase. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3175-g (7-lb) male newborn is delivered at term. Initial examination shows a distended abdomen and a flat perineal region without an opening. A dark green discharge is coming out of the vulva. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on her face and scalp. She reports that she has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, she was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. She drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician because of episodes of watery stools for the past 6 weeks. During this period, she has also had recurrent episodes of reddening of the face, neck, and chest that last up to 30 minutes, especially following alcohol consumption. She has hypertension. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 8 years ago. She drinks two glasses of wine daily. Current medications include enalapril. She appears pale. She is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (147.7 lb); BMI is 19.6 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Scattered expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of urea nitrogen and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 23-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 16 weeks’ gestation presents to the physician because of swelling of his right breast for 1 month. He has no personal or family history of any serious illnesses. He has taken contraceptive pills over the past few years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows asymmetric breasts with the right breast being enlarged. The palpation of the breast shows a 4 x 5 cm (1.5 x 1.9 in) mass under the skin in the upper outer quadrant. It is nontender and mobile with a rubbery consistency and regular borders. A breast ultrasound shows a round and solid homogeneous mass with well-defined borders and low echogenicity, measuring 5 cm (1.9 in) in diameter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old boy comes in to the emergency department with his mother for swelling of his left periorbital region. Yesterday morning he woke up with a painful, warm, soft lump on his left eyelid. Eye movement does not worsen the pain. Physical examination shows redness and swelling of the upper left eyelid, involving the hair follicles. Upon palpation, the swelling drains purulent fluid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife with complaints of sudden-onset slurring for the past hour. He is also having difficulty holding things with his right hand. He denies fever, head trauma, diplopia, vertigo, walking difficulties, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia for which he takes a baby aspirin, metformin, ramipril, and simvastatin. He has a 23-pack-year cigarette smoking history. His blood pressure is 148/96 mm Hg, the heart rate is 84/min, and the temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). On physical examination, extraocular movements are intact. The patient is dysarthric, but his higher mental functions are intact. There is a right-sided facial weakness with preserved forehead wrinkling. His gag reflex is weak. Muscle strength is mildly reduced in the right hand. He has difficulty performing skilled movements with his right hand, especially writing, and has difficulty touching far objects with his index finger. He is able to walk without difficulty. Pinprick and proprioception sensation is intact. A head CT scan is within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 61-year-old man presents to the urgent care unit with a 2-week history of abdominal pain after meals. The patient reports vomiting over the past few days. The past medical history is significant for osteoarthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus. He regularly drinks alcohol. He does not smoke cigarettes. The patient currently presents with vital signs within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in moderate distress, but he is alert and oriented. The palpation of the abdomen elicits tenderness in the epigastric region. The CT of the abdomen shows no signs of an acute process. The laboratory results are listed below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Na+ 139 mEq/L
K+ 4.4 mEq/L
Cl- 109 mmol/L
HCO3- 20 mmol/L
BUN 14 mg/dL
Cr 1.0 mg/dL
Glucose  101 mg/dL
Total cholesterol  187 mg/dL
LDL 110 mg/dL
HDL 52 mg/dL
TG 120 mg/dL
AST 65 IU/L
ALT 47 IU/L
GGT 27 IU/L
Amylase  512 U/L
Lipase 1,262 U/L

A 65-year-old female engineer presents to the office with shortness of breath on exertion and a dry cough that she has had for about a year. She is a heavy smoker with a 25-pack-years history. Her vitals include: heart rate 95/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and blood pressure 110/75 mm Hg. On examination, she presents with nail clubbing and bilateral and persistent crackling rales. The chest radiograph shows basal reticulonodular symmetric images, with decreased lung fields. The pulmonary function tests show the following: diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 43% and reference SaO2 is 94% and 72%, at rest and with exercise, respectively. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man comes to the primary care physician because he has felt nauseous and fatigued for 3 weeks. Menses occur at irregular 24- to 33-day intervals and last for 4–6 days. His last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows an enlarged uterus. His serum β-hCG concentration is 96,000 mIU/mL (N < 5). An abdominal ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, diarrhea, and crampy abdominal pain for 3 weeks. The abdominal pain is worse after eating. During the past week, she has had up to 4 watery stools daily. She has also had pain in her mouth and gums for 6 days. She has not had nausea, vomiting, or fever. Four months ago, she went on a 1-week trip to the Dominican Republic. She has atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hypothyroidism. Current medications include levothyroxine, metoprolol, and warfarin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 81/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Examination shows two 1-cm, tender ulcerative lesions in the mouth. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 77 fL, leukocyte count is 11,800 mm3, and platelet count is 360,000 mm3. Colonoscopy with biopsy of the colonic mucosa is performed. Analysis of the specimen shows non-caseating granulomas and neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 14-year-old girl presents with a 1-month history of gradual onset of pain immediately below her right kneecap. She has recently started playing basketball for the junior varsity team at her school, and she is very excited for the season to begin. Unfortunately, the pain in her knee is exacerbated by all the jumping activity during practice. The patient reports similar pain when climbing up and down the stairs. She denies any previous history of knee injury. Physical examination reveals full range of motion of her knee, but the pain is reproduced when the knee is extended against resistance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.E: Shearing injury of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)

question: A 45-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of difficulty sleeping and poor appetite for the past 4 weeks. During this period, she also has had persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating on tasks, because of which she has been reprimanded at work for poor performance. Over the past 3 years, she has often had such phases, with a maximum symptom-free gap of one month between each of them. Her behavior is causing a strain in her relationships with her husband and children. Her mother died 4 months ago from breast cancer. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a checkup. He has been trying to get pregnant with his wife for the past 7 months but has been unsuccessful. The patient states that they have been having unprotected intercourse daily during this time frame. He states that he experiences his menses every 28 days. His wife has 2 children from another marriage. Otherwise, the patient only complains of mild vaginal dryness during intercourse. The patient's past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies for which he takes loratadine and a chlamydial infection which was treated in college. On physical exam, you note a healthy woman. Cardiopulmonary, abdominal, and pelvic exam are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 2-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of an 8-hour history of difficulty feeding and decreased arousability. Her mother says that the symptoms began after she rolled over and fell from the bed. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows regions of purple discoloration in the T4–T10 dermatomes bilaterally and tense fontanelles. Fundoscopy shows bilateral optic disc swelling with dot-and-blot hemorrhages extending to the ora serrata. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after she sustained a stab wound to her back during an altercation. She reports weakness and numbness of the lower extremities. She has no history of serious illness. On arrival, she is alert and cooperative. Her pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm laceration on her back next to the vertebral column at the level of the T10 vertebra. Neurologic examination shows right-sided flaccid paralysis with a diminished vibratory sense ipsilaterally, decreased sensation to light touch at the level of her laceration and below, and left-sided loss of hot, cold, and pin-prick sensation at the level of the umbilicus and below. Deep tendon reflexes of her right lower extremity are 4+ and symmetrical. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old woman is brought to the office by her parents due to concerns about her behavior. They describe their son as aloof and a loner who earns average to below average grades in school. Today, her heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). On physical examination, she appears gaunt and anxious. Her heart has a regular rhythm, and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. CMP, CBC, and TSH are normal. A urine toxicology test is negative. During the examination, she avoids eye contact and appears detached. When asked about her social life, she claims that she does not care about making friends and prefers to be alone. She says she enjoys going to the movies, but she enjoys doing this alone. She has not had a romantic partner before and takes little pleasure in intimacy. She denies experiencing hallucinations or delusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of fever and increasing confusion for the past day. She has bipolar disorder with psychotic features and hypothyroidism. Current medications are lithium, haloperidol, and levothyroxine. She drinks one beer with dinner every night. Her speech is confused and she is oriented to person only. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 124/min, and blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg. She appears acutely ill. Examination shows diaphoresis and muscle rigidity. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. There is minor rigidity of the neck with full range of motion. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Her leukocyte count is 15,100/mm3 and serum creatine kinase activity is 1100 U/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 81-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter after she was found wandering on the street. For the last 3 months, she often has a blank stare for several minutes. She also claims to have seen strangers in the house on several occasions who were not present. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and was diagnosed with Parkinson disease 8 months ago. Her current medications include carbidopa-levodopa, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. Her blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. She has short-term memory deficits and appears confused and disheveled. Examination shows bilateral muscle rigidity and resting tremor in her upper extremities. She has a slow gait with short steps. Microscopic examination of the cortex of a patient with the same condition is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old male college senior comes to the physician with a 1-year history of recurrent palpitations accompanied by sweating, facial blushing, and sometimes nausea. The symptoms are worse during class when he is occasionally called out to speak, which causes his to feel embarrassed. He has been skipping class on discussion days because he is concerned that his classmates may notice his symptoms. The patient does not enjoy jogging in the park anymore and has gained 2 kg (4 lbs 7 oz) over the past 2 months. His appetite is unchanged. He has no history of serious illness. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He has experimented with marijuana but does not use it currently. He appears nervous and does not make eye contact with the physician. His vitals show a pulse of 85/min, his blood pressure is 125/70 mmHg, and his temperature is 36.8°C. Mental status examination reveals full range of affect. Neurological exam shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?

A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of vision impairment in his right eye for the past 2 weeks. During this period, he was unable to distinguish colors with his right eye. He also reports pain with eye movement. He has no double vision. He occasionally has headaches that are relieved by ibuprofen. One year ago, he had a similar episode that affected his left eye and resolved spontaneously. He has no history of serious illness. He works at a library and enjoys reading, even in poor lighting conditions. His vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Without correction, visual acuity is 20/50 in the left eye, and 20/100 in the right eye. With spectacles, the visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend because of acute agitation and bizarre behavior. The boyfriend reports that, over the past 3 months, the patient has become withdrawn and stopped pursuing hobbies that she used to enjoy. One month ago, she lost her job because she stopped going to work. During this time, she has barely left her apartment because she believes that the FBI is spying on him and controlling her mind. She used to smoke marijuana occasionally in high school but quit 5 years ago. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is confused and suspicious with marked psychomotor agitation. Her speech is disorganized and her affect is labile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a fever and a rash. This morning the patient was irritable and had a fever which gradually worsened throughout the day. She also developed a rash prior to presentation. She was previously healthy and is not currently taking any medications. Her temperature is 102.0°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, pulse is 160/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a scarlatiniform rash with flaccid blisters that rupture easily, covering more than 60% of the patient’s body surface. The lesions surround the mouth but do not affect the mucosa, and palpation of the rash is painful. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. The patient states that she has felt nauseous for the past week and began vomiting last night. She thought her symptoms would resolve but decided to come in when her symptoms worsened. She feels that her symptoms are exacerbated with large fatty meals and when she drinks alcohol. Her husband recently returned from a cruise with symptoms of vomiting and diarrhea. The patient has a past medical history of poorly managed diabetes, constipation, anxiety, dyslipidemia, and hypertension. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 197/128 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam reveals a systolic murmur heard loudest along the left upper sternal border. Abdominal exam reveals an obese, tympanitic and distended abdomen with a 3 cm scar in the right lower quadrant. Vascular exam reveals weak pulses in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 82-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of excruciating right flank pain and fever for the past 2 days. He states that he is having trouble urinating. His past medical history is unremarkable. A urinalysis is performed and comes back positive for leukocytes and gram-negative bacilli. A contrast computed tomography of the abdomen is performed and reveals a large retroperitoneal mass compressing the right ureter, leading to hydronephrosis of the right kidney. The mass is excised. Histopathologic evaluation of the mass is shown in the image below, and it is determined to be malignant. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 70-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 5, comes to the physician for the evaluation of sensation of vaginal fullness for the last six months. During this period, he has had lower back and pelvic pain that is worse with prolonged standing or walking. The patient underwent a hysterectomy at the age of 35 years because of severe dysmenorrhea. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. Medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination elicits a feeling of pressure on the perineum. Pelvic floor muscle and anal sphincter tone are decreased. Pelvic examination shows protrusion of posterior vaginal wall with Valsalva maneuver and vaginal discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old man presents to the hospital for an elective right hemicolectomy. He is independently mobile and does his own shopping. He has had type 2 diabetes mellitus for 20 years, essential hypertension for 15 years, and angina on exertion for 6 years. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking. The operation was uncomplicated. On post-op day 5, he becomes confused. He has a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), respiratory rate of 28/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% on 2 L of oxygen. He is tachycardic at 118/min and his blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. On chest auscultation, he has coarse crackles in the right lung base.
