His surgical wound appears to be healing well, and his abdomen is soft and nontender. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because they are concerned with his behavior. He has temper outbursts six or seven times per week, which last anywhere between 5 minutes to half an hour or until he becomes tired. According to his father, he screams at others and throws things in anger “when things don't go his way.” He says these outbursts started when he was 6 and a half years old and even between the outbursts, he is constantly irritable. He had been suspended from school three times in the past year for physical aggression, but his grades have remained unaffected. He appears agitated and restless. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. During the mental status examination, he is uncooperative and refuses to answer questions. What is the most likely diagnosis in this child?

A 20-year-old woman presents with a painless neck mass that has gradually increased in size. The mass is anteromedial to the right sternocleidomastoid muscle and has been present for 3 years. The mass increased in size and became more tender following an upper respiratory infection. An ultrasound of the neck identifies a single, round cystic mass with uniform, low echogenicity, and no internal septations. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck shows a homogeneous mass with low attenuation centrally and with smooth rim enhancement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a fever and a headache. His symptoms started yesterday and have rapidly progressed. Initially, he was experiencing just a fever and a headache which he was treating with acetaminophen. It rapidly progressed to blurry vision, chills, nausea, and vomiting. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension and he is currently taking insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and oral contraceptive pills. His temperature is 104°F (40.0°C), blood pressure is 157/93 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Upon further inspection, the patient also demonstrates exophthalmos in the affected eye. The patient's extraocular movements are notably decreased in the affected eye with reduced vertical and horizontal gaze. The patient also demonstrates decreased sensation near the affected eye in the distribution of V1 and V2. While the patient is in the department waiting for a CT scan, he becomes lethargic and acutely altered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 74-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of an erythematous and edematous skin rash on his right leg that has progressively worsened over the last 2 weeks. The medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. He takes prescribed lisinopril and metformin. The vital signs include: blood pressure 152/92 mm Hg, heart rate 76/min, respiratory rate 12/min, and temperature 37.8°C (100.1°F). On physical exam, the patient appears alert and oriented. Observation of the lesion reveals a poorly demarcated region of erythema and edema along the anterior aspect of the right tibia. Within the region of erythema is a 2–3 millimeter linear break in the skin that does not reveal any serous or purulent discharge. Tenderness to palpation and warmth is associated with the lesion. There are no vesicles, pustules, papules, or nodules present. Ultrasound of the lower extremity is negative for deep vein thrombosis or skin abscess. The blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on history and physical examination?

A mother brings his 4-year-old son to his pediatrician. Over the last eight months, his son has been exhibiting several "odd" behaviors. Most importantly, he repeatedly says that he is playing games with a friend named "Steven," though he is certain that he does not exist. He has often found him acting out magical scenarios as though someone else is present, when no one is there. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 19-month-old boy is brought by his mother to the local walk-in clinic after noticing a mass protruding from his vagina. The mass had the appearance of "a bunch of grapes". He also says that he has been having a vaginal discharge for the past 6 months. His family and personal history are not significant for malignancies or inherited disorders. The physical examination is unremarkable except for the presence of soft nodules protruding from the vaginal canal. A tissue sample is obtained for histologic evaluation. Several weeks later the patient returns to the walk-in clinic for a scheduled follow-up visit. The pathology report describes a polypoid mass beneath an epithelial surface with atypical stromal cells positive for polyclonal desmin. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling in his right foot for the past 2 weeks. Initially, the pain was intermittent but it is now constant and he describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. He has not had any trauma to the foot or any previous problems with his joints. The pain has not allowed his to continue training for an upcoming marathon. His only medication is an oral contraceptive. He is a model and has to regularly wear stilettos for fashion shows. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of the right forefoot. There is tenderness to palpation over the fifth metatarsal shaft. Pushing the fifth toe inwards produces pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 75-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for increasing shortness of breath for the last 8 months. She also complains of a dry cough for the last 6 months. Initially, her shortness of breath occurs with exertion, but now she feels it at rest as well. She has no other complaints. She has a sedentary lifestyle and had a hip replacement surgery recently. The past medical history is significant for hypertension for which she is taking lisinopril. The patient is a lifetime non-smoker. The blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, pulse rate is 85/min, and the temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F). Physical examination reveals fine inspiratory crackles and digital clubbing. A chest X-ray reveals peripheral reticular opacities associated with traction bronchiectasis predominantly at the lung bases. The pulmonary function test results reveal a decreased FEV1, a decreased FVC, and a preserved FEV1/FVC ratio. High-resolution CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department by her husband for slurred speech and right-sided weakness. The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The husband reports her husband went to bed last night normally but woke up this morning with the symptoms mentioned. Physical examination shows right-sided hemiparesis along with the loss of vibration and proprioception. Cranial nerve examination shows a deviated tongue to the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man with a recurrent vesicular genital rash comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a painful, pruritic rash that began on the extremities and has spread to his trunk. His only medication is acyclovir. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Examination of the skin shows several reddish-purple papules and macules, some of which have a dusky center with a lighter ring around them. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old child is brought to the emergency room by her parents in severe pain. They state that she fell on her outstretched right arm while playing with her friends. She is unable to move her right arm which is being supported by her left. On exam, her vitals are normal. Her right extremity reveals normal pulses without swelling in any compartments, but there is crepitus above the elbow upon movement. The child is able to flex and extend her wrist, but this is limited by pain. The child has decreased sensation along her thumb and is unable to make the "OK" sign with her thumb and index finger. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of right hip pain that started that afternoon. Her mother reports that she has also been limping since the pain developed. She says that the pain worsens when she moves or walks. She participated in a dance recital yesterday, but her mother believes that she was not injured at the time. She was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis and her grandmother has osteoporosis. She is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. Her right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated. Examination shows no tenderness, warmth, or erythema. She is able to bear weight. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 8,500/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Ultrasound of the right hip shows increased fluid within the joint. X-ray of the hips shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 70 year-old-man comes to the clinic for generalized fatigue. She says that she is more tired than before and has difficulty catching her breath while walking upstairs. She feels tired quickly doing her usual activity such as gardening and shopping. She does not have any symptoms of fever, change in bowel habits, abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, or weight loss. Her appetite is normal. Her last colonoscopy was done 10 years ago and it was normal. Her blood pressure is 116/74 and heart rate is 87/min. On physical examination, her conjunctivae are pale. A routine blood test shows iron deficiency anemia with hemoglobin of 10 gm/dL. Her stool is positive for occult blood. She is then sent for a colonoscopy (image is shown). What is the most likely diagnosis for the above condition?

A 32-year-old man presents to his family physician with a long history of depression, irritability, and, more recently, personality changes. As his partner comments, he has stopped engaging in activities he used to enjoy like dancing, drumming lessons, and yoga. The patient denies changes in skin pigmentation and assures he keeps a balanced diet low in fat and carbohydrates. During the physical examination, jaundice and dark rings encircling the iris of the eye are noted, as well as hepatomegaly and gait disturbances. For a follow-up visit, the patient brings a battery of laboratory tests that includes a complete blood count showing normocytic normochromic anemia, a negative Coombs, normal iron levels, normal fasting glucose levels, elevated aminotransferases from the liver biochemical tests, bilirubin, and decreased serum ceruloplasmin levels. Antinuclear antibodies are negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old woman presents to the internal medicine clinic with complaints of numbness and tingling in her fingers that she first noticed 6 months ago. It has been progressively worsening and has reached the point where it is affecting her normal daily activities, such as brushing her teeth. Her past medical history is significant for sinusitis and allergic rhinitis since the age of 18, as well as episodic wheezing and shortness of breath since she was 30. She was diagnosed with asthma when she was 22 years old, and subsequently with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) when she was 40. Her current medications include albuterol, loratadine, mometasone, and omeprazole. Her blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg, heart rate is 78/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. On physical exam, the patient’s skin is mottled and appears to have a diffuse, lace-like, erythematous discoloration of the arms, legs, and trunk. There is also a small papular rash on her right forearm. Bilateral wheezes are heard on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-month-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent otitis media since birth. The patient’s immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows multiple petechiae and several eczematous lesions over the scalp and extremities. The remainder of the examination reveals no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 9,600/mm3 (61% neutrophils and 24% lymphocytes), a platelet count of 29,000/mm3, and an increased serum IgE concentration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old primigravid man at 8 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department 4 hours after the onset of vaginal bleeding and crampy lower abdominal pain. He has passed multiple large and small blood clots. The vaginal bleeding and pain have decreased since their onset. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 112/76 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows mild vaginal bleeding and a closed cervical os. An ultrasound of the pelvis shows minimal fluid in the endometrial cavity and no gestational sac. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 63-year-old woman presents to the clinic concerned about numbness in her bilateral shoulders and arms for the past 8 weeks. The symptoms started when she fell from scaffolding at work and landed on her back. Initial workup was benign and she returned to normal duty. However, her symptoms have progressively worsened since the fall. She denies fever, back pain, limb weakness, preceding vomiting, and diarrhea. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, ischemic heart disease, and a 48-pack-year cigarette smoking history. She takes atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, labetalol, and metformin. Her blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg, the pulse is 72/min, and the respiratory rate is 15/min. All cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength is normal in all limbs. Perception of sharp stimuli and temperature is reduced on her shoulders and upper arms. The vibratory sense is preserved. Sensory examination is normal in the lower limbs. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of body aches for the past 9 months. He also has stiffness of the shoulders and knees that is worse in the morning and tingling in the upper extremities. Examination shows marked tenderness over the posterior neck, bilateral mid trapezius, and medial aspect of the left knee. A complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of progressive blurring and darkening of his vision in the right eye. Upon waking up in the morning, he suddenly started seeing multiple dark streaks. He has migraines and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed at his last health maintenance examination 20 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His only medication is sumatriptan. His vitals are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/40 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. The fundus is obscured and difficult to visualize on fundoscopic examination of the right eye. The red reflex is diminished on the right. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Thirty minutes after delivery, a 1780-g (3-lb 15-oz) female newborn develops respiratory distress. She was born at 30 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery. Her temperature is 36.8C (98.2F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 64/min, and blood pressure is 61/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. Examination shows pale extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Supplemental oxygen is administered. Ten minutes later, her pulse is 148/min and respirations are 66/min. Pulse oximetry on 60% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old school teacher visits his doctor because of disfiguring skin lesions that started to appear in the past few days. The lesions are mostly located on his chest, shoulders, and back. They are 2–5 mm in diameter, droplike, erythematous papules with fine silver scales. Besides a sore throat and laryngitis requiring amoxicillin several weeks ago, he has no significant medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after his neighbor found his unconscious on a running trail. His neighbor reports that he has been training for a marathon since the beginning of the summer. He is alert and oriented but becomes irritable when realizing that he is at a hospital and refuses to answer questions. He appears tired. He is 174 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (112 lb). His temperature is 35.5°C (96°F), pulse is 44/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 84/48 mm Hg. Examination shows dry, scaly skin and dry mucous membranes. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur that is heard best at the apex. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.9 g/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 41-year-old man presents to urgent care with complaints of a new rash. On review of systems, he endorses ankle pain bilaterally. Otherwise, he has no additional localized complaints. Physical examination reveals numerous red subcutaneous nodules overlying his shins, bilaterally. Complete blood count shows leukocytes 7,300, Hct 46.2%, Hgb 18.1 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 88 fL, and platelets 209. Chest radiography demonstrates bilateral hilar adenopathy with clear lungs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old African-American man presents to the office complaining of difficulty swallowing for 1 week, and described it as "food getting stuck in his throat". His discomfort is mainly for solid foods, and he does not have any problem with liquids. He further adds that he has frequent heartburn and lost 5 pounds in the last month because of this discomfort. He sometimes takes antacids to relieve his heartburn. His past medical history is insignificant. He is an occasional drinker and smokes a half pack of cigarettes a day. On examination, his skin is shiny and taut especially around his lips and fingertips. A barium swallow study is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal care visit. He used fertility enhancing treatment for his current pregnancy. His other children were born before 37 weeks' gestation. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 28.4 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender, and no contractions are felt. Ultrasonography shows a cervical length of 22 mm and a fetal heart rate of 140/min. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend 10 minutes after ingesting at least 15 acetaminophen tablets. He has been admitted to the hospital several times in the past few months after attempted self-harm. He claims that his girlfriend is “extremely selfish” and “does not care for her.” He says he feels lonely and wants his girlfriend to pay attention to her. His girlfriend says that they have broken up 10 times in the past year because he is prone to outbursts of physical aggression as well as mood swings. He says that these mood swings last a few hours and can vary from states of “exuberance and affection” to states of “depression.” On examination, the patient appears well-dressed and calm. He has normal speech, thought processes, and thought content. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of nocturnal cough and dyspnea. She has been a smoker for the past 15 years with a 7.5-pack-year smoking history. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Her blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, the heart rate is 84/min, the respiratory rate is 15/min, and the temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). A sputum sample shows Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann spirals. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old woman is brought by ambulance to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. She was the front seat driver in a head on collision. She is currently unconscious. The patient’s past medical history is only notable for an allergy to amoxicillin as she developed a rash when it was given for a recent upper respiratory infection 1 week ago. Otherwise, she is a college student in good health. The patient is resuscitated. A FAST exam is notable for free fluid in Morrison’s pouch. An initial assessment demonstrates only minor bruises and scrapes on her body. After further resuscitation the patient becomes responsive and begins vomiting. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.E: Rupture of the inferior vena cava

question: A 67-year-old woman with a history of diabetes mellitus, COPD, and a ST-elevation myocardial infarction currently on dialysis presents with shortness of breath for the past 2 hours. The patient missed her recent dialysis appointment and has been noncompliant with her other medications. The patient found out her best friend died this morning and has felt worse since this event. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 87/48 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respirations are 27/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. A bedside ultrasound demonstrates an anechoic rim surrounding the heart with poor cardiac squeeze, global hypokinesis, and right ventricular collapse with pleural sliding. Laboratory values are notable for 2 cardiac troponins that measure 0.72 ng/mL and 0.71 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-week history of recurrent vomiting and difficulty walking. Examination shows a broad-based gait and bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI shows an intracranial tumor. A ventriculoperitoneal shunt is placed, and surgical excision of the tumor is performed. A photomicrograph of a section of the tumor is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a wellness exam. He currently has no acute concerns but has been feeling hopeless, has a poor appetite, difficulty with concentration, and trouble with sleep. He says that he has poor self-esteem and that his symptoms have been occurring for the past 3 years. He has had moments where he felt better, but it lasted a few weeks out of the year. He currently lives alone and does not pursue romantic relationships because he feels he is not attractive. He has a past medical history of asthma. His mother is alive and healthy. His father committed suicide and suffered from major depressive disorder. On physical exam, the patient has a gloomy demeanor and appears restless and anxious. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her mother for an initial visit. She recently immigrated from Cambodia. Through an interpreter, the patient reports 6 months of mild exertional dyspnea. She denies chest pain or palpitations. Her medical history is unremarkable and she has never had any surgeries. Her family history is significant for hypertension and diabetes. Her father died of tuberculosis. The patient’s vaccination history is unknown. Her temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 113/71 mmHg, and pulse is 82/min. Her BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows a well-nourished, cooperative girl without any grossly dysmorphic features. Cardiac auscultation reveals a grade II systolic ejection murmur along the left upper sternal border and a mid-diastolic rumble along the left sternal border. S1 is normal and the splitting of S2 does not change with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old-man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a motorcycle accident. She lost control at high speed and was thrown forward onto the handlebars. On arrival, she is alert and responsive. She has abdominal pain and superficial lacerations on her left arm. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tender, erythematous area over her epigastrium. The abdomen is soft and non-distended. A CT scan of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Treatment with analgesics is begun, the lacerations are cleaned and dressed, and the patient is discharged home after 2 hours of observation. Four days later, the patient returns to the emergency department with gradually worsening upper abdominal pain, fever, poor appetite, and vomiting. Her pulse is 91/min and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man is brought into the office by his son. His son states that the patient has been acting inappropriately over the last few years. He has been taking off his clothes in front of visitors and putting objects in his mouth. He has had no emotional response to the death of one of his close friends and was laughing at his funeral. He has almost no memory issues, but sometimes forgets how to use objects such as a telephone. He has no other medical issues and takes no medications. On exam, he has no focal neurological deficits and his mini-mental status exam is 25/30. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a wellness checkup. The boy's past medical history is non-contributory, and he has met all his developmental milestones. His parents were recently called into the office as the boy was found touching the genitals of one of his classmates. He was trying to insert a toy into his classmate's genitals. The boy is asked what has happened and what he thinks is going on but he is too shy to reply to the physician. The boy and his mother recently moved in with a family member. They live in low-income housing subsidized by the government and are currently on food stamps. The mother states that his daughter has been particularly argumentative lately and that they have gotten into arguments in which his daughter screamed at his and locked herself in the bathroom. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a fall. She has been seen by the triage nurse but has not been evaluated by a physician. She is heard yelling down the hallway, requesting to speak to “whoever is in charge.” She refuses to talk to the emergency resident and insists on talking to the attending physician despite being informed that the attending is currently resuscitating a patient who was in a car accident. She says that she deserves better treatment because she has made numerous contributions to the field of medicine. When asked about her work, she mentions that she was a medical device salesman. She is accompanied by her husband, who appears embarrassed. She claims that her husband frequently makes a scene and apologizes for her husband's behavior. On mental status examination, the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. She appears agitated and speaks in short, pressured sentences. There is no disorder of thought process or content. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by her parents for evaluation of her “weird” behavior. The parents report that their son tortured their cat to death two weeks ago. Over the past year, she has been accused of stealing a car and setting a fire at her school. She has no history of serious illness. She attends a local high school, and her performance at school is very poor compared to her classmates. She often loses her temper and argues with her teachers. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 2 years. She does not drink alcohol. Her mother has a 10-year history of schizophrenia controlled with medication. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Her speech is normal in rate and rhythm, and her thought process is organized. Short- and long-term memory are intact. Attention and concentration are poor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. The pain started suddenly several hours ago and has steadily worsened. The patient has a past medical history of anxiety and depression. His current medications include sertraline, sodium docusate, a multivitamin, and fish oil. The patient is currently sexually active with his girlfriend and uses the "pull-out" method for contraception. A pelvic ultrasound in the emergency room reveals an ectopic pregnancy. The patient is scheduled for surgery and is promptly treated. He is recovering on the surgical floor. The procedure was complicated by a large amount of blood loss. The patient is recovering on IV fluids when his family comes to visit. When his parents find out the diagnosis, yelling ensues and they leave angrily. The patient is scheduled to go home today. Prior to discharge, the patient reports he is unable to use his left hand. Upon examination, he is teary-eyed and he claims that he has “the worst family in the world,” and he does not want to go home. Physical exam reveals no skin or bony abnormalities of the left arm. Strength is 0/5 in the left upper extremity. He does not recoil his left arm to pain. A MRI is obtained and is unremarkable. The rest of the patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician with a wound on her forearm. She says that she injured himself by absentmindedly walking into a glass door. She does not have health insurance. She has had 5 jobs in the past 8 months. She quit each job after 3–4 weeks because she found the work beneath him. She was imprisoned 6 years ago for credit card fraud. She was released from prison on parole a year ago. She was expelled from school at the age of 13 years for stealing school property and threatening to assault a teacher. She has fathered 6 children with 4 women. She says that she does not provide child support because she needs the money for her own personal expenses. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the forearm shows a 6 cm long, 0.5 cm deep wound with neat edges on the dorsal surface of the left forearm. There are bruises on the left shoulder, back, and the proximal phalanges of the right hand. On mental status examination, the patient is alert and calm. Her mood is described as cheerful. Her thought process, thought content, and speech are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old woman is brought into clinic by her daughter for increasing confusion. The daughter states that over the past 2 weeks, she has noticed that the patient “seems to stare off into space.” She reports she has multiple episodes a day during which she will walk into a room and forget why. She is also worried about her balance. She endorses that she has had several falls, the worst being 3 weeks ago when she tripped on the sidewalk getting the mail. The patient denies loss of consciousness, pre-syncope, chest pain, palpitations, urinary incontinence, or bowel incontinence. She complains of headache but denies dizziness. She reports nausea and a few episodes of non-bloody emesis but denies abdominal pain, constipation, or diarrhea. The patient’s medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. She takes aspirin, warfarin, insulin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and ibuprofen. She drinks a half glass of whisky after dinner every night and smokes a cigar on the weekends. On physical examination, she is oriented to name and place but not to date. She is unable to spell "world" backward. When asked to remember 3 words, she recalls only 2. There are no motor or sensory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department by her parents for concerning behavior. Her parents relate that over the past 3 weeks, she has had multiple episodes of staring into space, lip smacking, and clasping her hands together. The patient has her eyes open during these episode but does not respond to her parents’ voice or her name. These episodes last between 1-2 minutes after which the patient appears to return back to awareness. The patient is confused after these episodes and appears not to know where she is for about 15 minutes. These episodes occur once every few days and the most recent one happened about 10 minutes before the patient arrived to the emergency department. On arrival, the patient is mildly confused and does not know where she is or what recently happened. She is slow to respond to questions and appears tired. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling down a flight of stairs. On arrival, he has shortness of breath, right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and right shoulder pain. He is otherwise healthy. He takes no medications. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Examination shows several ecchymoses over the right chest. There is tenderness to palpation over the right chest wall and right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neck veins are flat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man presents with fever and acute onset chest pain for the past 12 hours. He describes the pain as severe, sharp and stabbing in character, and localized to the retrosternal area. He also says the pain is worse when he breathes deeply or coughs. Past medical history is significant for recently diagnosed systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). His vital signs include: blood pressure 110/75 mm Hg, pulse 95/min, and temperature 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination is significant for a friction rub heard best at the lower left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A previously healthy 64-year-old woman comes to the physician 3 days after noticing a lump in her right groin while she was bathing. She has no history of trauma to the region. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension treated with atorvastatin and labetalol. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 4-cm (1.6-in), nontender, pulsatile mass with a palpable thrill at the right midinguinal point. On auscultation, a harsh continuous murmur is heard over the mass. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.C: Arteriovenous fistula of the femoral vessels

question: A 24-year-old woman, G1P0, presents to his OB/GYN for his annual examination with complaints of painful cramps, abdominal pressure, and bloating with his cycle. He reports that he has not menstruated since his missed abortion requiring dilatation and curettage (D&C) seven months ago. He is sexually active with his wife and is not using any form of contraception. His BMI is 29. At the clinic, his vitals are as follows: temperature, 98.9°F; pulse, 80/min; and blood pressure, 120/70 mm Hg. The physical examination is unremarkable. Thyroid-stimulating hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, and prolactin concentrations are all within normal limits. The patient tests negative for qualitative serum beta‐hCG. A progestin challenge test reveals no withdrawal bleeding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of fever, malaise, and a painful, itchy rash on the right shoulder for 2 weeks. The patient's mother says the girl's condition has worsened over the past 4 days. She has a history of atopic dermatitis. She has lived with her mother at several public shelters since she separated from her physically abusive father 2 months ago. Her immunizations are up-to-date. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of palpitations and loose stools. He has had a 2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss over the past month. He has had no change in appetite. He has no history of serious illness. He works in accounting and has been under more stress than usual lately. He takes no medications. He appears pale. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 126/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bilateral hand tremor with outstretched arms and a palpable thyroid nodule in the left lobe. Serum laboratory studies show a thyroid stimulating hormone level of 0.03 μU/mL and a thyroxine level of 28 μg/dL. A radioactive iodine uptake scan shows enhancement in a 3-cm encapsulated nodule in the lower left lobe with decreased uptake in the remaining gland. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man complains of intermittent diffuse abdominal pain that becomes worse after eating meals and several episodes of diarrhea, the last of which was bloody. These symptoms have been present for the previous 6 months but have worsened recently. He has had significant weight loss since the onset of symptoms. His past medical history includes systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which has been difficult to manage medically. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 100/70 mm Hg, temperature of 37.1°C (98.8 °F), and pulse of 95/min. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in severe pain, and there is mild diffuse abdominal tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, and multiple painless swellings on her neck and axilla. She reports that her swellings become painful after she drinks alcohol. Physical examination shows nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy specimen shows giant binucleate cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she was found in a stuporous state with a small cut on her forehead on a cold night in front of her apartment. Non-contrast head CT is normal, and she is monitored in the emergency department. Twelve hours later, she yells for help because she hears the wallpaper threatening her family. She also has a headache. The patient started drinking regularly 10 years ago and consumed a pint of vodka prior to admission. She occasionally smokes marijuana and uses cocaine. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, the patient is alert and oriented. She appears markedly distressed and is diaphoretic. A fine digital tremor on her right hand is noted. The remainder of the neurological exam shows no abnormalities. Urine toxicologic screening is pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 13-year-old boy is being evaluated for failure to thrive and bad performance at school. She has a history of microcytic anemia and takes a multivitamin every morning with breakfast. An electrophoresis analysis shows no adult hemoglobin (HbA), elevated hemoglobin adult type 2 (HbA2), and normal fetal hemoglobin (HbF). A skull X-ray revealed a crewcut appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of blurry vision for 10 hours. He has also had urinary urgency and discomfort while urinating for the past 4 days. He has been feeling increasingly weak and nauseous since yesterday. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and arterial hypertension. One year ago he was treated for an infection of his eyes. He drinks 2–3 glasses of wine weekly. Current medications include captopril, metoprolol, metformin, and insulin. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg. Visual acuity is decreased in both eyes. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The corneal reflexes are brisk. The mucous membranes of the mouth are dry. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for memory difficulty. He states that for the past couple months he has had trouble with his memory including forgetting simple things like bills he needs to pay or locking doors. He was previously fully functional and did not make these types of mistakes. The patient has not been ill lately but came in because his daughter was concerned about his memory. He makes his own food and eats a varied diet. Review of systems is notable for a decrease in the patient’s mood for the past 2 months since his wife died and a sensation that his limbs are heavy making it difficult for his to do anything. His temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg, pulse is 71/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an elderly woman. His neurological exam is unremarkable; however, the patient struggles to recall 3 objects after a short period of time and can only recall 2 of them. The patient’s weight is unchanged from his previous visit and cardiac, pulmonary, and dermatologic exams are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old farmer from Ohio seeks evaluation at a clinic with complaints of a chronic cough, fevers, and anorexia of several months duration. On examination, she has generalized lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly. A chest radiograph reveals local infiltrates and patchy opacities involving all lung fields. Fine needle aspiration of an enlarged lymph node shows the presence of intracellular yeast. A fungal culture shows the presence of thick-walled spherical spores with tubercles and microconidia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-day-old female newborn delivered vaginally at 36 weeks to a 27-year-old man has generalized convulsions lasting 3 minutes. Prior to the event, he was lethargic and had difficulty feeding. The infant has two healthy older siblings and the mother's immunizations are up-to-date. The infant appears icteric. The infant's weight and length are at the 5th percentile, and his head circumference is at the 99th percentile for gestational age. There are several purpura of the skin. Ocular examination shows posterior uveitis. Cranial ultrasonography shows ventricular dilatation, as well as hyperechoic foci within the cortex, basal ganglia, and periventricular region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old boy is referred to a child psychologist because of worsening behavior and constant disruption in class. She has received multiple reprimands in the past 6 months for not doing the homework her teacher assigned, and she refuses to listen to the classroom instructions. Additionally, her teachers say she is very argumentative and blames other children for not letting him do her work. She was previously well behaved and one of the top students in her class. She denies any recent major life events or changes at home. Her past medical history is noncontributory. Her vital signs are all within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of concerns about her behavior during the past year. Her parents report that she often fails to answer when they call him and has regular unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming. At kindergarten, she can follow and participate in group activities, but does not follow her teacher's instructions when these are given to him directly. She is otherwise cheerful and maintains eye contact when spoken to but does not respond when engaged in play. She gets along well with friends and family. She started walking at the age of 11 months and can speak in two-to-three-word phrases. She often mispronounces words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she is concerned about her son's behavior. She reports that she has been wearing her dresses at home and asks to be called Lilly. She also stopped going to swim class because she “doesn't feel comfortable in swim trunks.” Since starting puberty about a year ago, she has not had any friends and the teachers report she is consistently being bullied at school. Her academic performance has been poor for the last year even though she had maintained an A average the year before. The mother further reports that her son has had mainly female friends since preschool. She also mentions that as a child her son never enjoyed playing with typical boy toys like cars and instead preferred dressing up dolls. The patient was raised by her single mother from the age of 8 because her father left the family due to financial issues. She appears shy. Physical examination shows normal male external genitalia. There is scarce coarse, dark axillary and pubic hair. Upon questioning, the patient reports that she would rather be a girl. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after numerous episodes of vomiting. The patient states that she thinks she ‘ate something weird’ and has been vomiting for the past 48 hours. She says that she came to the hospital because the last few times she "threw up blood". She is hypotensive with a blood pressure of 90/55 mm Hg and a pulse of 120/min. After opening an intravenous line, a physical examination is performed which is normal except for mild epigastric tenderness. An immediate endoscopy is performed and a tear involving the mucosa and submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction is visualized. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling 7 feet onto a flat-top wooden post. On arrival, she is in severe pain and breathing rapidly. Her pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. There is an impact wound in the left fourth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Auscultation shows tracheal deviation to the right and absent breath sounds over the left lung. There is dullness to percussion over the left chest. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are placed and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man presents to the urgent care center with several hours of worsening abdominal discomfort that radiates to the back. The patient also complains of malaise, chills, nausea, and vomiting. Social history is notable for alcoholism. On physical exam, he is febrile to 39.5°C (103.1℉), and he is diffusely tender on abdominal palpation. Other vital signs include a blood pressure of 126/74 mm Hg, heart rate of 74/min, and respiratory rate of 14/min. Complete blood count is notable for 13,500 white blood cells (WBCs), and his complete metabolic panel shows bilirubin of 2.1 and amylase of 3210. Given the following options, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of watery discharge from his right eye for 2 weeks. He and his parents, who are refugees from Sudan, arrived in Texas a month ago. His immunization status is not known. He is at the 25th percentile for weight and the 50th percentile for height. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. Examination of the right eye shows matting of the eyelashes. Everting the right eyelid shows hyperemia, follicles, and papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye shows follicles in the limbic region and the bulbar conjunctiva. There is corneal haziness with neovascularization at the 12 o'clock position. Examination of the left eye is unremarkable. Direct opthalmoscopy of both eyes shows no abnormalities. Right pre-auricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

One week after discharge from the neonatal intensive care unit to a regular pediatric ward, a 1450-g (3-lb 1-oz) female infant has respiratory distress and wheezing. After birth, the patient was intubated and mechanically ventilated for 3 weeks because of hypoxia. She required a 60% fraction of inspired oxygen to achieve adequate oxygen saturation. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 65/35 mm Hg. Physical examination shows labored breathing, intercostal retractions, and crackles at both lung bases. There is bluish discoloration around the lips. An x-ray of the chest shows interspersed areas of atelectasis, granular densities, and hyperinflation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old G1P0 male presents to his OB/GYN for his routine 36-week visit. His current complaints include increased fatigue at the end of the day, and edema in his ankles. The patient’s physical examination is unremarkable except for inguinal adenopathy. Upon pelvic examination for cervical changes, the OB/GYN notices a vaginal chancre. The patient states that it is not painful when touched. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a painless lump on his neck. He has no history of serious illness and his vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when he is asked to protrude his tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old man is brought by his mother to a psychiatrist due to concerns about his behavior. The patient’s mother tells the psychiatrist that he believes that a famous Hollywood celebrity actor loves his and will marry her. When the patient is asked about this, he says that he attended a function at which this actor was the guest of honor six months back, and he waved his hand at his by which he understood that he loves her. However, when he tries to contact him over the phone, he does not respond, which he says is probably because he is too busy with his career at present. When asked why the successful actor would marry her, he says, “Celebrities often prefer to marry ordinary people and that is why he expressed his interest in me that day”. The patient is otherwise healthy with no known medical condition. He denies any mood disturbances, hallucinations, or anxiety. He is currently working as an assistant manager at a private advertising firm and has a normal socio-occupational life. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in her mouth. During the past year, she has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. She has never had any genital or anal lesions. Her mother reports that she has been very stressed over the past month because she is approaching her senior year at high school. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of her oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man visits your office complaining about discharge from his left nipple for the past 3 months. The discharge looks like gray greenish and its amount is progressively increasing. He appears to be anxious and extremely uncomfortable with this situation as it is embarrassing for his when it occurs outdoors. Past medical history is insignificant. His family history is negative for breast and ovarian disorders. He tries to stay active by running for 30 minutes every day on a treadmill, staying away from smoking, and by eating a balanced diet. He drinks alcohol occasionally. During physical examination you find a firm, stable mass under an inverted nipple in his left breast; while on the right breast, dilated subareolar ducts can be noted. There is no lymphadenopathy and remaining of the physical exam is normal. A mammogram is performed which reveals tubular calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of vaginal discharge. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus and his only medication is insulin. Menses occur at 28- to 29-day intervals, and his last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. He does not want to share information regarding sexual activity. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows Tanner stage II breast development. Pelvic examination shows white, thin, odorless vaginal discharge. A wet mount of the discharge shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician because of a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. The headaches are often accompanied by nausea and sometimes relieved by vomiting. He stopped going to his ballet lessons 2 weeks ago because he was embarrassed about falling frequently and having increasing difficulty performing the steps. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. He has a broad-based gait. While standing with both feet together and raising his arms, closing his eyes does not affect his balance. He is unable to perform rapid, alternating movements with his hands. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 31-year-old G1P0 man with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department because he believes that he is in labor. He is in his 38th week of pregnancy and his course has thus far been uncomplicated. This morning, he began feeling painful contractions and noted vaginal bleeding after he fell off his bike while riding to work. He is experiencing lower abdominal and pelvic pain between contractions as well. His temperature is 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 177/99 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a gravid and hypertonic uterus and moderate blood in the vaginal vault. Ultrasound reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Five weeks after delivery, a 1350-g (3-lb 0-oz) female newborn has respiratory distress. She was born at 26 weeks' gestation. She required intubation and mechanical ventilation for a month following delivery and has been on noninvasive pressure ventilation for 5 days. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 148/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 60/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 40% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions. Scattered crackles are heard in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse granular densities and basal atelectasis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-week-old boy is brought to a pediatrician due to feeding difficulty for the last 4 days. His mother mentions that the infant breathes rapidly and sweats profusely while nursing. He has been drinking very little breast milk and stops feeding as if he is tired, only to start sucking again after a few minutes. There is no history of cough, sneezing, nasal congestion, or fever. He was born at full term and his birth weight was 3.2 kg (7.0 lb). His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse rate is 190/min, and respiratory rate is 64/min. On chest auscultation, bilateral wheezing is present. A precordial murmur starts immediately after the onset of the first heart sound (S1), reaching its maximal intensity at the end of systole, and waning during late diastole. The murmur is best heard over the second left intercostal space and radiates to the left clavicle. The first heart sound (S1) is normal, while the second heart sound (S2) is obscured by the murmur. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.D: Supracristal ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation
options.E: Ruptured congenital sinus of Valsalva aneurysm

question: A newborn is evaluated by the on-call pediatrician. He was born at 33 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 34-year-old G1P1. The pregnancy was complicated by poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type 2. His birth weight was 3,700 g and the appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration (APGAR) scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The umbilical cord had 3 vessels and the placenta was tan-red with all cotyledons intact. Fetal membranes were tan-white and semi-translucent. The normal-appearing placenta and cord were sent to pathology for further evaluation. On physical exam, the newborn’s vital signs include: temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure 60/44 mm Hg, pulse 185/min, and respiratory rate 74/min. He presents with nasal flaring, subcostal retractions, and mild cyanosis. Breath sounds are decreased at the bases of both lungs. Arterial blood gas results include a pH of 6.91, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) 97 mm Hg, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) 25 mm Hg, and base excess of 15.5 mmol/L (reference range: ± 3 mmol/L). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man presents to the urgent care center with several hours of worsening abdominal discomfort with radiation to the back. The patient also complains of malaise, chills, nausea, and vomiting. Social history is notable for alcoholism. On physical exam, he is febrile to 39.5°C (103.1°F), and he is diffusely tender to abdominal palpation. Complete blood count is notable for 13,500 white blood cells, bilirubin 2.1, lipase 842, and amylase 3,210. Given the following options, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man with a past medical history significant only for endometriosis presents to the outpatient clinic with a 2-cm left breast mass that he first identified 6 months earlier. On review of systems, the patient states that the mass is not painful and, by his estimation, has not significantly increased in size since he first noticed it. On physical examination, there is a palpable, round, rubbery, mobile mass approximately 2 cm in diameter. Given the lesion’s characteristics and the patient’s demographics, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by the police after she was found running around a local park naked and screaming late at night. During intake, the patient talks non-stop about the government spying on him and her family, but provides little useful information besides her name and date of birth. Occasionally she refers to himself in the third person. She refuses to eat anything and will only drink clear fluids because she is afraid of being poisoned. A medical records search reveals that the patient has been treated for psychotic behavior and occasional bouts of severe depression for several years. Today, her heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 19/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, she appears gaunt and anxious. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. CMP, CBC, and TSH are normal. A urine toxicology test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An otherwise healthy 31-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a several-day history of sharp, central chest pain, which is constant and unrelated to exertion. The pain gets worse on lying down and decreases with sitting forward. She has smoked 10–15 cigarettes daily for the past 7 years. Her blood pressure is 120/50 mm Hg, the pulse is 92/min, and the temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F). On physical examination, a scratching sound is heard at end-expiration with the patient leaning forward. ECG is shown in the image. Serum troponin is mildly elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 4 hours after the sudden onset of a diffuse, dull, throbbing headache. During this time, he also reports blurred vision, nausea, and one episode of vomiting. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks 1–2 glasses of wine per day. His temperature is 36.6 °C (97.9 °F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 185/110 mm Hg. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral blurring of the optic disc margins. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein but no WBCs or RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for right wrist pain and swelling 2 hours after falling on an outstretched hand while playing softball. The pain worsened when she attempted to pitch after the fall. She has eczema and type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and topical clobetasol. She appears uncomfortable. Examination shows multiple lichenified lesions over her forearms. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. There is tenderness to palpation in the area between the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus muscle. The thumb can be opposed actively towards the other fingers. Muscle strength of the right hand is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of recurrent headaches and nausea. The headaches occur a few times a month and alternately affect the right or left side. The headaches are exacerbated by loud sounds or bright light. He is in graduate school and has been under a lot of stress recently. He does not smoke or drink alcohol but does drink 2–3 cups of coffee daily. His only medication is an oral contraceptive. Physical examination shows no abnormalities; visual acuity is 20/20. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 59-year-old man comes to the emergency department 25 minutes after the onset of severe left periorbital pain and blurred vision in the same eye. The pain began soon after he entered a theater to watch a movie. He has a headache and vomited twice on the way to the hospital. Two weeks ago, he had acute sinusitis that resolved spontaneously. He has atrial fibrillation and hypertension. Current medications include metoprolol and warfarin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Visual acuity is counting fingers at 3 feet in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. The left eye shows conjunctival injection and edematous cornea. The left pupil is mid-dilated and irregular; it is not reactive to light. Extraocular movements are normal. Fundoscopic examination is inconclusive because of severe corneal edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe headache. The patient states she gets sudden, severe pain over her face whenever anything touches it, including shaving or putting lotion on her skin. She describes the pain as electric and states it is only exacerbated by touch. She is currently pain free. Her temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 127/81 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Neurological exam is within normal limits, except severe pain is elicited with light palpation of the patient’s face. The patient is requesting morphine for her pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 4-week history of fatigue, crampy abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and pain in her mouth and gums. She returned from a 2-week trip to the Dominican Republic 2 months ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Examination shows three 1.5-cm, painful ulcers in the mouth. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant without guarding or rebound. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 75 fL, and leukocyte count is 11,900 mm3. Colonoscopy shows a cobblestone mucosa. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Six hours after delivery, a 3100-g (6-lb 13-oz) female newborn has an episode of bilious projectile vomiting. She was born at term to a 21-year-old woman. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The mother smoked a pack of cigarettes daily during the pregnancy. Physical examination shows a distended upper abdomen. An x-ray of the abdomen shows 3 distinct, localized gas collections in the upper abdomen and a gasless distal abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A previously healthy 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of nervousness and difficulty sleeping over the past 4 weeks. He has difficulty falling asleep at night because he cannot stop worrying about his relationship and his future. Three months ago, his new girlfriend moved in with her. Before this relationship, he had been single for 13 years. He reports that his girlfriend does not keep things in order in the way he was used to. Sometimes, he puts his dirty dishes in the kitchen sink instead of putting them in the dishwasher directly. He refuses to add any groceries to the shopping list when they are used up. He has also suggested several times that they have dinner at a restaurant instead of eating at home, which enrages his because he likes to plan each dinner of the week and buy the required groceries beforehand. The patient says that he really loves his girlfriend but that he will never be able to tolerate his “flaws.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is cooperative but appears distressed. His affect has little intensity or range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness 2 hours ago. She can speak clearly without difficulty and denies any similar symptoms in the past. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes, both poorly managed due to medication non-compliance. Family history is significant for heart disease and diabetes in multiple paternal and maternal relatives. Her vital signs include: blood pressure 150/88 mm Hg, pulse 86/min, and respiratory rate 15/min. On physical examination, strength is 3/5 on the right and 5/5 on the left upper and lower extremities. The sensation is intact, and no impairments in balance or ataxias are present. An initial noncontrast CT scan of the head is unremarkable, but a repeat noncontrast CT scan of the head performed a month later reveals the 2 lesions circled in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with dizziness. She states she has experienced a sustained sense of disequilibrium for the past 2 days. She feels that the floor is unstable/moving. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not have any other medical diagnoses. The patient is currently taking vitamin C as multiple family members are currently ill and she does not want to get sick. Her temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, pulse is 73/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a horizontal nystagmus. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver does not provoke symptoms and examination of the patient’s cranial nerves is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man presents to the ER with shortness of breath, cough, and severe lower limb enlargement. The dyspnea was of sudden onset, started a week ago, and increased with exercise but did not disappear with rest. His cough was dry, persistent, and non-productive. He has a family history of maternal hypertension. His vital signs include heart rate 106/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg. On physical examination, thoracic expansion was diminished on the right side with rhonchi and crackles on the lower two-thirds of both sides, with left predominance. A systolic murmur was heard on the tricuspid foci, which increased in intensity with inspiration. There was jugular engorgement when the bed was placed at 50°. Palpation of the abdomen was painful on the right hypochondrium, with hepatomegaly 4 cm below the lower coastal edge. Hepatojugular reflux was present. Soft, painless, pitting edema was present in both lower limbs up until the middle third of both legs. Lung computed tomography (CT) and transthoracic echocardiogram were performed and detected right heart failure and severe pulmonary fibrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 67-year-old female presents to her primary care physician complaining of increased fatigue over the last year. She also says that her friends say she appears to be more pale. Her past medical history is significant for 10 years of arthritis. Physical exam reveals spoon shaped nails as well as conjunctival pallor. Based on clinical suspicion RBC tests are ordered showing an mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 75 fl (normal 80-100 fl) and a peripheral blood smear is obtained and found to be normal. Iron studies shows a serum iron of 30 micromolar (normal range 50-170) and a serum ferritin of 300 micrograms/liter (normal range 15-200). What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 39-year-old man with a history of migraine headaches is brought to the emergency room because of a severe, sudden-onset, throbbing headache and double vision for 1 hour. He says that he has been having frequent headaches and has not had his period in several months. His blood pressure is 93/61 mm Hg. Visual field testing shows decreased visual acuity and loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman who is a professional baseball player presents with stiffness in her hands. She says she is unable to bat as she would like and feels like she lacks power in her swings. She also has noticed that she sometimes seems to be dragging her feet while walking, and her voice seems to have changed. On physical examination, strength is 3 out of 5 in the extensor and flexor muscle groups in both upper and lower limbs bilaterally. Sensation is intact. Widespread muscle fasciculations are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing pain in the right hip for 2 months. The pain is intermittent, presenting at the lateral side of the hip and radiating towards the thigh. It is aggravated while climbing stairs or lying on the right side. Two weeks ago, the patient was treated with a course of oral prednisone for exacerbation of asthma. His current medications include formoterol-budesonide and albuterol inhalers. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the right thigh. There is no swelling. The patient is placed in the left lateral decubitus position. Abducting the extended right leg against the physician's resistance reproduces the pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the pelvis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has been increasingly reluctant to speak at school over the past 4 months. His teachers complain that s=he does not answer their questions and it is affecting his academic performance. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia. Previous well-child examinations have been normal. His older brother was diagnosed with a learning disability 4 years ago. He is at 65th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. He follows commands. He avoids answering questions directly and whispers his answers to his mother instead who then mediates between the doctor and her son. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a lump in her left axilla that she first noticed 1 year ago. She reports that the size of the mass has varied over time and that there have been similar masses in her neck and groin. She has not had fever, weight loss, or night sweats. Physical examination shows a nontender, rubbery mass in the left axilla and a similar, smaller mass in the right groin. Her spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, are within reference ranges. Genetic analysis obtained on resection of the axillary mass shows a t(14;18) translocation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to severe, intractable headaches, and bilateral ocular pain. His symptoms began approximately 2 weeks prior to presentation and have progressively worsened. He initially had right-sided headaches that were sharp, interfered with sleep, and were unresponsive to pain medications. The headache was around his right eye and cheek, and he noticed diplopia with right lateral gaze. His symptoms were accompanied by fatigue, fever, and edema around the right eye. Approximately 2 days after these symptoms, he developed swelling around the left eye. Medical history is significant for a recent rhinosinusitis infection. His temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 133/72 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. On physical exam, there is ptosis, proptosis, chemosis, and periorbital swelling of both eyes. There is hyperesthesia in the bilateral ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve. Fundoscopic exam demonstrates bilateral papilledema. There is mydriasis and eye muscle weakness in all directions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 35 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding for the last hour. He has had no prenatal care. His third child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a preterm breech presentation; his first two children were delivered vaginally. The patient's pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen; no contractions are felt. There is blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect both thighs bilaterally. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. One hour later, the bleeding stops. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless skin lesion on her neck. The lesion has gradually become darker in color. Sometimes it is itchy. She also noticed one similar lesion on her lower back. She is a retired gardener. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 123/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule on her neck and a 0.6-cm hyperpigmented papule on her lower back, both of which have a greasy and wax-like appearance. A photograph of the neck is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old woman presents to the behavioral health clinic for assistance overcoming her fear of public speaking. She has always hated public speaking. Two weeks ago, she was supposed to present a research project at school but had to leave the podium before the presentation. She recalled that her heart was racing, her palms were sweating, and that she could not breathe. These symptoms resolved on their own after several minutes, but she felt too embarrassed to return to college the next day. This had also happened in high school where, before a presentation, she started sweating and felt palpitations and nausea that also resolved on their own. She is scheduled for another presentation next month and is terrified. She states that this only happens in front of large groups and that she has no problems communicating at small gatherings. Other than her fear of public speaking, she has a normal social life and many friends. She enjoys her classes and a part-time job. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old man comes to the physician for a 3-month history of bloody discharge from the right nipple. His mother died of breast cancer at the age of 69 years. Mammography 6 months ago did not show any abnormalities. Examination of the breast shows expression of a small amount of serosanguinous fluid from the right nipple; there are no palpable breast masses or axillary lymphadenopathy. Ultrasonography of the right breast shows a single dilated duct. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-month-old neonate boy is brought to the pediatrician because of feeding problems and recurrent infections. He has a blood pressure of 104/65 mm Hg and heart rate of 91/min. On physical examination, he has a cleft palate, malformed jaw, structural cardiac abnormalities, and diminished cell-mediated responses. Laboratory investigations reveal hypocalcemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
