A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of repetitive tongue twisting and abnormal movements of the hands and legs that started several days ago. He has a 2-year history of schizophrenia that has been controlled with fluphenazine. Two weeks ago, he was switched to risperidone. Examination shows protrusion of the tongue and smacking of the lips. He makes twisting movements of the arms and frequently taps his right foot. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 53-year-old man seeks medical care for superficial erosions and blisters over the skin of his head and trunk. He also has significant involvement of his buccal mucosa, which has made eating difficult. A year earlier, he developed tender sores on the oral mucosa and soft palate of his mouth, which was initially treated as herpes simplex stomatitis. His condition worsened despite treatment, resulting in the development of eroded areas over his trunk and extremities, with a 10 kg weight loss. Upon further questioning, he denies itching, but he notes that the top layer of his skin could be easily removed when firm horizontal pressure was applied. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient’s condition?

A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department for leg weakness. About 4 hours ago, he was out walking his dog when he had a sudden onset of left-leg weakness. He had no prior symptoms and noticed nothing else except that he was unable to move his left leg like he normally could. This weakness lasted for roughly 3 hours, but it resolved completely while he was in the car on his way to the emergency department, he can move his leg normally now. His medical history is notable for a 20-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His heart rate is 80/min, the blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical exam, including a thorough neurological exam, is unremarkable; strength is 5/5 throughout his bilateral upper and lower extremities. A noncontrast CT scan of his head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a fall from his bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on his way to work as he lost his balance, hitting his head on the sidewalk. He had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. He currently has nausea and a headache. He has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. He has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. He has never used illicit drugs. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While performing the remainder of the physical examination the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and he is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on her scalp. When she scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, her scalp itches or she notices a burning sensation. She had a mole removed on her right forearm 5 years ago. She is a retired winemaker. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on her scalp. A photograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old man presents to your office complaining of right arm numbness and weakness. His past medical history is unremarkable. His family history, however, is significant for the unexpected death of both his parents at age 59 in a motor vehicle accident last week. On physical exam, his bicep, brachioradialis, and patellar reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. CNS imaging shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 39 weeks' gestation comes to the hospital 20 minutes after the onset of vaginal bleeding. He has not received prenatal care. His third child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a footling breech presentation. His other two children were delivered vaginally. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/74 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender, and no contractions are felt. The fetus is in a vertex presentation. The fetal heart rate is 96/min. Per speculum examination reveals ruptured membranes and severe bleeding from the external os. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old gravida 2, para 1 man at 37+6 weeks of gestation presents for elective cesarean delivery. He says he has been having increased fatigue over the past few weeks. Past medical history includes gestational hypertension for which he has been taking an antihypertensive drug twice daily since week 24. His vital signs include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg, pulse 127/min. Physical examination reveals generalized pallor. His laboratory results reveal microcytic, hypochromic anemia with anisocytosis, hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a differential with 14% lymphocytes, an ESR of 22 mm/hr, and a reticulocyte production index of 3.1. A direct antiglobulin test is positive. LFTs, creatinine, ferritin level, vitamin B12 level, coagulation studies, and urinalysis are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 18-year-old man presents to his primary care physician reporting that he has not experienced his first menses. He is accompanied by his mother who states that he personally experienced menstruation at age 12 and that the patient's sister started menstruating at the age of 11 years. The patient is not sexually-active and denies taking any medications. On physical examination, the patient appears thin and has fine hair covering his arms. His height is 62 inches (157.48 cm) and his weight is 85 pounds (38.5 kg). The patient does not make eye contact and only answers in one word responses. The mother is asked to step out of the room and the interview resumes. After establishing some trust, the patient admits that he does not have an appetite. He has had difficulty sleeping and some feels guilty for worrying his mother. He also admits to occasional cocaine use. He switches between binge-eating and vomiting. He is constantly fatigued but he also goes to the gym three times daily, often without his parents’ knowledge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 3-day-old infant presents because the patient’s parents noticed that her skin was becoming yellow. The mother said that the patient eats well, has normal stool and urine color. It’s her first child from first healthy pregnancy. The patient was born on time and delivered via spontaneous vaginal delivery with no complications. Family history is significant for a maternal aunt who died as an infant of unknown causes. The patient is afebrile and vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, she is awake, calm, and looks healthy, except for the yellow tone of the skin and scleral icterus. Laboratory findings are significant for elevated unconjugated bilirubin, with a normal complete blood count. Other routine laboratory blood tests are within normal limits. The patient is treated with phototherapy, but her jaundice worsens and her unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia persists well into the second week of life. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0 at 11 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of left lower extremity pain and swelling. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Physical examination shows a tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg. The overlying skin is erythematous and indurated. Duplex ultrasound shows vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 64-year-old woman is admitted with a history of altered mental status. She was in her usual state of health until a few days ago when she has started to become confused, lethargic, forgetful, and repeating the same questions. Over the last few days, she sometimes appears perfectly normal, and, at other times, she has difficulty recognizing her family members. Yesterday, she was screaming that the room was filled with snakes. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed medically, and chronic kidney disease, for which she undergoes regular hemodialysis on alternate days. There is no history of smoking, alcohol use, or illicit drug use. Her vitals include: blood pressure 129/88 mm Hg, pulse 112/min, temperature 38.2°C (100.8°F), and respiratory rate 20/min. The patient is oriented only to person and place. Her mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score is 18/30, where she had difficulty performing basic arithmetic calculations and recalled only 1 out of 3 objects. Nuchal rigidity is absent. Muscle strength is 5/5 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 5-year-old boy presents for a routine checkup. The patient’s parents say he has been looking pale and tired lately. His family history is unremarkable. Upon physical examination, several bruises are seen, as well as petechial bleeding on his limbs. A complete blood count shows leukocytosis with severe anemia and thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood smear shows 35% blasts. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows hepatosplenomegaly and a chest radiograph reveals a mediastinal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe right hip pain. The pain is worse at night. She has chronic headaches and back pain for which she takes vitamin D, calcium supplements, and ibuprofen. Examination shows hip tenderness and mild sensorineural hearing loss. X-ray of the hip shows a radiolucent lesion in the ilium with a moth-eaten appearance, wide transition zone, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. Wide excision of the lesion is performed. A photomicrograph of a section of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man, who was a coal miner for more than 15 years presents with complaints of a cough and shortness of breath. Her cough started 6 years ago and is dry and persistent. The shortness of breath started 4 months ago and is exacerbated by physical activity. When interviewed, her physician discovers that she doesn’t take any safety measures when working in the mines. Vital signs include: heart rate 85/min, respiratory rate 32/min, and blood pressure 125/90 mm Hg. On physical examination, there are diminished respiratory sounds on both sides. In her chest X-ray, interstitial fibrosis with reticulonodular infiltrate with honeycombing is found on both sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Twelve hours after delivery a 2700-g (5-lb 15-oz) female newborn has 3 episodes of bilious vomiting. She was born at 36 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The mother has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily and has a history of intravenous cocaine use. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended upper abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. An x-ray of the abdomen shows 3 gas shadows in the upper abdomen with a gasless distal abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old woman presents with substernal chest pain for the past hour. She describes the chest pain as severe, squeezing in nature, diffusely localized to the substernal area and radiating down her left arm. She also has associated nausea, dizziness, and diaphoresis. She denies any recent history of fever, chest trauma, palpitations, or syncope. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), managed medically with a proton pump inhibitor for the last 3 months. She also has uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypercholesterolemia diagnosed 10 years ago. Her last HbA1c was 8.0. The vital signs include: blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg, pulse 100/min, respiratory rate 20/min, temperature 36.8°C (98.3°F) and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. She is administered sublingual nitroglycerin which lessens her chest pain. Chest radiograph seems normal. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in anterolateral leads. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?

A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of fever, malaise, and severe right knee joint pain and swelling for 3 days. She had also had episodes of abdominal pain and epistaxis during this period. Five days ago, she had swelling and pain in her left ankle joint which has since resolved. She reports having a sore throat 3 weeks ago while she was camping in the woods, for which she received symptomatic treatment. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 119/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen, tender right knee; range of motion is limited. There are painless 3- to 4-mm nodules over the elbow. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 11,800/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 58 mm/h. Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint yields clear, straw-colored fluid; no organisms are identified on Gram stain. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 1,350/mm3 with 17% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in his lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. He had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 ml of blood. During the procedure, he received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below his waist and 0/5 muscle strength in his lower extremities. He feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of his great toes. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for the evaluation of confusion and memory deficits for the last month. During this period, he has also had mild weakness in his left leg. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for the last 45 years. He drinks a glass of wine every day. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person. He recalls 2 out of 3 objects immediately and none after 5 minutes. The patient is unable to lift his eyebrows or to smile. Muscle strength is decreased in the left lower extremity. A T2-weighted MRI scan of the head shows several hyperintense round lesions in the frontal and temporal lobe at the border of the gray and white matter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider complaining of smelling abnormal odors on several occasions. She says that she smells burnt rubber even though there is nothing burning and no one around him can smell what she does. This symptom has been intermittently bothering him for the past 6 months. Also during this period, she had occasional nosebleeds. She works as a high school teacher. Although her work gets a little stressful around the exam season, she says she is able to cope well. Family history is unremarkable. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and denies the use of any medication. Physical examination reveals unilateral nasal obstruction with some dried blood in the nasal passage. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with back pain. She states that it started yesterday and has been gradually getting worse. She states that the pain is worsened with moving and lifting and is relieved with rest and ibuprofen. She has a past medical history of smoking and IV drug abuse and states she last used IV drugs 2 days ago. She thinks her symptoms may be related to lifting a heavy box. Her temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 122/88 mmHg, pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for focal back pain lateral to the patient’s spine on the left. There is no midline tenderness and the rest of the patient’s exam is unremarkable. There are scars in the antecubital fossae bilaterally. Laboratory values including a C-reactive protein are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old nulliparous man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of heavy, prolonged bleeding with menstruation, dyspareunia, and cyclical abdominal pain. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals and lasted 4 days with normal flow. Pelvic examination shows an asymmetrically enlarged, nodular uterus consistent in size with a 10-week gestation. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A photomicrograph of a section of an endometrial biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old primigravida schedules an appointment with his obstetrician for a regular check-up. He says that everything is fine, although he reports that his baby has stopped moving as much as previously. He is 22 weeks gestation. He denies any pain or vaginal bleeding. The obstetrician performs an ultrasound and also orders routine blood and urine tests. On ultrasound, there is no fetal cardiac activity or movement. The patient is asked to wait for 1 hour, after which the scan is to be repeated. The second scan shows the same findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her husband insisting that her husband has been acting strange lately. She is a dentist by profession and has no known medical conditions. For the past 6 weeks, she has insisted on listening to the 6 PM news on the radio. She is adamant that the news anchor is referencing her life during the broadcasts. Apart from this, her husband states that her husband is fine. She and her husband deny the use of any prescribed medications or illicit drugs. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol only on social occasions. Physical examination and routine laboratory investigations are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a skin lesion on her nose. The patient has had the lesion for 11 months and it has increased in size over the past few months. She is a farmer and lives together with her husband. Her mother died of metastatic melanoma at the age of 67 years. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks 1–2 glasses of whiskey on weekends. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 140/78 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows a nontender lesion at the right root of the nose. An image of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 48-year-old man presents to an urgent care clinic with the complaints of bloody diarrhea, mid-abdominal discomfort, and cramping for 3 days. He also has nausea, vomiting, and fever. He reports that he had eaten raw oysters at a local seafood restaurant almost 3 days ago, but he denies any other potentially infectious exposures. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. Physical examination is non-contributory. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by her parents because they are concerned about her “strange behavior”. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. The parents state that she has always been a solitary child without many friends, but that recently, she has been having behavioral problems that seem to be unprovoked and are occurring more frequently. The child will throw a tantrum for no reason and does not respond to punishment or reward. She also has a 'strange obsession' with collecting rocks that she finds on her way to and from school, so much so that her room is filled with rocks. Her teachers say she “daydreams a lot” and is very good at art, being able to recreate her favorite cartoon characters in great detail. On assessment, the patient does not make eye contact with the physician but talks incessantly about her rock collection. The child’s grammar and vocabulary seem normal, but her speech is slightly labored. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department when he was found yelling and screaming outside a bowling alley. The patient was found smoking marijuana and eating pizza while stating “if I'm going to die I'm going to die happy.” He was brought in by police and has been compliant since his arrival. Upon questioning, the patient states that he has had technology implanted in his for quite a while now, and he knows he will die soon. Any attempts to obtain further history are not helpful. The patient’s parents are contacted who provide additional history. They state that the patient recently started college 3 months ago. Two months ago, the patient began complaining about “technology” and seemed at times to converse with inanimate objects. On physical exam, you note a healthy young man whose neurological exam is within normal limits. The patient is fixated on his original story and does not offer any information about his past medical history or current medications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old man with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He appears lethargic and confused. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ count of 89 cells/μL (N > 500). A CT scan of the head with contrast shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal ganglia and subcortical white matter. An India ink preparation of cerebrospinal fluid is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of persistent pain in his right shoulder. The pain is localized to the top of the shoulder and is worse with movement. He has stiffness in the right shoulder that is worse in the morning and usually lasts 20 minutes. The patient reports that he is unable to brush his hair and has stopped going to his regular tennis lessons because of the pain. He does not recall any fall or trauma. When his right arm is passively abducted in an arc, there is pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction. When asked to lower the right arm slowly from 90 degrees of abduction, he is unable to hold his arm up and it drops to his side. Passive range of motion is normal. Injection of 5 mL of 1% lidocaine into the right subacromial space does not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion of the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty at school. He does not listen to his teachers or complete assignments as requested. He does not play or interact with his peers. The boy also ignores his parents. Throughout the visit, he draws circles repeatedly and avoids eye contact. Physical and neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 74-year-old Hispanic woman comes to the physician because of a three-week history of dizziness upon standing and a brief loss of consciousness one hour ago. The patient suddenly collapsed on her way to the bathroom after waking up in the morning. She did not sustain any injuries from her collapse. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and gout. The patient's mother died of a grand mal seizure at the age of 53 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 55 years. She drinks three beers and two glasses of whiskey daily. Current medications include ranitidine, dutasteride, tamsulosin, and allopurinol. She is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 22.5 kg/m2. She appears pale. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg supine and 100/70 mm Hg one minute after standing with no change in pulse rate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. A plopping sound is heard on auscultation, immediately followed by a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows regular sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 2-week history of generalized fatigue, intermittent fever, and occasional bleeding from her nose. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F). She appears pale. Physical examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy and multiple petechiae on her trunk. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 63,000/mm3, and platelet count is 30,000/mm3. A bone marrow aspirate predominantly shows immature leukocytes that stain positive for CD10, CD19, and terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT), and negative for myeloperoxidase. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

In your outpatient clinic you are seeing a 22-year-old male for his annual check-up. He has a past medical history significant for sexual abuse in his teens. Currently he has no complaints. He reports that his last menstrual period was 1 week ago. His temperature is 98.5 deg F (36.9 deg C), pulse is 65/min, blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, respirations are 11/min. Physical exam is notable only for dry mucous membranes with multiple dental carries and calluses on the dorsum of his right hand. His BMI is 17. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with bloody vomitus. The patient is an alcoholic and has presented similarly before. She is given ondansetron; however, she continues to vomit. The patient complains of sudden substernal chest pain and dysphagia after another bout of vomiting. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 117/60 mmHg, pulse is 122/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an uncomfortable woman with subcutaneous emphysema in the patient’s neck and supraclavicular areas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 44-year-old woman presents to a clinic for the evaluation of difficulty swallowing for the past few days. She says that she has noticed progressively worsening chest pain when she attempts to swallow solids or liquids. She works from a home office, has not had any recent sick contacts, and is currently not sexually active. Her medical history includes AIDS. Her current medications include emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F),  pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg. A physical examination is notable for a dry mouth with red mucosa and no distinct plaques or patches, and a supple neck with no masses or cervical lymphadenopathy. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows small white patches within the esophageal lumen. A biopsy of one of the lesions is performed and the microscopic appearance of the finding is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 1710-g (3.77-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 27-year-old man at 33 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was uncomplicated, but the mother had a cold and sore throat 2 months before delivery that resolved spontaneously. The newborn appears lethargic. He is at the 15th percentile for height and weight and at the 1st percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. A cranial ultrasound of the newborn shows periventricular calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive headaches, dizziness, and recurrent episodes of vomiting for 3 weeks. She has a history of surgical removal of a sac-like protuberance on her lower back soon after birth. Neurologic examination shows ataxia. Fundoscopy shows bilateral optic disk swelling. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of five episodes of painful oral ulcers over the past year. During this period, she has also had two painful genital ulcers that healed without treatment. She reports frequently having diffuse joint pain, malaise, and low-grade fever. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She emigrated to the US from Syria with her family four years ago. She is sexually active with one female partner and they do not use condoms. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows three painful ulcers on the oral buccal mucosa. Pelvic examination shows that the external genitalia has several healing scars. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of shortness of breath while lying on his back over the past month. During this period, he has also had several episodes of bloody coughing. The patient reports that he had a heart problem when he was a child that was treated with antibiotics. He emigrated to the US from Russia 5 years ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. An ECG shows tachycardia and no P waves. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old child with a history of abdominal and thigh pain that runs in his family is brought into the emergency room by his mother. His mother states they have a "blood disease." He also states the child was coughing and had fever to 101.1 F over the last three days and has been suddenly feeling much worse. On exam, the vitals are HR 110, BP 100/60, RR 20, T 101.5 F. CBC is significant for Hgb 3.2, WBC 2.1, Hct 10, Plts 30000. The reticulocyte count is 1% and the MCV is 81. Bone marrow biopsy shows hypocellular marrow with fatty tissue. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-month-old infant is brought the pediatrician for immunizations and assessment. Her parents report that she is eating well and produces several wet diapers every day. She is a happy and curious child. The girl was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. The infant’s vital signs are normal. Physical growth is appropriate for her age. The physician notes a loud holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border (grade IV) and orders an echocardiogram which confirms the diagnosis of congenital heart defect. Based on echocardiogram findings, the pediatrician reassures the parents that the infant will be monitored, but most likely will not require surgical intervention. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her husband because of a 3-day history of severe pain in her right arm. She also reports that she cannot move her right arm. The symptoms began after the patient woke up one morning, having slept on her side. She is otherwise healthy. She works as a waiter and says that she feels exhausted from working several night shifts per week. She adds that she “can barely keep her eyes open” when looking after their daughter the next day. Since the onset of the pain, she has been unable to work and is fully dependent on her husband, who took an extra shift to make enough money to pay their monthly bills. The patient appears relaxed but only allows himself to be examined after her husband convinces him. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm. Reflexes are normal. She has no sensation to light touch over the entire right arm and forearm. When a pin prick test is conducted, the patient rapidly withdraws the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man comes in to see his physician because he has had undiagnosed abdominal pain for the past 3 and a half years. His pain is not related to meals and does not correspond to a particular time of day, although he does report nausea and bloating. In the past two years he has had two endoscopies, a colonoscopy, and an exploratory laproscopy - without any results. He is very concerned because his mother has a history of colon cancer. The patient has been unable to work or maintain a social life because she's constantly worrying about his condition. What is this patient's most likely diagnosis?

A mother brings in his 7-year-old son because he is worried about his behavior after his teacher called. The patient’s mother says he was told that he has not been doing his assignments and frequently tells his teachers that he forgets about them. In addition, he tends to have a difficult time sitting still in class and frequently disrupts the other children. This behavior has been going on for about 8 months, but recently it worsened prompting his teacher to bring it to his mother’s attention. The patient’s mother was surprised to hear about these issues; however, he admits that he needs to repeat herself several times when asking his son to complete his chores. He also has trouble sitting still when doing homework. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 24-year-old female graduate student presents to the physician for a 2-month history of persistent thoughts and anxiety that she is going to be harmed by someone on the street. The anxiety worsened after she witnessed a pedestrian being hit by a car 2 weeks ago. She states, “That was a warning sign.” On her way to school, she now often leaves an hour earlier to take a detour and hide from people that she thinks might hurt him. She is burdened by her coursework and fears that her professors are trying to fail him. She says her friends are concerned about him, but claims they do not understand because they were not present at the accident. The patient has no known history of any psychiatric illnesses. On the mental status exam, she is alert and oriented, and she shows a full range of affect. Thought processes and speech are organized. Her memory and attention are within normal limits. She denies auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations. The results of urine toxicology screening are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of back pain for the past six months. The pain is worse with exercise and when reclining. She attends high school and is on the swim team. She also states that she lifts weights on a regular basis. She has not had any trauma to the back or any previous problems with her joints. She has no history of serious illness. Her father has a disc herniation. Palpation of the spinous processes at the lumbosacral area shows that two adjacent vertebrae are displaced and are at different levels. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact throughout. When the patient is asked to walk, a waddling gait is noted. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 75-year-old man presents with episodic abdominal pain following meals for the past few years. He says these episodes have worsened over the past month. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 30 years ago, managed with metformin. His most recent HbA1C last month was 10%. Vital signs include: blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 80/min, and respiratory rate 16/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine medical check-up. The patient feels well. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and recurrent panic attacks. She had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. She underwent a left inguinal hernia repair at the age of 25 years. A colonoscopy 2 years ago was normal. She works as a nurse at a local hospital. She is married and has two children. Her father died of prostate cancer at the age of 70 years. She had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit following her myocardial infarction. She drinks one to two beers on the weekends. She has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, fluoxetine, metformin, and a multivitamin. She appears well-nourished. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur that is best heard at the apex. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A parent-teacher conference is called to discuss the behavior of a 9-year-old girl. According to the girl's teacher, she has become progressively more disruptive during class. She is performing poorly in school and has trouble focusing. She is destructive to classroom property, tore a classmate's art project, and takes other children's lunches regularly. She is avoided by her classmates. Her mother reports that her son can "sometimes be difficult." Recently she placed a rubber band around the cats tail, resulting in gangrene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old woman and her mother arrive for a psychiatric evaluation. She is concerned about her health and behavior ever since she dropped out of graduate school and moved back home 8 months ago. She is always very anxious and preoccupied with thoughts of school and getting a job. She also seems to behave very oddly at times such as wearing her winter jacket in summer. She says that she hears voices but she can not understand what they are saying. When prompted she describes a plot to have him killed with poison seeping from the walls. Today, her heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). On physical exam, she appears gaunt and anxious. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. CMP, CBC, and TSH are normal. A urine toxicology test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she was found screaming and clutching her head. She has had nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting for 1 week, fever and left-sided headaches for 2 weeks, and increasing tooth pain over the past 3 weeks. She has no history of ear or sinus infections. She is in moderate distress. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 122/85 mmHg. She is confused and only oriented to person. The pupils react sluggishly to light. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema bilaterally. Extraocular movements are normal. Flexion of the neck causes hip flexion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old man presents to the women’s clinic with chronic pelvic pain, especially during sexual intercourse. He also reports new onset yellowish vaginal discharge. He has no significant past medical history. He does not take contraceptive pills as he has had a copper intrauterine device placed. He smokes 2–3 cigarettes every day. He drinks beer on weekends. He admits to being sexually active with over 10 partners since the age of 14. His blood pressure is 118/66 mm Hg, the heart rate is 68/min, the respiratory rate is 12/min and the temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). On physical examination he appears uncomfortable but alert and oriented. His heart and lung examinations are within normal limits. Bimanual exam reveals a tender adnexa and uterus with cervical motion tenderness. Whiff test is negative and vaginal pH is greater than 4.5. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a large head contusion and altered mental status. At first, the mother says her son got injured when a “pot fell from a shelf onto her head.” Later, she changes the story and says that she hit her head after “tripping over a football.” Physical examination shows cracks in the suture lines of the skull, and there is a flattened appearance to the bone. The patient’s father arrives to inquire on how her son is “recovering from her fall down the stairs.” Upon request to interview the patient alone, the parents refuse, complaining loudly about the request. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic for a routine checkup. He has unintentionally lost 4.5 kg (9.9 lb) in the past month but denies any other complaints. His pulse rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. An irregularly irregular rhythm is heard on auscultation of the heart. Neck examination shows a markedly enlarged thyroid with no lymphadenopathy or bruit. Laboratory tests show low serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level, high T4 level, absent thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin, and absent anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody. Nuclear scintigraphy shows patchy uptake with multiple hot and cold areas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old woman presents to the office complaining of a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and difficulty opening her mouth for the past 5 days. She states that she had symptoms like this before and "was given some antibiotics that made him feel better". She is up to date on her immunizations. On examination, her temperature is 39.5°C (103.2°F) and she has bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. An oropharyngeal exam is difficult, because the patient finds it painful to fully open her mouth. However, you are able to view an erythematous pharynx as well as a large, unilateral lesion superior to the left tonsil. A rapid antigen detection test is negative. Which of the following is a serious complication of the most likely diagnosis?

Five days after undergoing an open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, a 68-year-old man has crampy abdominal pain. During this period, he has also had two episodes of loose, bloody stools. His surgery was complicated by severe blood loss requiring the administration of vasopressors and multiple transfusions. Cefazolin was administered as a perioperative antibiotic. The patient has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease. The patient has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 50 years and drinks 3–4 glasses of wine every week. His current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, amlodipine, aspirin, and metoprolol. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 96/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen with absent bowel sounds. The abdomen is exquisitely tender to palpation in all quadrants. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows an S4 gallop. An x-ray of the abdomen shows air-filled distended bowel. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 81-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased exertional dyspnea and dizziness over the past 8 weeks. She has hypertension for which she takes lisinopril. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old woman presents to the clinic with several days of flatulence and greasy, foul-smelling diarrhea. She says that she was on a camping trip last week after which her symptoms started. When asked further about her camping activities, she reports collecting water from a stream but did not boil or chemically treat the water. The patient also reports nausea, weight loss, and abdominal cramps followed by sudden diarrhea. She denies tenesmus, urgency, and bloody diarrhea. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6° F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. A physical examination is performed where nothing significant was found except for dry mucous membranes. Intravenous fluids are started and a stool sample is sent to the lab, which reveals motile protozoa on microscopy, negative for any ova, no blood cells, and pus cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother for a rash. The patient had a sore throat a few days ago with symptoms initially well-controlled with lozenges. However, today she had a rash covering her body, which prompted her presentation. The mother states that she did smear an herbal remedy on the rash with no alleviation in symptoms and also gave him a single dose of amoxicillin left over from a previous infection. The patient is up to date on her vaccinations and has no past medical conditions. Her temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 102/68 mmHg, pulse is 97/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the findings in Figures A and B. The rash seen in Figure B is very coarse. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 11-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician by his mother with complaints of constant lower abdominal pain and foul-smelling urine for the past 2 days. The patient has had several previous episodes of simple urinary tract infections in the past. His vitals signs show mild tachycardia without fever. Physical examination reveals suprapubic tenderness without costovertebral angle tenderness on percussion. Urinalysis reveals positive leukocyte esterase and nitrite. Further questioning reveals that the patient does not use the school toilets and holds his urine all day until he gets home. When pressed further, he gets teary-eyed and starts to cry and complains that other boys will make fun of his if he uses the bathroom and will spread rumors to the teachers and his friends. He reports that though this has never happened in the past it concerns his a great deal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision of her right eye. She has difficulties opening the eye because of pain. Her left eye is asymptomatic. She wears contact lenses. She has bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. She works as a kindergarten teacher. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
